0;893;35d0f68bb7be2fee0fd0990932773e3ff794d66777632e9e5c5c104f78d9b534;posted_link;r/science;https://www.sciencenews.org/article/google-quantum-computer-supremacy-claim?utm_source=Reddit&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=r_science;['dlwaxv'];['Science_News'];[1571819663.0];['Google has officially laid claim to quantum supremacy. The quantum computer Sycamore reportedly performed a calculation that even the most powerful supercomputers available couldn’t reproduce.'];[nan];2019-10-23;"Science News Magazine; Emily Conover";Google officially lays claim to quantum supremacy;"Quantum supremacy is here
column2: researchers from Google claim.

column1: For the first time
column2: a quantum computer has solved a problem that can’t be performed by a standard computer — at least not within a reasonable amount of time — Google announced October 23. This milestone
column3: known as quantum supremacy
column4: is a long-anticipated step toward useful quantum computers.

column1: The researchers performed the task with a chip consisting of only 53 qubits
column2: the quantum version of the bits found in everyday computers. “It’s fascinating that we can do something so powerful with such a small chip
column3: ” says quantum physicist Mária Kieferová of the University of Technology Sydney
column4: who was not involved with the study.

column1: But don’t expect quantum computers to suddenly take over. The calculation Google’s quantum computer performed was not a particularly useful one. Instead
column2: the task at hand was one that was designed to play to quantum computers’ strengths and to be difficult for a nonquantum
column3: or “classical
column4: ” computer.

column1: What’s more
column2: some researchers are pushing back against Google’s quantum supremacy claim
column3: arguing that the milestone has yet to be achieved.

column1: For about a month
column2: rumors have been swirling among scientists that Google would soon report its achievement of quantum supremacy (SN: 9/21/19). The company’s official announcement
column3: in a study published October 23 in Nature
column4: follows the apparently unintentional posting of an earlier version of the study on a NASA website in September. That paper was swiftly taken down
column5: but copies of it persisted and were shared among researchers.

column1: The concept of quantum supremacy
column2: proposed in 2012 by theoretical physicist John Preskill
column3: has attracted controversy. The term lends itself to hype
column4: and some quantum physicists prefer to focus on metrics that imply practical usefulness — which supremacy does not.

column1: But
column2: says Preskill
column3: of Caltech
column4: the demonstration of quantum supremacy is not only a milestone in computing
column5: but also an advance in scientists’ understanding of quantum mechanics. Making a computer that can perform complex quantum calculations on the scale of quantum supremacy is “an exploration of physics that we’ve never been able to do before
column6: ” he says.

column1: Using the computer
column2: named Sycamore
column3: Google researchers performed a task called random circuit sampling. Essentially
column4: the team performed a sequence of randomized operations on the qubits. “It’s literally as if the code of their program was chosen randomly
column5: ” says computer scientist Bill Fefferman of the University of Chicago.

column1: Then the researchers measured the values of all the qubits. After repeating the process multiple times
column2: the team got a distribution of numbers that was close to random — but not quite
column3: thanks to quantum effects. That resulting distribution is very difficult to calculate via a classical computer. While it takes Sycamore 200 seconds to repeat the sampling process a million times
column4: a state-of-the-art supercomputer
column5: the most powerful type of classical computer available
column6: would take 10
column7: 000 years to do the same task

column1: “With the first quantum computation that cannot reasonably be emulated on a classical computer
column2: we have opened up a new realm of computing to be explored
column3: ” Google researchers John Martinis and Sergio Boixo wrote October 23 in a post on Google’s AI blog. That’s because quantum supremacy is a challenge to an idea known as the extended Church-Turing thesis
column4: a principle of computer science
column5: which states that all reasonable types of computation can be performed by classical computers. If the supremacy claim is correct
column6: it would be the first violation of that principle.

column1: However
column2: on October 21
column3: even before Google scientists officially unveiled their claim
column4: researchers from IBM were challenging it. In a paper posted at arXiv.org
column5: IBM researchers suggested that the calculation that Google says would take 10
column6: 000 years could instead be performed in 2.5 days on a classical computer using an improved technique
column7: though it would still require the most powerful supercomputer on the planet.

column1: IBM has a competing quantum computing effort
column2: which has also developed a 53-qubit quantum computer. The team
column3: however
column4: favors a different performance metric than quantum supremacy known as quantum volume
column5: which incorporates a variety of factors such as how error-prone the qubits are and how long they retain their quantum properties. In an October 21 blog post
column6: those IBM researchers argue that their result means that Google hasn’t achieved quantum supremacy after all. IBM has not yet used a supercomputer to perform such a computation
column8: so that leaves the quantum supremacy result in a “gray territory

column1: Still
column2: quantum supremacy is not a straightforward line to be crossed
column3: says quantum physicist Simon Devitt
column4: also of the University of Technology Sydney. Instead
column5: there’s a nebulous buffer zone. That’s where the new result falls
column6: he says. But “the supremacy stuff is not what really excites me
column8: what gets him going is the new level of control over famously finicky qubits.

column1: “In the end
column2: ” Martinis said in a news conference on October 23
column3: “this experiment is about building the most powerful quantum computer in the world right now and showing that … things are working well.”

column1: Once physicists master the control of quantum computers
column2: the machines could be scaled up to assist with useful problems
column3: like studying the physics that underlies chemical reactions or even cracking encryption techniques used to secure online communications. But those achievements remain far in the future
column4: researchers agree. Quantum supremacy is a step in that direction.

column1: “I think the jury is still out as to whether this is really quantum supremacy
column2: ” Fefferman says. But
column3: “no matter what happens
column4: I’m convinced it’s an impressive experiment. They’re paving new ground
column5: and they’re going where no one has gone before.”";5873;['f4uonhc'

column1: 1;63;d7fabb35ee22a2ac2b64906a450f26bb9197507a952d230da19bf4a195dbe1cf;posted_link;r/space;http://www.astronomy.com/news/2019/05/could-quantum-mechanics-explain-the-existence-of-space-time;['bm6sq4'];['clayt6'];[1557330139.0];"['Space-time may be a sort of hologram generated by quantum entanglement (""spooky action at a distance""). Basically
column2: a network of entangled quantum states
column3: called qubits
column4: weave together the fabric of space-time in a higher dimension. The resulting geometry seems to obey Einstein’s general relativity.']";[nan];2019-05-07;Tom Siegfried;Could quantum mechanics explain the existence of space-time?;"Rod Serling knew all about dimensions.

column1: His Twilight Zone was a dimension of imagination
column2: a dimension of sight and sound and mind
column3: a dimension as vast as space and timeless as infinity. It was all very clear except for the space and time part
column4: the dimensions of real life. Serling never explained them.

column1: Of course
column2: ever since Einstein
column3: scientists have also been scratching their heads about how to make sense of space and time. Before then
column4: almost everybody thought Isaac Newton had figured it all out. Time “flows equably without relation to anything external
column5: ” he declared. Absolute space is also its own thing
column6: “always similar and immovable.” Nothing to see there. Events of physical reality performed independently on a neutral stage where actors strutted and fretted without influencing the rest of the theater.

column1: But Einstein’s theories turned Newton’s absolute space and time into a relativistic mash-up — his equations suggested a merged space-time
column2: a new sort of arena in which the players altered the space of the playing field. It was a physics game changer. No longer did space and time provide a featureless backdrop for matter and energy. Formerly independent and uniform
column3: space and time became inseparable and variable. And as Einstein showed in his general theory of relativity
column4: matter and energy warped the space-time surrounding them. That simple (hah!) truth explained gravity. Newton’s apparent force of attraction became an illusion perpetrated by space-time geometry. It was the shape of space-time that dictated the motion of massive bodies
column5: a symmetric justice since massive bodies determined space-time’s shape.

column1: Verification of Einstein’s space-time revolution came a century ago
column2: when an eclipse expedition confirmed his general theory’s prime prediction (a precise amount of bending of light passing near the edge of a massive body
column3: in this case the Sun). But space-time remained mysterious. Since it was something rather than nothing
column4: it was natural to wonder where it came from.

column1: Now a new revolution is on the verge of answering that question
column2: based on insights from the other great physics surprise of the last century: quantum mechanics. Today’s revolution offers the potential for yet another rewrite of space-time’s résumé
column3: with the bonus of perhaps explaining why quantum mechanics seems so weird.

column1: “Space-time and gravity must ultimately emerge from something else
column2: ” writes physicist Brian Swingle in the 2018 Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics. Otherwise it’s hard to see how Einstein’s gravity and the math of quantum mechanics can reconcile their longstanding incompatibility. Einstein’s view of gravity as the manifestation of space-time geometry has been enormously successful. But so also has been quantum mechanics
column3: which describes the machinations of matter and energy on the atomic scale with unerring accuracy. Attempts to find coherent math that accommodates quantum weirdness with geometric gravity
column4: though
column5: have met formidable technical and conceptual roadblocks.

column1: At least that has long been so for attempts to understand ordinary space-time. But clues to a possible path to progress have emerged from the theoretical study of alternate space-time geometries
column2: thinkable in principle but with unusual properties. One such alternate
column3: known as anti de Sitter space
column4: is weirdly curved and tends to collapse on itself
column5: rather than expanding as the universe we live in does. It wouldn’t be a nice place to live. But as a laboratory for studying theories of quantum gravity
column6: it has a lot to offer. “Quantum gravity is sufficiently rich and confusing that even toy universes can shed enormous light on the physics

column1: 2;561;d508b4daa15ec8fd62acb2a37ae1c70b15013bfe81786fe408b1f984f1a7850a;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/weirdest-idea-quantum-physics-catching-there-may-be-endless-worlds-ncna1068706;['dlvjor'];['izumi3682'];[1571814234.0];['The weirdest idea in quantum physics is catching on: There may be endless worlds with countless versions of you.'];[nan];2019-10-22;Corey S Powell;A weird physics theory is gaining traction. Another version of you might already know it.;"Ever wonder what would have happened if you'd taken up the ""Hey
column2: let's get coffee"" offer from that cool classmate you once had? If you believe some of today’s top physicists
column3: such questions are more than idle what-ifs. Maybe a version of you in another world did go on that date
column4: and is now celebrating your 10th wedding anniversary.

column1: The idea that there are multiple versions of you
column2: existing across worlds too numerous to count
column3: is a long way from our intuitive experience. It sure looks and feels like each of us is just one person living just one life
column4: waking up every day in the same
column5: one-and-only world.

column1: But according to an increasingly popular analysis of quantum mechanics known as the “many worlds interpretation
column2: ” every fundamental event that has multiple possible outcomes — whether it’s a particle of light hitting Mars or a molecule in the flame bouncing off your teapot — splits the world into alternate realities.

column1: Multiple splits
column2: multiple worlds

column1: Even to seasoned scientists
column2: it’s odd to think that the universe splits apart depending on whether a molecule bounces this way or that way. It’s odder still to realize that a similar splitting could occur for every interaction taking place in the quantum world.

column1: Things get downright bizarre when you realize that all those subatomic splits would also apply to bigger things
column2: including ourselves. Maybe there’s a world in which a version of you split off and bought a winning lottery ticket. Or maybe in another
column3: you tripped at the top of a cliff and fell to your death — oops.

column1: “It's absolutely possible that there are multiple worlds where you made different decisions. We're just obeying the laws of physics
column2: ” says Sean Carroll
column3: a theoretical physicist at the California Institute of Technology and the author of a new book on many worlds titled ""Something Deeply Hidden."" Just how many versions of you might there be? “We don't know whether the number of worlds is finite or infinite
column4: but it's certainly a very large number
column5: Carroll says. ""There’s no way it’s
column6: like

column1: Carroll is aware that the many worlds interpretation sounds like something plucked from a science fiction movie. (It doesn’t help that he was an adviser on ""Avengers: Endgame."") And like a Hollywood blockbuster
column2: the many worlds interpretation attracts both passionate fans and scathing critics.

column1: Renowned theorist Roger Penrose of Oxford University dismisses the idea as “reductio ad absurdum”: physics reduced to absurdity. On the other hand
column2: Penrose’s former collaborator
column3: the late Stephen Hawking
column4: described the many worlds interpretation as “self-evidently true.”

column1: Carroll himself is comfortable with the idea that he’s but one of many Sean Carrolls running around in alternate versions of reality. “The concept of a single person extending from birth to death was always just a useful approximation
column2: ” he writes in his new book
column3: and to him the many worlds interpretation merely extends that idea: “The world duplicates
column4: and everything within the world goes along with it.”

column1: How did we get here?
The mind-bending saga of the many worlds interpretation began in 1926
column2: when Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger mathematically demonstrated that the subatomic world is fundamentally blurry.

column1: In the familiar
column2: human-scale reality
column3: an object exists in one well-defined place: Place your phone on your bedside table
column4: and that’s the only spot it can be
column5: whether or not you're looking for it. But in the quantum realm
column6: objects exist in a smudge of probability
column7: snapping into focus only when observed.

column1: “Before you look at an object
column2: whether it's an electron
column3: or an atom or whatever
column4: it's not in any definite location
column5: ” Carroll says. “It might be more likely that you observe it in one place or another
column6: but it's not actually located at any particular place.”

column1: Nearly a century of experimentation has confirmed that
column2: strange as it seems
column3: this phenomenon is a core aspect of the physical world. Even Einstein struggled with the notion: What happened to all of the other possible locations where the object could have been
column4: and all the other different outcomes that could have ensued? Why should an object’s behavior depend on whether or not somebody was looking at it?

column2: a Princeton student named Hugh Everett III came up with a radical explanation. He proposed that all possible outcomes really do occur — but that only a single version plays out in the world we inhabit. All the other possibilities split off from us
column3: each giving rise to its own separate world. Nothing ever goes to waste
column4: in this view
column5: since everything that can happen does happen in some world.

column1: For decades
column2: Everett’s colleagues mostly brushed aside his explanation
column3: treating it more like a ghost story than serious science. But nobody has found any flaws in Schrödinger’s equation; nor can they explain away its implications. As a result
column4: many contemporary physicists — including David Deutsch at Oxford University and Max Tegmark at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology — have come to agree with Carroll that the many worlds interpretation is the only coherent way to understand quantum mechanics.

column1: A field guide to many worlds
The many worlds interpretation raises all kinds of puzzling questions about the multiple versions of reality
column2: and about the multiple versions of you that exist in them. Carroll has some answers.

column1: If new universes are constantly popping into existence
column2: isn’t something being created from nothing
column3: violating one of the most basic principles of physics? Not so
column4: according to Carroll: “It only looks like you are creating extra copies of the universe. It's better to think of it as taking a big thick universe and slicing it.”

column1: Why do we experience one particular reality but none of the others? “What other one would you find yourself in?” Carroll says
column2: amused. “It’s like asking why you live now instead of some other time. Everyone in every world thinks that they're in that world.”

column1: Carroll also has a disappointing response for one of the most compelling questions of all: Could you cross over and visit one of the other realities and compare notes with an alternate-world version of yourself? “Once the other worlds come into existence
column2: they go their own way
column3: ” Carroll says. “They don't interact
column4: they don't influence each other in any form. Crossing over is like traveling faster than the speed of light. It's not something that you can do.”

column1: War of the many worlds
One criticism of the many worlds interpretation is that while it offers a colorful way to think about the world
column2: it doesn’t deliver any new insights into how nature works. “It is completely content-less
column3: ” says physicist Christopher Fuchs of the University of Massachusetts
column4: Boston.

column1: Fuchs favors an alternative called Quantum Bayesianism
column2: which offers a path back to an old-fashioned single reality. He argues that the universe changes when you look at it not because you are creating new worlds but simply because observation requires interacting with your surroundings. No coffee dates
column3: no other lives for you. “In this way
column4: measurement is demoted from being something mystical to being about things as mundane as walking across a busy street: It’s an action I can take that clearly has consequences for me
column5: ” he says.

column1: Coming at the critique from a different angle
column2: Oxford's Roger Penrose argues that the whole idea of many worlds is flawed
column3: because it’s based on an overly simplistic version of quantum mechanics that doesn’t account for gravity. “The rules must change when gravity is involved
column4: ” he says.

column1: In a more complete quantum theory
column2: Penrose argues
column3: gravity helps anchor reality and blurry events will have only one allowable outcome. He points to a potentially decisive experiment now being carried out at the University of California
column4: Santa Barbara
column5: and Leiden University in the Netherlands that's designed to directly observe how an object transforms from many possible locations to a single
column6: fixed reality.

column1: Carroll is unmoved by these alternative explanations
column2: which he considers overly complicated and unsupported by data. The notion of multiple yous can be unnerving
column3: he concedes. But to him the underlying concept of many worlds is “crisp
column4: clear
column5: beautiful
column6: simple and pure.”

column1: If he's right
column2: he's not the only Sean Carroll who feels that way.";8257;['f4up4g5'

column1: 3;423;cea1ee857ff66bf052c61dd4c10226bfd9bc3128c574b5033bd4d9aba32f1d72;posted_link;r/science;https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-01223-4?utm_source=twt_nnc&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=naturenews;['n6qbuv'];['MistWeaver80'];[1620361887.0];['By playing two tiny drums
column2: physicists have provided the most direct demonstration yet that quantum entanglement — a bizarre effect normally associated with subatomic particles — works for larger objects. This is the first direct evidence of quantum entanglement in macroscopic objects.'];[nan];2021-05-06;"Castelvecchi; Davide";Minuscule drums push the limits of quantum weirdness;"By playing two tiny drums
column3: physicists have provided the most direct demonstration yet that quantum entanglement — a bizarre effect normally associated with subatomic particles — works for larger objects.

column1: The findings
column2: described in two Science papers on 6 May1
column4: could help researchers to build measuring devices of unprecedented sensitivity
column5: as well as quantum computers that can perform certain calculations beyond the reach of any ordinary computer.

column1: The counter-intuitive rules of quantum mechanics predict that two objects can share a common
column2: ‘entangled’ state. Measurable properties of one object
column3: such as its position or velocity
column4: are then correlated to those of the other
column5: with a degree of correlation that is stronger than what can be achieved in classical
column6: or non-quantum

column1: Although nothing in the laws of quantum physics limits such quantum weirdness to subatomic particles
column2: the theory predicts that at much larger scales — say
column3: the size of a cat — quantum effects should be so vanishingly small as to be unobservable in practice. Physicists have long debated whether this is just a limitation of our senses and instruments
column4: or whether macroscopic objects are governed by their own set of laws that is fundamentally different from quantum mechanics. To explore this question
column5: researchers have been pushing to observe quantum effects at ever larger scales. “One point of our research is
column6: is there quantum in the classical world?” says Mika Sillanpää
column7: a physicist at Aalto University in Finland.

column1: Quantum drums
In an experiment at the US National Institute of Standards and Technology in Boulder
column2: Colorado
column3: physicist Shlomi Kotler and his collaborators built a pair of vibrating aluminium membranes akin to two tiny drums
column4: each around 10 micrometres long.

column1: Although these structures are barely visible to the naked eye
column2: they are enormous by quantum standards
column3: consisting of around one trillion atoms each. When physicists discovered quantum mechanics a century ago
column4: “people didn’t imagine you could do an experiment with something this big”
column5: says Kotler
column6: who is now at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

column1: The team tickled the membranes with microwave photons to make them vibrate in sync
column2: and in such a way that their motions were in a quantum-entangled state: at any given time
column3: as the drums wobbled up and down
column4: measuring their displacement from flat showed they were in the same exact position
column5: and probing their velocities returned exactly opposite values.

column1: Two other laboratories had done similar measurements on macroscopic vibrating objects in the past
column2: showing indirect evidence of entangled states3
column3: 4. But Kotler and his team were able to ‘see’ the entanglement more directly by amplifying the signal at the moment it came out of their devices. Kotler says this is similar to how old record players pre-amplified their signal before sending it to the amplifier
column4: helping to reduce hiss. The team also improved upon earlier techniques
column5: allowing the researchers to create entanglement more reliably.

column1: Such steps will be crucial for applications such as quantum computers that could encode information in the vibrations of an array of membranes
column2: Kotler says — a radical alternative to current popular approaches
column3: which typically involve electrical currents or atomic systems. Amazon recently announced that it was investigating the possibility of using vibrating crystals to encode and process quantum information.

column1: Testing limits
In a separate experiment with quantum drums
column2: a group led by Sillanpää probed the limits of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle
column3: which states that any measurement must necessarily change the state of the object which is being measured.

column1: The team also built a pair of tiny aluminium drums
column2: and used microwave-frequency photons both to put it in a synchronized vibrating pattern and to read out the drums’ positions.

column1: This experiment had a different purpose to the one carried out by Kotler’s team — the researchers wanted to probe the boundary between quantum and non-quantum behaviour. They tuned the oscillating drums to move in a coordinated but not identical way
column2: so that some of their measurable properties were identical to those of a single
column3: virtual
column4: oscillating drum.

column1: In this way
column2: the researchers were able to measure the position of the virtual drum without affecting its velocity. For a normal quantum oscillator
column3: that would be impossible because of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. To circumvent that fundamental limit
column4: the researchers “use quantum mechanics to hack quantum mechanics”
column5: says Hoi-Kwan Lau
column6: a theoretical physicist at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby

column1: As in Kotler’s experiment
column2: the two drums shared an entangled state
column3: and the measurement technique opens the possibility of studying how entanglement of large objects spontaneously evolves. “We can measure the entangled states continuously without destroying them
column4: ” says Laure Mercier de Lépinay
column5: a colleague of Sillanpää at Aalto and a co-author of the paper.

column1: The quantum-drum techniques could lead to the development of instrumentation that beats the limitations that quantum mechanics imposes on measurement. “One application would be for a force sensor
column2: ” says Lau. Depending on how such a device is engineered
column3: it could measure different types of force
column4: such as magnetic or gravitational
column5: he says.";5337;['gx8lasu'

column1: 4;144;c297f9dd1ad34c426d0ba64b0b62f5a3e8d08985bc429f4d15b1fb6807ec6c75;posted_link;r/worldnews;http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/ibm-quantum-computer-how-work-commercial-api-faster-q-systems-computing-a7613271.html;['5xt03g'];['ManiaforBeatles'];[1488804172.0];['IBM to build quantum computers
column2: selling machines millions of times faster than anything made before - The first practical machines will be available soon enough that developers should start working on software for them
column3: according to executives'];[nan];2017-03-06;Andrew Griffin;IBM is going to sell computers millions of times faster than any ever made;"IBM has taken its first step towards selling computers that are millions of times faster than the one you're reading this on.

column1: The company has set up a new division
column2: IBM Q
column3: that is intended to make quantum computers and sell them commercially.

column1: Until now
column2: quantum computers have mostly been a much hyped but long away dream. But IBM believes they are close enough to reality to start work on getting software ready for when they become commercially available.

column1: Quantum computers rely on quantum mechanics and the bizarre behaviour of quantum bits to do calculations far faster than any computer yet known.
Most researchers agree that the theoretical machines are still years away from actually being made
column2: despite advances towards creating a working quantum computer. But IBM says that its work has shown enough promise to get working on programming the machines.

column1: So far
column2: IBM has demonstrated systems that use quantum effects in small-scale demonstrations. They have taken advantage of effects like superpositioning
column3: which means that electrons can exist in two states at the same time – behaviour that could in the future be harnessed to allow them to work in far more complex ways than the 1s and 0s that are used in today's computers.

column1: That work has shown enough promise that IBM executives believe such computers could soon be made commercially available
column2: they said. As such
column3: the software and the technologies that will be required to run on those computers must be prepared now
column4: they said.

column1: As such it will create APIs that allow developers and programmers to start working on machines that will be able to send programmes between quantum computers and traditional ones. Later this year it will also release a simulator that can mimic the kind of circuits that will be inside quantum computers
column2: allowing people to get to work making software for them.

column1: Eventually those technologies could be put to work in industries like drug and materials discovery or as yet unimagined artificial intelligence.

“Classical computers are extraordinarily powerful and will continue to advance and underpin everything we do in business and society. But there are many problems that will never be penetrated by a classical computer. To create knowledge from much greater depths of complexity
column2: we need a quantum computer
column3: ” said Tom Rosamilia
column4: senior vice president of IBM Systems. “We envision IBM Q systems working in concert with our portfolio of classical high-performance systems to address problems that are currently unsolvable
column5: but hold tremendous untapped value.”";2550;['dekosy2'

column1: 5;679;3fb49c5829f403ce8579165971a9e274dd276ae1188eb0486ab1a9bfced37b6e;posted_link;r/worldnews;https://phys.org/news/2020-12-chinese-photonic-quantum-supremacy.html;['k8cxw7'];['DioriteLover'];[1607330355.0];['In world first
column2: a Chinese quantum supercomputer took 200 seconds to complete a calculation that a regular supercomputer would take 2.5 billion years to complete.'];[nan];2020-12-04;Bob Yirka;Chinese photonic quantum computer demonstrates quantum supremacy;"Chinese photonic quantum computer demonstrates quantum supremacy

column1: A team of researchers affiliated with several institutions in China has built and tested a photonic quantum computer that demonstrates quantum supremacy. In their paper published in the journal Science
column2: the group describes their computer
column3: which they call Jiuzhang
column4: and how well it performed while conducting Gaussian boson sampling.

column1: Quantum computers have been in the news lately as scientists try to determine if they can meet expectations. Quantum computers could vastly outperform conventional machines on certain tasks. The goal is to achieve what has come to be known as"" quantum supremacy""—where a quantum computer can outperform conventional computers on at least one type of task. Until now
column2: only one computer has ever achieved this feat—Google's Sycamore device. And because the field is still so new
column3: researchers around the world are working on vastly different designs. Sycamore was based on qubits represented by superconducting materials. In this new effort
column4: the team in China has developed a photon-based quantum computer capable of carrying out a single specific type of calculation—boson sampling.

column1: Boson sampling is a means for calculating the output of a straight-line optical circuit that has multiple inputs and outputs. It is carried out by constructing a machine in which photons are sent into a circuit in parallel
column2: and once inside
column3: are split by beam splitters. The split photons continue through the circuit
column4: encountering mirrors and other beam splitters. Notably
column5: if two photons happen to encounter the same splitter simultaneously
column6: both unsplit photons will follow one of the paths away from the splitter. The process is repeated
column7: resulting in a distribution of numbers that represent the network output. Conventional computers become bogged down very quickly when trying to calculate distributions of such a system. Jiuzhang was built to handle 100 inputs and 100 outputs using 300 beam splitters and 75 mirrors.

column1: The researchers found that it took Jiuzhang approximately 200 seconds to provide an answer. They noted that it would have taken the world's fastest supercomputer approximately 2.5 billion years to carry out the same calculations—a clear example of quantum supremacy.";2270;['gey6vi6'

column1: 6;181;567f9172509ac9c0cc5d143a4d822932d2ed7c2579a60e7df66d69a346581400;posted_link;r/gadgets;https://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/ibm-reveals-quantum-computing-leap-with-127-qubit-processor/?utm_source=reddit&utm_medium=pe&utm_campaign=pd;['qv4rwc'];['Redditditditdahdo'];[1637058029.0];['IBM’s new 127-qubit processor is a major breakthrough in quantum computing'];[nan];2021-11-16;Zak Islam;IBM Reveals Quantum Computing Leap With 127-Qubit Processor | Digital Trends;"IBM has revealed its latest and most powerful quantum processor
column2: and it represents a key breakthrough in the quantum computing industry.

column1: Dubbed Eagle
column2: the 127-qubit processor becomes the first of its kind to deliver more than 100 qubits. To illustrate just how powerful quantum computing systems are
column3: it’s been a requirement until recently that their qubits have to be cooled at temperatures as cold as outer space.

column1: In order to demonstrate the power of Eagle
column2: IBM highlighted how a computer has typically required more bits than atoms found in every human in the world to successfully simulate the processor.

column1: Due to the substantial quantity of qubits
column2: Eagle is claimed to be the first processor ever created that cannot be simulated on a classic supercomputer.

column1: By increasing the amount of qubits in a quantum computer
column2: it allows highly sophisticated programs to function on such systems that would otherwise not be capable of running on a standard supercomputer.

column1: “The arrival of the Eagle processor is a major step toward the day when quantum computers can outperform classical computers at meaningful levels
column2: ” said Dr. Darío Gil
column3: senior vice president and director of research at IBM. “Quantum computing has the power to transform nearly every sector and help us tackle the biggest problems of our time.”

column1: IBM aims to achieve “quantum advantage” by 2023.
The processor architecture of Eagle features new methods that place control components on several physical levels
column2: while qubits have been incorporated into their own level.

column1: IBM also noted how it had to combine and improve techniques that originated in previous generations of IBM quantum processors so it could develop an architecture that includes advanced 3D packaging techniques. Ultimately
column2: such functionality will allow the company to provide a strong foundation for its processors
column3: which includes the forthcoming 1000-plus-qubit Condor chip.

column1: As for plans pertaining to future IBM quantum systems
column2: Condor in particular is expected to contain 1
column3: 121 qubits in total upon its planned launch in 2023. Eagle’s immediate successor
column4: the 433-qubit Osprey
column5: is scheduled for a 2022 release.

column1: The company also aims to achieve “quantum advantage” by 2023. The term is attributed to quantum computers that can solve problems that are impossible to crack via a classical computer. Condor’s capabilities will help in accomplishing this goal.
Eagle will become available to select members of IBM’s Quantum Network
column2: who have remote access to IBM’s quantum computers
column3: in December. IBM will divulge more information related to its quantum systems at its annual Quantum Summit event taking place tomorrow
column4: November 16.";2657;['hku5yth'

column1: 7;892;7fb30b8281af8185d53cf4a066048a05413ee901ad5e61b1b5c98baa3ea4808f;posted_link;r/worldnews;http://www.sciencealert.com/google-s-quantum-computer-is-helping-us-understand-quantum-physics;['4uhlc3'];['Short_Term_Account'];[1469435950.0];['Google’s quantum computer just accurately simulated a molecule for the first time'];[nan];2016-07-21;David Nield;Google's Quantum Computer Just Accurately Simulated a Molecule For The First Time;"Google's engineers just achieved a milestone in quantum computing: they've produced the first completely scalable quantum simulation of a hydrogen molecule.
That's big news
column2: because it shows similar devices could help us unlock the quantum secrets hidden in the chemistry that surrounds us.

column1: Researchers working with the Google team were able to accurately simulate the energy of hydrogen H2 molecules
column2: and if we can repeat the trick for other molecules
column3: we could see the benefits in everything from solar cells to medicines.

column1: These types of predictions are often impossible for 'classical' computers or take an extremely long time – working out the energy of something like a propane (C3H8) molecule would take a supercomputer in the region of 10 days.
To achieve the feat
column2: Google's engineers teamed up with researchers from Harvard University
column3: Lawrence Berkeley National Labs
column4: UC Santa Barbara
column5: Tufts University
column6: and University College London in the UK.

column1: While the energies of molecular hydrogen can be computed classically (albeit inefficiently)
column2: as one scales up quantum hardware it becomes possible to simulate even larger chemical systems
column3: including classically intractable ones
column4: writes Google Quantum Software Engineer Ryan Babbush.

column1: Chemical reactions are quantum in nature
column2: because they form highly entangled quantum superposition states. In other words
column3: each particle's state can't be described independently of the others
column4: and that causes problems for computers used to dealing in binary values of 1s and 0s.

column1: Enter Google's universal quantum computer
column2: which deals in qubits – bits that themselves can be in a state of superposition
column3: representing both 1 and 0 at the same time.

column1: To run the simulation
column2: the engineers used a supercooled quantum computing circuit called a variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) – essentially a highly advanced modelling system that attempts to mimic our brain's own neural networks on a quantum level.

column1: When the results of the VQE were compared against the actual released energy of the hydrogen molecule
column2: the curves matched almost exactly
column3: as you can see in the graph above.

column1: Babbush explains that going from qualitative and descriptive chemistry simulations to quantitative and predictive ones ""could modernise the field so dramatically that the examples imaginable today are just the tip of the iceberg"".
We're dealing with the very first steps of modelling reality
column2: and Google says we could start to see applications in all kinds of systems involving chemistry: improved batteries
column3: flexible electronics
column4: new types of materials
column5: and more.

column1: One potential use is modelling the way bacteria produce fertiliser. The way humans produce fertiliser is extremely inefficient in terms of the environment
column2: and costs 1-2 percent of the world's energy per year – so any improvements in understanding the chemical reactions involved could produce massive gains.

column1: It's still early days though
column2: and while we've described Google's hardware as a quantum computer for simplicity's sake
column3: there's still an ongoing debate over whether we've cracked the quantum computing code just yet.

column1: Some say Google's machine is still a prototype
column2: part-quantum computer rather than the real deal. But while the scientists discuss the ins and outs of that argument
column3: at least we're starting to reap the benefits of the technology – and can look forward to a near future where computing power is almost unimaginable.";3414;['d5prn9z'

column1: 8;207;fc4a2f9e9a2de71d422ab19b466c6f24cfa418709ff3f4b6f79999130679194d;posted_link;r/science;https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2019-03/miop-prt031119.php;['b0qbe7'];['drewiepoodle'];[1552506057.0];"['Physicists ""turn back time"" by returning the state of a quantum computer a fraction of a second into the past
column2: possibly proving the second law of thermodynamics can be violated. The law is related to the idea of the arrow of time that posits the one-way direction of time: from the past to the future']";[nan];2019-03-13;;Physicists reverse time using quantum computer;"Researchers from the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology teamed up with colleagues from the U.S. and Switzerland and returned the state of a quantum computer a fraction of a second into the past. They also calculated the probability that an electron in empty interstellar space will spontaneously travel back into its recent past. The study comes out March 13 in Scientific Reports.

column1: This is one in a series of papers on the possibility of violating the second law of thermodynamics. That law is closely related to the notion of the arrow of time that posits the one-way direction of time: from the past to the future
column2: commented the study's lead author Gordey Lesovik
column3: who heads the Laboratory of the Physics of Quantum Information Technology at MIPT.

column1: We began by describing a so-called local perpetual motion machine of the second kind. Then
column2: in December
column3: we published a paper that discusses the violation of the second law via a device called a Maxwell's demon
column4: Lesovik said. ""The most recent paper approaches the same problem from a third angle: We have artificially created a state that evolves in a direction opposite to that of the thermodynamic arrow of time.""

column1: What makes the future different from the past
Most laws of physics make no distinction between the future and the past. For example
column2: let an equation describe the collision and rebound of two identical billiard balls. If a close-up of that event is recorded with a camera and played in reverse
column3: it can still be represented by the same equation. Moreover
column4: one could not tell from the recording if it has been doctored. Both versions look plausible. It would appear that the billiard balls defy the intuitive sense of time.

column1: However
column2: imagine that someone has recorded a cue ball breaking the pyramid
column3: the billiard balls scattering in all directions. One need not know the rules of the game to tell the real-life scenario from reverse playback. What makes the latter look so absurd is our intuitive understanding of the second law of thermodynamics: An isolated system either remains static or evolves toward a state of chaos rather than order.

column1: Most other laws of physics do not prevent rolling billiard balls from assembling into a pyramid
column2: infused tea from flowing back into the tea bag
column3: or a volcano from ""erupting"" in reverse. But we do not see any of this happening
column4: because that would require an isolated system to assume a more ordered state without any outside intervention
column5: which runs contrary to the second law. The nature of that law has not been explained in full detail
column6: but researchers have made great headway in understanding the basic principles behind it.

column1: Spontaneous time reversal
Quantum physicists from MIPT decided to check if time could spontaneously reverse itself at least for an individual particle and for a tiny fraction of a second. That is
column2: instead of colliding billiard balls
column3: they examined a solitary electron in empty interstellar space.

column1: Suppose the electron is localized when we begin observing it. This means that we're pretty sure about its position in space. The laws of quantum mechanics prevent us from knowing it with absolute precision
column2: but we can outline a small region where the electron is localized
column3: says study co-author Andrey Lebedev from MIPT and ETH Zurich.

column1: The physicist explains that the evolution of the electron state is governed by Schrödinger's equation. Although it makes no distinction between the future and the past
column2: the region of space containing the electron will spread out very quickly. That is
column3: the system tends to become more chaotic. The uncertainty of the electron's position is growing. This is analogous to the increasing disorder in a large-scale system -- such as a billiard table -- due to the second law of thermodynamics.

column1: However
column2: Schrödinger's equation is reversible
column3: adds Valerii Vinokur
column4: a co-author of the paper
column5: from the Argonne National Laboratory
column6: U.S. ""Mathematically
column7: it means that under a certain transformation
column9: the equation will describe a 'smeared' electron localizing back into a small region of space over the same time period."" Although this phenomenon is not observed in nature
column10: it could theoretically happen due to a random fluctuation in the cosmic microwave background permeating the universe.

column1: The team set out to calculate the probability to observe an electron ""smeared out"" over a fraction of a second spontaneously localizing into its recent past. It turned out that even if one spent the entire lifetime of the universe -- 13.7 billion years -- observing 10 billion freshly localized electrons every second
column2: the reverse evolution of the particle's state would only happen once. And even then
column3: the electron would travel no more than a mere one ten-billionth of a second into the past.

column1: Large-scale phenomena involving billiard balls
column2: volcanoes
column3: etc. obviously unfold on much greater timescales and feature an astounding number of electrons and other particles. This explains why we do not observe old people growing younger or an ink blot separating from the paper.

column1: Reversing time on demand
The researchers then attempted to reverse time in a four-stage experiment. Instead of an electron
column2: they observed the state of a quantum computer made of two and later three basic elements called superconducting qubits.

column1: Stage 1: Order. Each qubit is initialized in the ground state
column2: denoted as zero. This highly ordered configuration corresponds to an electron localized in a small region
column3: or a rack of billiard balls before the break.

column1: Stage 2: Degradation. The order is lost. Just like the electron is smeared out over an increasingly large region of space
column2: or the rack is broken on the pool table
column3: the state of the qubits becomes an ever more complex changing pattern of zeros and ones. This is achieved by briefly launching the evolution program on the quantum computer. Actually
column4: a similar degradation would occur by itself due to interactions with the environment. However
column5: the controlled program of autonomous evolution will enable the last stage of the experiment.

column1: Stage 3: Time reversal. A special program modifies the state of the quantum computer in such a way that it would then evolve ""backwards
column2: from chaos toward order. This operation is akin to the random microwave background fluctuation in the case of the electron
column3: but this time it is deliberately induced. An obviously far-fetched analogy for the billiards example would be someone giving the table a perfectly calculated kick.

column1: Stage 4: Regeneration. The evolution program from the second stage is launched again. Provided that the ""kick"" has been delivered successfully
column2: the program does not result in more chaos but rather rewinds the state of the qubits back into the past
column3: the way a smeared electron would be localized or the billiard balls would retrace their trajectories in reverse playback
column4: eventually forming a triangle.

column1: The researchers found that in 85 percent of the cases the two-qubit quantum computer indeed returned back into the initial state. When three qubits were involved
column2: more errors happened
column3: resulting in a roughly 50 percent success rate. According to the authors
column4: these errors are due to imperfections in the actual quantum computer. As more sophisticated devices are designed
column5: the error rate is expected to drop.

column1: Interestingly
column2: the time reversal algorithm itself could prove useful for making quantum computers more precise. ""Our algorithm could be updated and used to test programs written for quantum computers and eliminate noise and errors
column3: Lebedev explained.";7551;['eighrv8'

column1: 9;1218;e987fc7a843587719db03c4f014d84236021df215151b58332e9d60321fc8374;posted_link;r/gadgets;https://www.tomshardware.com/news/quantum-chip-brings-9000-years-of-compute-down-to-microseconds;['v83f5h'];['Cascading_Neurons'];[1654732216.0];['Quantum Chip Brings 9
column2: 000 Years of Compute Down to Microseconds'];[nan];2022-06-08;Francisco Pires;Quantum Chip Brings 9
column3: 000 Years of Compute Down to Microseconds;"A Quantum Processing Unit (QPU) developed by Toronto
column4: Canada-based Xanadu
column5: has outrageously outperformed a classical system (opens in new tab) in a computing task. We say outrageously because that's one of the few adjectives that encapsulates the performance difference between both systems: the QPU
column6: named Borealis
column7: completed the computing task revolving on gaussian Boson sampling (GBS) in just 36 microseconds. According to the paper published in Nature (opens in new tab)
column8: today's algorithms and supercomputers - the highest-performing classical computing systems - would take an inhuman scale of 9
column9: 000 years to accomplish the same task. Nevertheless
column10: it is enough for the team to claim the coveted quantum advantage (opens in new tab) badge of honor.

column1: Remember that the basic unit of quantum computation
column2: the qubit
column3: can simultaneously represent 0 or a 1. The orders-of-magnitude higher performance in specific tasks than their classical counterparts comes from quantum computers not working on exact computation methods. Instead
column4: they describe how probable a solution is - before making a measurement.

column1: Sadly
column2: there's no practical use for the GBS workload; it's one of the possible benchmarks for testing the performance of quantum processing solutions against classical computers
column3: a space that's still teeming with benchmark standardization attempts from players such as IBM.

column1: Xanadu's Borealis (opens in new tab) is based on the increasingly relevant photonics field as it applies to computing. Specific quantum computing chips use qubits borne from silicon quantum dots
column2: topological superconductors
column3: trapped ions
column4: and other technologies
column5: with some already employing photonics as scaling mechanisms to create interconnected QPUs.The Borealis QPU is photonics-based through and through
column6: unlocking lightspeed-esque operations through its photon-based qubits. The researchers expect photonics-based quantum computing solutions to ultimately provide the most effective way to scale quantum computers' performance. It is mainly due to the advantages of time-domain multiplexing
column8: independent data streams to travel simultaneously masked as a single

column1: The researchers managed to squeeze as many as 219 photon-based qubits onto the Borealis QPU - although the programmable nature of the gates means that that number isn't fixed
column2: and the mean active number of photons was 129. That's still more than IBM's current Eagle QPU
column3: which features 127 qubits - but the company's roadmap does lay out plans to introduce its Osprey QPU
column4: which packs as many as 433 of IBM's superconducting transmon qubits
column5: later this year.

column1: Another element that allowed for the increased quantum performance of Xanadu's Borealis is that the researchers have designed their system with dynamic programmability on all implemented quantum gates. This base circuitry allows for quantum operations to be performed
column2: employing varying numbers of qubits. The programmable aspect of Borealis' quantum gates thus unlocks an FPGA-like architecture that one can reconfigure according to the task.

column1: The researchers further ensured that the computed solutions to the GBS task were correct
column2: which should settle the debate on whether or not quantum advantage was achieved. Xanadu is now bound to continue developing its solution
column3: showcasing very promising results.

column1: Ultimately
column2: they'll also have to convert Borealis into a commercially-available solution. However
column3: researchers can already take the QPU for a spin through Xanadu's cloud and Amazon Braket. But the results bode well not only for the future of photonics but also for photonics-based quantum computing and should be one of the technologies to look at until the anticipated explosion in quantum computing capability currently expected by 2030.";3801;['ibo8oj7'

column1: 10;1217;97d180af0aa24682c633ce8bde6accef045f396e665634307fc22afccb93c7ee;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://twistedsifter.com/2022/07/quantum-processor-completes-9000-years-of-work-in-36-microseconds/;['vrn1gt'];['izumi3682'];[1656986657.0];['Quantum Processor Completes 9
column2: 000 Years of Work in 36 Microseconds'];[nan];2022-07-04;Matthew Gilligan;Quantum Processor Completes 9
column3: 000 Years of Work in 36 Microseconds;"Quantum Processor Completes 9
column4: 000 Years of Work in 36 Microseconds

column1: Technology continues to move forward at incredible speeds and it seems like every week we learn about a new breakthrough that changes our minds about what is possible.
Researchers in Toronto used a photonic quantum computer chip to solve a sampling problem that went way beyond the fastest computers and algorithms.
The paper the researchers published says that the Borealis quantum chip took only 36 microseconds to solve a problem that would take supercomputers and algorithms 9
column2: 000 years to figure out.

column1: Yes
column2: you read that right…9
column3: 000 years.

column1: The Borealis chip uses bursts of light to transmit quantum information and the researchers believe that this is a huge leap forward for quantum chips.
The authors of the study said
“This work is a critical milestone on the path to a practical quantum computer
column2: validating key technological features of photonics as a platform for this goal.”

column1: Quantum computers are different from traditional computers and one major way is to process three units of data instead of only two. The computers we are used to use binary (0
column2: 1) and quantum computers use what is called qubits (0
column4: both).

column1: While this news is certainly exciting
column2: quantum computers still have a long road ahead of them. The UK Ministry of Defence purchased its first quantum computer in order to run tests
column3: but it could be years before we know how or when they’ll be used regularly.";1452;['iewa4lb'

column1: 11;956;46e37ce201a00badaf602f026f9e6e256516a1bbec0d20f4021b8319fa9453cd;posted_link;r/science;https://www.sciencenews.org/article/quantum-physics-imaginary-numbers-math-reality;['rhooth'];['MistWeaver80'];[1639653451.0];['Quantum physics requires imaginary numbers to explain reality. Theories based only on real numbers fail to explain the results of two new experiments. To explain the real world
column2: imaginary numbers are necessary
column3: according to a quantum experiment performed by a team of physicists.'];[nan];2021-12-15;"Science News Magazine; Emily Conover";Quantum physics requires imaginary numbers to explain reality;"Imaginary numbers might seem like unicorns and goblins — interesting but irrelevant to reality.

column1: But for describing matter at its roots
column2: imaginary numbers turn out to be essential. They seem to be woven into the fabric of quantum mechanics
column3: the math describing the realm of molecules
column4: atoms and subatomic particles. A theory obeying the rules of quantum physics needs imaginary numbers to describe the real world
column5: two new experiments suggest.

column1: Imaginary numbers result from taking the square root of a negative number. They often pop up in equations as a mathematical tool to make calculations easier. But everything we can actually measure about the world is described by real numbers
column2: the normal
column3: nonimaginary figures we’re used to (SN: 5/8/18). That’s true in quantum physics too. Although imaginary numbers appear in the inner workings of the theory
column4: all possible measurements generate real numbers.

column1: Quantum theory’s prominent use of complex numbers — sums of imaginary and real numbers — was disconcerting to its founders
column2: including physicist Erwin Schrödinger. “From the early days of quantum theory
column3: complex numbers were treated more as a mathematical convenience than a fundamental building block
column4: ” says physicist Jingyun Fan of the Southern University of Science and Technology in Shenzhen
column5: China.

column1: Some physicists have attempted to build quantum theory using real numbers only
column2: avoiding the imaginary realm with versions called “real quantum mechanics.” But without an experimental test of such theories
column3: the question remained whether imaginary numbers were truly necessary in quantum physics
column4: or just a useful computational tool.

column1: A type of experiment known as a Bell test resolved a different quantum quandary
column2: proving that quantum mechanics really requires strange quantum linkages between particles called entanglement (SN: 8/28/15). “We started thinking about whether an experiment of this sort could also refute real quantum mechanics
column3: ” says theoretical physicist Miguel Navascués of the Institute for Quantum Optics and Quantum Information Vienna. He and colleagues laid out a plan for an experiment in a paper posted online at arXiv.org in January 2021 and published December 15 in Nature.

column1: In this plan
column2: researchers would send pairs of entangled particles from two different sources to three different people
column3: named according to conventional physics lingo as Alice
column4: Bob and Charlie. Alice receives one particle
column5: and can measure it using various settings that she chooses. Charlie does the same. Bob receives two particles and performs a special type of measurement to entangle the particles that Alice and Charlie receive. A real quantum theory
column6: with no imaginary numbers
column7: would predict different results than standard quantum physics
column8: allowing the experiment to distinguish which one is correct.

column1: Fan and colleagues performed such an experiment using photons
column2: or particles of light
column3: they report in a paper to be published in Physical Review Letters. By studying how Alice
column4: Charlie and Bob’s results compare across many measurements
column5: Fan
column6: Navascués and colleagues show that the data could be described only by a quantum theory with complex numbers.

column1: Another team of physicists conducted an experiment based on the same concept using a quantum computer made with superconductors
column2: materials which conduct electricity without resistance. Those researchers
column3: too
column4: found that quantum physics requires complex numbers
column5: they report in another paper to be published in Physical Review Letters. “We are curious about why complex numbers are necessary and play a fundamental role in quantum mechanics
column6: ” says quantum physicist Chao-Yang Lu of the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei

column1: But the results don’t rule out all theories that eschew imaginary numbers
column2: notes theoretical physicist Jerry Finkelstein of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California
column3: who was not involved with the new studies. The study eliminated certain theories based on real numbers
column4: namely those that still follow the conventions of quantum mechanics. It’s still possible to explain the results without imaginary numbers by using a theory that breaks standard quantum rules. But those theories run into other conceptual issues
column5: making them “ugly
column6: ” he says. But “if you’re willing to put up with the ugliness
column7: then you can have a real quantum theory.”

column1: Despite the caveat
column2: other physicists agree that the quandaries raised by the new findings are compelling. “I find it intriguing when you ask questions about why is quantum mechanics the way it is
column3: ” says physicist Krister Shalm of the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Boulder
column4: Colo. Asking whether quantum theory could be simpler or if it contains anything unnecessary
column5: “these are very interesting and thought-provoking questions.”";4824;['horne1j'
column6: 'horwuo6'

column1: 12;1250;bcaed93f93cf90c4d24aaad5664fafef4c94faee13c785ea72976103738cc5b0;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/07/23/us-plan-quantum-internet/;['hx77f6'];['jsamwrites'];[1595615410.0];['U.S. hatches plan to build a quantum Internet that might be unhackable'];[nan];2021-12-15;Jeanne Whalen;U.S. hatches plan to build a quantum Internet that might be unhackable;"The new network would sit alongside the existing Web
column2: offering a more secure way to send and process information

column1: U.S. officials and scientists unveiled a plan Thursday to pursue what they called one of the most important technological frontiers of the 21st century: building a quantum Internet.
Speaking in Chicago
column2: one of the main hubs of the work
column3: they set goals for forging what they called a second Internet — one that would function alongside the globe’s existing networks
column4: using the laws of quantum mechanics to share information more securely and to connect a new generation of computers and sensors.

column1: Quantum technology seeks to harness the distinct properties of atoms
column2: photons and electrons to build more powerful computers and other tools for processing information. A quantum Internet relies on photons exhibiting a quantum state known as entanglement
column3: which allows them to share information over long distances without having a physical connection.

column1: David Awschalom
column2: a professor at the University of Chicago’s Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering and senior scientist at Argonne National Laboratory
column3: called the Internet project a pillar of the nation’s quantum-research program.

column1: “It’s the birth of a new technology. It’s becoming a global competition. Every major country on earth has launched a quantum program … because it is becoming clearer and clearer there will be big impacts
column2: ” he said in an interview.

column1: The United States’ top technology rival
column2: China
column3: is investing heavily in quantum technology
column4: a field that could transform information processing and confer big economic and national security advantages to countries that dominate it. Europe is also hotly pursuing the research.

column1: The Energy Department and its 17 national labs will form the backbone of the project.
How exactly the work will be funded wasn’t clear. The Energy Department did not announce a funding figure for the project Thursday. Speaking to reporters
column2: Paul Dabbar
column3: the Energy Department’s undersecretary for science
column4: said the federal government invests about $500 to $700 million a year in quantum information technology
column5: suggesting some of that money would fund the new Internet.

column1: In an interview
column2: Dabbar said there would probably be further funding announcements for the project in the future.

column1: Panagiotis Spentzouris
column2: head of quantum science at the Chicago-area Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory
column3: or Fermilab
column4: said in an interview that more resources
column5: and a clearer project structure
column6: will be needed to carry out the blueprint published Thursday.

column1: The 38-page document lays out research priorities and milestones to aim for
column2: but it doesn’t assign detailed tasks to particular parties.

column1: Initial users of a quantum Internet could include national security agencies
column2: financial institutions and health-care companies seeking to send data more securely
column3: researchers said.

column1: The networks promise to be more secure — some even say unhackable — because of the nature of photons and other quantum bits
column2: known as qubits. Any attempt to observe or disrupt these particles would automatically alter their state and destroy the information being transmitted
column3: scientists say.

column1: A quantum Internet could also be used to connect various quantum computers with one another
column2: helping boost their total computing power. Quantum computers are still at an early stage of development and not yet as powerful as classical computers
column3: but connecting them via an Internet could help accelerate their use for solving complex problems like finding new pharmaceuticals or new high-tech materials
column4: Awschalom said.

column1: Eventually consumers might also tap into the quantum Internet
column2: to buy products with less risk of their credit card details being hacked
column3: or to send and receive sensitive personal information such as health records or social security numbers
column4: Spentzouris said. It is possible consumers will surf seamlessly between the regular and quantum Internets as they make purchases and send information
column5: without necessarily knowing they are switching platforms
column6: he said.

column1: In a sign of the potential economic rewards that quantum technology could bring
column2: Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker and Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot both spoke at the announcement Thursday
column3: expressing hope that there would be spillover effects for the city’s tech community.

column1: Universities and labs in the region have established the Chicago Quantum Exchange to try to accelerate innovation and economic development.
Pieces of the network are already up and running at various national labs. In the Chicago area
column2: Argonne National Laboratory has built a 52-mile quantum network that soon will connect to nearby Fermilab
column3: to establish an 80-mile test bed.

column1: In New York
column2: Stony Brook University and Brookhaven National Lab have built another 80-mile quantum network.

column1: The plan is to slowly connect these local networks nationwide
column2: using fiber-optic cable
column3: satellites and drones fitted with quantum-communication hardware
column4: Spentzouris said.

column1: A key piece of hardware called a quantum repeater still needs to be developed to amplify a quantum network’s signal over long distances
column2: researcher said.

column1: Awschalom stressed that the country needs to do more to educate a new generation of quantum engineers. “When you ask tech companies what is their number one concern with quantum information technology
column2: the number one concern by far is the workforce
column3: ” he said. Companies will ask him
column4: “Where are we going to hire a thousand quantum engineers?”";5475;['fz48k1f'
