column1: 53;902;65d178ab1755fe72794383d2a04084c8a9dffa268212d16832a8c08120c6920d;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.sciencealert.com/physicists-say-aliens-may-be-using-black-holes-as-quantum-computers;['1124pmv'];['Gari_305'];[1676379281.0];['Physicists Say Aliens May Be Using Black Holes as Quantum Computers : ScienceAlert'];[nan];2023-02-14;Universe Today;Physicists Say Aliens May Be Using Black Holes as Quantum Computers;"If life is common in our Universe
column2: and we have every reason to suspect it is
column3: why do we not see evidence of it everywhere? This is the essence of the Fermi Paradox
column4: a question that has plagued astronomers and cosmologists almost since the birth of modern astronomy.

column1: It is also the reasoning behind the Hart-Tipler Conjecture
column2: one of the many (many!) proposed resolutions
column3: which asserts that if advanced life had emerged in our galaxy sometime in the past
column4: we would see signs of their activity everywhere we looked. Possible indications include self-replicating probes
column5: megastructures
column6: and other Type III-like activity.

column1: On the other hand
column2: several proposed resolutions challenge the notion that advanced life would operate on such massive scales. Others suggest that advanced extraterrestrial civilizations would be engaged in activities and locales that would make them less noticeable.

column1: This makes sense from a computing standpoint and offers an explanation for the apparent lack of activity we see when we look at the cosmos.
The research was conducted by Gia Dvali
column2: a theoretical physicist with the Max Planck Institute for Physics and the physics chair at Ludwig-Maximilians-University in Munich
column3: and Zaza Osmanov
column4: a professor of physics at the Free University of Tbilisi
column5: and a researcher with the Kharadze Georgian National Astrophysical Observatory and the SETI Institute.

column1: The paper that describes their findings recently appeared online and is being reviewed for publication in the International Journal of Astrobiology.

The first SETI survey (Project Ozma) was conducted in 1960 and was led by famed astrophysicist Dr. Frank Drake (who proposed the Drake Equation). This survey relied on the Green Bank Observatory's 26-meter (85-foot) radio telescope to listen for radio transmissions from the nearby star systems of Tau Ceti and Epsilon Eridani.
Since then
column2: the vast majority of SETI projects have been geared towards the search for radio technosignatures
column3: owing to the ability of radio waves to propagate through interstellar space. As Dvali and Osmanov explained to Universe Today via email:

column1: Currently
column2: we are mainly looking for radio messages
column3: and there have been several attempts to study the sky for finding the so-called Dyson sphere candidates – megastructures built around stars. On the other hand
column4: the problem of SETI is so complex that one should test all possible channels.

column1: A whole ""spectrum"" of technosignatures might be much wider: for instance
column2: the infrared or optical emission from megastructures also built around pulsars
column3: white dwarfs
column4: and black holes. A completely new ""direction"" must be the search for an anomalous spectral variability of these technosignatures
column5: which might distinguish them from normal astrophysical objects.""

column1: For many researchers
column2: this limited focus is one of the main reasons SETI has failed to find any evidence of technosignatures. In recent years
column3: astronomers and astrophysicists have recommended extending the search by looking for other technosignatures and methods – such as Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence (METI).

column1: These include directed energy (lasers)
column2: neutrino emissions
column3: quantum communications
column4: and gravitational waves
column5: many of which are spelled out in the NASA Technosignature Report (released in 2018) and at the TechnoClimes 2020 workshop.

column1: For their study
column2: Dvali and Osmanov suggest looking for something altogether different: evidence of large-scale quantum computing. The benefits of quantum computing are well-documented
column3: which include the ability to process information exponentially faster than digital computing and being immune to decryption.

column1: Given the rate at which quantum computing is advancing today
column2: it is entirely logical to assume that an advanced civilization could adapt this technology to a much grander scale. Said Dvali and Osmanov:

column1: No matter how advanced is a civilization or how different is their particle composition and chemistry from ours
column2: we are unified by laws of quantum physics and gravity. These laws tell us that the most efficient storers of quantum information are black holes.

column1: Although our recent studies show that theoretically
column2: there may exist devices created by non-gravitational interactions that also saturate the capacity of information storage (so-called ""saturons"")
column3: the black holes are the clear champions. Correspondingly
column4: any sufficiently advanced ETI is expected to use them for information storage and processing.""

column1: This idea builds on the work of Nobel-prize winner Roger Penrose
column2: who famously proposed that limitless energy could be extracted from a black hole by tapping into the ergosphere. This space lies just outside the event horizon
column3: where infalling matter forms a disk that is accelerated to near the speed of light and emits tremendous amounts of radiation.

column1: Several researchers have suggested that this may be the ultimate power source for advanced ETIs
column2: either by feeding matter onto an SMBH (and harnessing the resulting radiation) or simply harnessing the energy they already put out.

column1: Two possibilities for this latter scenario involve harnessing the angular momentum of their accretions disks (the ""Penrose Process"") or capturing the heat and energy generated by their hypervelocity jets (perhaps in the form of a Dyson Sphere).
In their later paper
column2: Dvali and Osamov suggest that black holes could be the ultimate source of computation. This is based on the notions that: a) a civilization's advancement is directly correlated to its level of computational performance
column3: and b) that there exist certain universal markers of computational advancement which can be used as potential technosignatures

column1: for SETI.
Using the principles of quantum mechanics
column2: Dvali and Osomanov explained how black holes would be the most efficient capacitors for quantum information. These black holes would likely be artificial in nature and micro-sized rather than large and naturally occurring (for the sake of computing efficiency).

column1: As a result
column2: they argue
column3: these black holes would be more energetic than naturally-occurring ones:

column1: By analyzing the simple scaling properties of information retrieval time
column2: we showed that the optimization of the information volume and processing time suggests that it is maximally beneficial for ETI to invest energy in the creation of many microscopic black holes as opposed to a few large ones.

column1: First
column2: the micro-black holes radiate with much higher intensity and in the higher energy spectrum of Hawking radiation. Secondly
column3: such black holes must be manufactured by means of high-energy particle collisions in accelerators. This manufacturing necessarily provides an accompanying high-energy radiation signature.""

column1: Hawking radiation
column2: named in honor of the late and great Stephen Hawking
column3: is theorized to be released just outside the event horizon of a black hole due to relativistic quantum effects. The emission of this radiation reduces the mass and rotational energy of black holes
column4: theoretically resulting in their eventual evaporation.

column1: The resulting Hawking radiation
column2: said Dvali and Osomanov
column3: would be ""democratic"" in nature
column4: meaning that it would produce many different species of subatomic particles that are detectable by modern instruments:

column1: The great thing about Hawking radiation is that it is universal in all the existing particle species. Thereby
column2: ETI quantum computers must radiate ""ordinary"" particles such as neutrinos and photons. Neutrinos
column3: in particular
column4: are excellent messengers due to their extraordinary penetration ability
column5: which avoids the possibility of screening.

column1: This
column2: in particular
column3: offers novel fingerprints of ETI in the form of a flux of very high energy neutrinos coming both from Hawking radiation of information storing micro black holes as well as from the collision 'factories' that manufacture them. The Hawking component of radiation is expected to be a superposition of black body spectra of very high energies.

column1: In the paper
column2: we have shown that the IceCube observatory can potentially observe such technosignatures. However
column3: this is just one potential example of a very exciting new direction for SETI.""

column1: In many respects
column2: this theory echoes the logic of the Barrow Scale
column3: proposed by astrophysicist and mathematician John D. Barrow in 1998. A revision of the Kardashev Scale
column4: the Barrow Scale suggests that civilizations should be characterized not by their physical mastery of outer space (i.e.
column5: planet
column6: solar system
column8: etc.) but of inner space – i.e.

column1: This Scale is central to the Transcension Hypothesis
column2: a proposed resolution to Fermi's Paradox that suggests that ETIs would have ""transcended"" beyond anything we would recognize.

column1: Herein lies another exciting aspect of this theory
column2: which is how it offers another possible resolution to the Fermi Paradox. As they explained:

column1: Up until now
column2: we have completely overlooked a natural direction for SETI in form of high energy neutrinos and other particles produced by the Hawking radiation of artificial black holes. Thereby
column3: various experimental searches for such high energy particles can potentially shed an extremely important light on the presence of advanced ETI within the observable part of the Universe.""

column1: In short
column2: it could be that we see a ""Great Silence"" when we look into the cosmos because we've been looking for the wrong technosignatures.

column1: After all
column2: if extraterrestrial life has had a jump on humanity (which seems reasonable given the age of the Universe)
column3: it stands to reason they would have outgrown radio communications and digital computing a long time ago. Another advantage to this theory is that it need not apply to all ETIs to explain why we haven't heard from any civilizations to date.

column1: Given the exponential rate at which computing progresses (using humanity as a template)
column2: advanced civilizations might have a short window in which they broadcast in radio wavelengths. This is a key part of the Drake Equation: the L parameter
column3: which refers to the length of time civilizations have to release detectable signals into space.

column1: In the meantime
column2: this study offers another potential technosignature for SETI surveys to look for in the coming years. The Paradox persists
column3: but we need only find one indication of advanced life to resolve it.";10252;['j8hzwvi'

column1: 54;1071;f03e79be4c968095d5f1e3b63bc4c9dc2df54259df93de0a4963728af4193288;posted_link;r/science;https://www.stevens.edu/news/quantum-future-which-starship-destroys-other;['cu871h'];['The_Necromancer10'];[1566530527.0];"[""Physicists have shown that time itself can exist in a state of superposition. The work is among the first to reveal the quantum properties of time
column2: whereby the flow of time doesn't observe a straight arrow forward
column3: but one where cause and effect can co-exist both in forward and backward direction.""]";[nan];2019-08-22;;In a Quantum Future
column4: Which Starship Destroys The Other?;"Quantum physicists blur the lines of cause and effect
column5: illustrating how a sequence of events can flip and co-exist at the same time

column1: Quantum mechanics boasts all sorts of strange features
column2: one being quantum superposition – the peculiar circumstance in which particles seem to be in two or more places or states at once. Now
column3: an international group of physicists led by Stevens Institute of Technology
column4: University of Vienna and University of Queensland flip that description on its head
column5: showing that particles are not the only objects that can exist in a state of superposition – so can time itself.

column1: “The sequence of events can become quantum mechanical
column2: ” said co-author Igor Pikovski
column3: a physicist at the Center for Quantum Science and Engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology. “ We looked at quantum temporal order where there is no distinction between one event causing the other or vice versa. So at the same time
column4: A can cause B and B can cause A
column5: in a quantum loop that blurs the lines of cause and effect.”

column1: The work
column2: reported in the August 22 issue of Nature Communications
column3: is among the first to reveal the quantum properties of time
column4: whereby the flow of time doesn’t observe a straight arrow forward
column5: but one where cause and effect can co-exist both in the forward and backward direction. In the upcoming era of quantum computers
column6: the work holds particular promise: quantum computers that exploit the quantum order of performing operations might beat devices that operate using only fixed sequences.

column1: Pikovski and colleagues merged two seemingly conflicting theories – quantum mechanics and general relativity – to conduct a Gedanken experiment
column2: a way of using the imagination to investigate the nature of things. The team
column3: consisting of Pikovski
column4: Magdalena Zych
column5: Fabio Costa and Caslav Brukner
column6: started by asking the question
column7: “what would a clock measure if it was influenced by a massive object in a quantum superposition state
column8: i.e. both near and far at the same time?”

column1: According to general relativity
column2: the presence of a massive object slows down the flow of time
column3: such that a clock placed close to a massive object will run slower compared to an identical one that is farther away.

column1: Based on that observation
column2: the Gedanken experiment goes like this: imagine a pair of starships training for a mission. They are asked to fire at each other at a specified time and dodge the fire at another time
column3: whereby each ship knows the exact time when to fire and when to dodge. If either ship fires too early
column4: one will destroy the other
column5: establishing an unmistakable time order between the firing events. That is
column6: starship A fires before starship B
column7: and starship A survives and starship B is destroyed.

column1: However
column2: if a powerful agent could place a sufficiently massive object
column3: say a planet
column4: closer to one starship it would slow down its flow of time. As a result
column5: the starship would be in line of fire of the attack and be destroyed.

column1: Quantum mechanics complicates the matter. When placing the planet in a state of superposition near one starship or the other
column2: both can be destroyed or survive at the same time. The sequence of events exists in a state of superposition
column3: such that each starship simultaneously destroys the other as two separate events
column4: llustrating for the first time how this quantum scenario can occur and how it can be verified.

column1: “Moving planets around is hard
column2: ” said Pikovski. “But imagining it helped us examine a quantum aspect of time that was previously unknown.”

column1: 55;374;c7c3ba82a7b0f2f913cac7ec1f9a7a4ac50b6af0e462f4e31990aed2c694c775;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.inverse.com/article/36317-quantum-internet-erbium-crystal;['6zmbnt'];['mvea'];[1505215408.0];['Crystal treated with erbium
column2: an element already found in fluorescent lights and old TVs
column3: allowed researchers to store quantum information successfully for 1.3 seconds
column4: which is 10
column5: 000 times longer than what has been accomplished before
column6: putting the quantum internet within reach - Nature Physics.'];[nan];2017-09-11;Alasdair Wilkins;This Glowing Crystal Has the Quantum Internet Within Reach;"And the key element is already found in fluorescent lights and old TVs.

column1: The quantum computer has the potential to revolutionize the 21st century
column2: solving problems so massively complex they would baffle today’s computers. But a single quantum computer is still no match for the more than billion classical computers currently in use. Quantum computers need a quantum internet
column3: and researchers may just have found the perfect — and practical — material to built that network.

column1: A team at the Australian National University details this big challenge facing dreamers who want to create a quantum internet in a paper published Monday in Nature Physics.
How can one store quantum information in a way that can be transmitted across the planet? Being able to keep quantum bits
column2: or qubits
column3: entangled over tens of thousands of miles is a huge challenge
column4: considering it’s only recently that researchers were able to move beyond a few meters.

column1: But it is more an engineering problem than a theoretical one
column2: and their work suggests a crystal treated with the element erbium just might be the answer. These crystals allowed the researchers to store quantum information successfully for 1.3 seconds.

column1: That may not sound like much
column2: but it’s actually a whopping 10
column3: 000 times longer than what has been accomplished before. And when you consider information traveling at the speed of light needs far less than a second to travel around the world
column4: 1.3 seconds is already long enough to start thinking about a global quantum internet.

column1: Erbium is a common enough element found in fluorescent lights
column2: older-model televisions
column3: and lasers. It’s already used in existing fiber optic networks because it naturally operates at the right wavelength to greatly boost communication signals.

column1: It turns out the same principle can work for a quantum communications network. Using erbium-treated crystals means there would be no need to build an entirely new network
column2: as the researchers say quantum information transmitted by using such crystals would be compatible with the planet’s existing telecommunications system.

column1: Any other material than erbium would operate at a different wavelength
column2: meaning a quantum internet would need to convert qubits from wavelength to another and then back again as part of any transmission
column3: which makes an already fiendishly complicated challenge a nearly impossible one. ";2365;['dmwi4gn'

column1: 56;568;279bd7d9482f5c5cb0b48da7f10a0acbfb0ca1ca6b39d7bed849fa9e1ca3f764;posted_link;r/space;https://www.news.com.au/technology/science/big-bang-theory-under-threat-from-quantum-graphity-breakthrough/news-story/405634e8db86f3561e8bae8967f75eb1;['yjhhu'];['DueyDerp'];[1345493912.0];['Big Bang theory under threat from quantum graphity breakthrough. Researchers from University of Melbourne and RMIT believe they may be on the brink of rewriting the history of the universe.'];[nan];2012-08-20;AAP;Big Bang theory under threat from quantum graphity breakthrough;"AUSTRALIAN researchers believe they may be on the brink of rewriting the history of the universe.
A paper being published in a US physics journal suggests it may be possible to view ""cracks"" in the universe that would support the theory of ""quantum graphity""
column2: considered to be the holy grail of physics.

column1: The team of researchers from the University of Melbourne and RMIT say that instead of thinking of the start of the universe as being a big bang
column2: we should imagine it as a cooling of water into ice.

column1: Think of the early universe as being like a liquid
column2: Melbourne University theoretical physics researcher James Quach said.

column1: Then as the universe cools
column2: it `crystalises'.

column1: The reason we use the water analogy is water is without form.
In the beginning there wasn't even space
column2: space did not exist because there was no form.""

column1: Their research rests on a school of thought that has emerged recently to suggest space is made of indivisible building blocks
column2: like atoms
column3: that can be thought of as similar to pixels that make up images on a computer screen.

column1: Mr Quach says the standing model for the origins of the universe
column2: the big bang
column3: needs to be rewritten.

column1: He hopes experimentalists will be able to find evidence to support the theory put forward by the Melbourne team of researchers
column2: that would replace it.

column1: The biggest problem with the big bang model is the bang itself
column2: Mr Quach says.

column1: At the bang
column2: physics breaks down.

column1: The model cannot make any predictions at what occurs at the big bang. You can't use any of the mathematics (or) any of the theories.""
Mr Quach and his fellow researchers theorise that if quantum graphity ""cracks"" do exist
column2: they will bend or reflect light
column3: which
column4: if observed through a telescope would support their predictions.

column1: If they prove my predictions that's really good evidence for the condensed matter model of quantum graphity in which case you can throw out all the other attempts.""";1930;['c5w716v'

column1: 57;3;f6ffcf64352a087bb5c98eceba9a9a83d57cbf02bf72c7cfeddc75b830d031bf;posted_link;r/technology;http://arstechnica.com/science/news/2010/05/quantum-teleportation-achieved-over-ten-miles-of-free-space.ars;['c5wwv'];['dinglebrits'];[1274276536.0];['Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles.  FINALLY. No more lag in my starcraft games.'];[nan];2010-05-19;Casey Johnston;Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles of free space;"Quantum teleportation has achieved a new milestone or
column2: should we say
column3: a new ten-milestone: scientists have recently had success teleporting information between photons over a free space distance of nearly ten miles
column4: an unprecedented length. The researchers who have accomplished this feat note that this brings us closer to communicating information without needing a traditional signal
column5: and that the ten miles they have reached could span the distance between the surface of the earth and space.

column1: As we've explained before
column2: ""quantum teleportation"" is quite different from how many people imagine teleportation to work. Rather than picking one thing up and placing it somewhere else
column3: quantum teleportation involves entangling two things
column4: like photons or ions
column5: so their states are dependent on one another and each can be affected by the measurement of the other's state.

column1: When one of the items is sent a distance away
column2: entanglement ensures that changing the state of one causes the other to change as well
column3: allowing the teleportation of quantum information
column4: if not matter. However
column5: the distance particles can be from each other has been limited so far to a number of meters.

column1: Teleportation over distances of a few hundred meters has previously only been accomplished with the photons traveling in fiber channels to help preserve their state. In this particular experiment
column2: researchers maximally entangled two photons using both spatial and polarization modes and sent the one with higher energy through a ten-mile-long free space channel. They found that the distant photon was still able to respond to changes in state of the photon they held onto even at this unprecedented distance.

column1: However
column2: the long-distance teleportation of a photon is only a small step towards developing applications for the procedure. While photons are good at transmitting information
column3: they are not as good as ions at allowing manipulation
column4: an advancement we'd need for encryption. Researchers were also able to maintain the fidelity of the long-distance teleportation at 89 percent— decent enough for information
column5: but still dangerous for the whole-body human teleportation that we're all looking forward to.";2182;['c0qbpqr'

column1: 58;688;0e2c511268f9d5f0e1d3449da52a048a8fdc7b62e2dde7f005e91eba5787d508;posted_link;r/tech;https://phys.org/news/2021-02-quantum-tunneling-graphene-advances-age.html;['ld51by'];['JackFisherBooks'];[1612523504.0];['Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications'];[nan];2021-02-03;"Moscow Institute; Technology";Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications;"Quantum tunneling in graphene advances the age of terahertz wireless communications
Scientists from MIPT (Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology)
column2: Moscow Pedagogical State University and the University of Manchester have created a highly sensitive terahertz detector based on the effect of quantum-mechanical tunneling in graphene. The sensitivity of the device is already superior to commercially available analogs based on semiconductors and superconductors
column3: which opens up prospects for applications of the graphene detector in wireless communications
column4: security systems
column5: radio astronomy
column6: and medical diagnostics. The research results are published in Nature Communications.

column1: Information transfer in wireless networks is based on transformation of a high-frequency continuous electromagnetic wave into a discrete sequence of bits. This technique is known as signal modulation. To transfer the bits faster
column2: one has to increase the modulation frequency. However
column3: this requires synchronous increase in carrier frequency. A common FM-radio transmits at frequencies of a hundred megahertz
column4: a Wi-Fi receiver uses signals of roughly five gigahertz frequency
column5: while the 5G mobile networks can transmit up to 20 gigahertz signals. This is far from the limit
column6: and further increase in carrier frequency admits a proportional increase in data transfer rates. Unfortunately
column7: picking up signals with hundred gigahertz frequencies and higher is an increasingly challenging problem.

column1: A typical receiver used in wireless communications consists of a transistor-based amplifier of weak signals and a demodulator that rectifies the sequence of bits from the modulated signal. This scheme originated in the age of radio and television
column2: and becomes inefficient at frequencies of hundreds of gigahertz desirable for mobile systems. The fact is that most of the existing transistors aren't fast enough to recharge at such a high frequency.

column1: An evolutionary way to solve this problem is just to increase the maximum operation frequency of a transistor. Most specialists in the area of nanoelectronics work hard in this direction. A revolutionary way to solve the problem was theoretically proposed in the beginning of 1990's by physicists Michael Dyakonov and Michael Shur
column2: and realized
column3: among others
column4: by the group of authors in 2018. It implies abandoning active amplification by transistor
column5: and abandoning a separate demodulator. What's left in the circuit is a single transistor
column6: but its role is now different. It transforms a modulated signal into bit sequence or voice signal by itself
column7: due to non-linear relation between its current and voltage drop.

column1: In the present work
column2: the authors have proved that the detection of a terahertz signal is very efficient in the so-called tunneling field-effect transistor. To understand its work
column3: one can just recall the principle of an electromechanical relay
column4: where the passage of current through control contacts leads to a mechanical connection between two conductors and
column5: hence
column6: to the emergence of current. In a tunneling transistor
column7: applying voltage to the control contact (termed as ''gate'') leads to alignment of the energy levels of the source and channel. This also leads to the flow of current. A distinctive feature of a tunneling transistor is its very strong sensitivity to control voltage. Even a small ""detuning"" of energy levels is enough to interrupt the subtle process of quantum mechanical tunneling. Similarly
column8: a small voltage at the control gate is able to ""connect"" the levels and initiate the tunneling current.

column1: The idea of strong reaction of a tunneling transistor to low voltages is known for about fifteen years
column2: says Dr. Dmitry Svintsov
column3: one of the authors of the study
column4: head of the laboratory for optoelectronics of two-dimensional materials at the MIPT center for photonics and 2-D materials. ""But it's been known only in the community of low-power electronics. No one realized before us that the same property of a tunneling transistor can be applied in the technology of terahertz detectors. Georgy Alymov (co-author of the study) and I were lucky to work in both areas. We realized then: if the transistor is opened and closed at a low power of the control signal
column5: then it should also be good in picking up weak signals from the ambient surrounding. ""

column1: The created device is based on bilayer graphene
column2: a unique material in which the position of energy levels (more strictly
column3: the band structure) can be controlled using an electric voltage. This allowed the authors to switch between classical transport and quantum tunneling transport within a single device
column4: with just a change in the polarities of the voltage at the control contacts. This possibility is of extreme importance for an accurate comparison of the detecting ability of a classical and quantum tunneling transistor.

column1: The experiment showed that the sensitivity of the device in the tunneling mode is few orders of magnitude higher than that in the classical transport mode. The minimum signal distinguishable by the detector against the noisy background already competes with that of commercially available superconducting and semiconductor bolometers. However
column2: this is not the limit—the sensitivity of the detector can be further increased in 'cleaner' devices with a low concentration of residual impurities. The developed detection theory
column3: tested by the experiment
column4: shows that the sensitivity of the optimal detector can be a hundred times higher.

column1: The current characteristics give rise to great hopes for the creation of fast and sensitive detectors for wireless communications
column2: says the author of the work
column3: Dr. Denis Bandurin. And this area is not limited to graphene and is not limited to tunnel transistors. We expect that
column4: with the same success
column5: a remarkable detector can be created
column6: for example
column7: based on an electrically controlled phase transition. Graphene turned out to be just a good launching pad here
column9: behind which is a whole world of exciting new research.""

column1: The results presented in this paper are an example of a successful collaboration between several research groups. The authors note that it is this format of work that allows them to obtain world-class scientific results. For example
column2: earlier
column3: the same team of scientists demonstrated how waves in the electron sea of graphene can contribute to the development of terahertz technology. ""In an era of rapidly evolving technology
column4: it is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve competitive results
column5: comments Dr. Georgy Fedorov
column6: deputy head of the nanocarbon materials laboratory
column8: ""Only by combining the efforts and expertise of several groups can we successfully realize the most difficult tasks and achieve the most ambitious goals
column9: which we will continue to do.""";6774;['gm3zndv'

column1: 59;896;0b2c7fbc152b3e9d3a52714b4970912f238562d485080f628032be3c76266761;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.sciencealert.com/new-study-proves-that-global-quantum-communication-is-going-to-be-possible;['a963g1'];['Valcaralho'];[1545667125.0];['Study Confirms: Global Quantum Internet Really Is Possible'];[nan];2018-12-21;David Nield;Study Confirms: Global Quantum Internet Really Is Possible;"Quantum internet promises ultra-secure
column2: next-generation communications
column3: but is it actually feasible on a global scale?

column1: Absolutely
column2: according to a new experiment carried out between satellites in orbit and a station on the ground.

column1: The team of scientists was able to exchange several carefully managed photons in pulses of infrared light
column2: carried between Russian GLONASS satellites and the Space Geodesy Centre on the ground run by the Italian Space Agency.

column1: Getting these signals to pass through some 20
column2: 000 kilometres (12
column3: 427 miles) of air and space without any interference or data loss is no easy task – but the signs are promising that such a global network could indeed be functional.

column1: Space quantum communications (QC) represent a promising way to guarantee unconditional security for satellite-to-ground and inter-satellite optical links
column2: by using quantum information protocols as quantum key distribution (QKD)
column3: says one of the researchers
column4: Giuseppe Vallone from the University of Padova in Italy.

column1: The quantum key distribution or QKD method Vallone mentions refers to data encrypted using the power of quantum mechanics: thanks to the delicate nature of the technology
column2: any interference is quickly detected
column3: making QKD communications impossible to intercept.

column1: In fact
column2: hacking into a quantum mechanics message would cause it to self-destruct.

column1: So far so good in theory
column2: but keeping these secure channels open across long distances has proved tricky.

column1: The key to the successful data exchange here was the use of passive retro-reflectors mounted on the satellites to keep the long-distance light signals intact
column2: breaking the previous record distance for this type of quantum communication by an extra 15
column3: 000 kilometres (9
column4: 321 miles).

column1: While satellites placed higher in orbit
column2: like the GLONASS ones
column3: are more difficult to communicate reliably with
column4: they pass within sight of ground stations more regularly
column5: potentially enabling an unhackable quantum network that can span the globe.

column1: We're only just getting started with this type of technology – not least because scientists are still trying to figure out if it can actually work – and for the moment it's not clear exactly what a quantum internet would be used for or how it might be operated.
One idea is that it might become a specialised
column2: very secure extension to the normal internet
column3: used by a small selection of apps and devices.

column1: What we do now know is that quantum communications are possible between the ground and high orbit satellites
column2: extending the potential reach of the new technology.

column1: That's important as the satellite networks we rely on continue to get developed and upgraded.
Satellite-based technologies enable a wide range of civil
column2: scientific and military applications like communications
column3: navigation and timing
column4: remote sensing
column5: meteorology
column6: reconnaissance

column1: The core of these systems is to safely transmit information and data from orbiting satellites to ground stations on Earth. Protection of these channels from a malicious adversary is therefore crucial for both military and civilian operations.""";3140;['ecgt6iw'

column1: 60;373;4af6c1fcd8ea04e11b61d9dd9949aee2f906c9839a9df57651fe4ee255d77f75;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/quantum-teleportation-breakthrough-third-dimension-a9075476.html;['cu4f6x'];['QuantumThinkology'];[1566511328.0];"[""Scientists have made a major breakthrough in quantum teleportation
column2: successfully transferring something far more complex than ever before. Discovery opens up new 'dimension' in transmitting information""]";[nan];2019-08-22;Andrew Griffin;Scientists announce major breakthrough in 'quantum teleportation';"Scientists have made a major breakthrough in quantum teleportation
column3: successfully transferring something far more complex than ever before.

column1: Quantum teleportation is a still mysterious phenomena that can see information flung across space.

The effect is not the same as the teleportation often seen in science fiction – where matter is moved through space – but instead is the transfer information about the quantum state of a particle. It could have huge and unimagined effects on the way we organise and transmit information
column2: including the possibility of a vastly more complicated quantum internet.

column1: Until now
column2: scientists have only been able to teleport quantum bits
column3: or qubits. Those are the simplest possible piece of quantum information
column4: where a particle can be in two states at once.

column1: But a qutrit – which scientists have now successfully teleported – adds a whole extra dimension. If a qubit is polarised in two ways at once
column2: a qutrit is polarised in three directions – a vastly more complicated unit
column3: and a far greater challenge for the scientists involved.

column1: It means
column2: in effect
column3: that scientists have more detailed information that can be teleported. A qubit could be 0 or 1; a qutrit can be 0
column4: 1 or 2.

column1: Sending a qutrit rather than a qubit means a vast increase in complexity
column2: because of the nature of the process.

column1: But it also means that the effect could be far more useful. The extra information that can be transferred could power technologies such as a possible quantum internet
column2: allowing for instant and very secure communication.

column1: “The higher the dimensions of your quantum system
column2: the more secure you can ensure your communication is and the more information you can encode
column3: ” Ciarán Lee
column4: from University College London
column5: told New Scientist. “But going from a qubit to a qutrit is especially difficult — the tricks you use for qubits have to do with a nice symmetry that qutrits don’t have.”

column1: The researchers report in their new paper
column2: published in Physical Review Letters
column3: that the demonstrations of their technique had a 75 per cent fidelity. That may appear low
column4: but is far better than similar techniques that do not use quantum entanglement and is likely to improve in time.";2183;['exscwre'

column1: 61;680;0deea3506c00dd4a4d67a8411123c2d0e7053620ef64df1a5cf01e3d6272b5d0;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2020-08-scientists-quantum-states-longer.html;['i9k0nh'];['izumi3682'];[1597403432.0];['Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column2: 000 times longer'];[nan];2020-08-13;Louise Lerner;Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column3: 000 times longer;"Scientists discover way to make quantum states last 10
column4: 000 times longer

column1: If we can harness it
column2: quantum technology promises fantastic new possibilities. But first
column3: scientists need to coax quantum systems to stay yoked for longer than a few millionths of a second.

column1: A team of scientists at the University of Chicago's Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering announced the discovery of a simple modification that allows quantum systems to stay operational—or ""coherent""—10
column2: 000 times longer than before. Though the scientists tested their technique on a particular class of quantum systems called solid-state qubits
column3: they think it should be applicable to many other kinds of quantum systems and could thus revolutionize quantum communication
column4: computing and sensing.

column1: This breakthrough lays the groundwork for exciting new avenues of research in quantum science
column2: said study lead author David Awschalom
column3: the Liew Family Professor in Molecular Engineering
column4: senior scientist at Argonne National Laboratory and director of the Chicago Quantum Exchange. ""The broad applicability of this discovery
column5: coupled with a remarkably simple implementation
column6: allows this robust coherence to impact many aspects of quantum engineering. It enables new research opportunities previously thought impractical.""

column1: Down at the level of atoms
column2: the world operates according to the rules of quantum mechanics—very different from what we see around us in our daily lives. These different rules could translate into technology like virtually unhackable networks or extremely powerful computers; the U.S. Department of Energy released a blueprint for the future quantum internet in an event at UChicago on July 23. But fundamental engineering challenges remain: Quantum states need an extremely quiet
column3: stable space to operate
column4: as they are easily disturbed by background noise coming from vibrations
column5: temperature changes or stray electromagnetic fields.

column1: Thus
column2: scientists try to find ways to keep the system coherent as long as possible. One common approach is physically isolating the system from the noisy surroundings
column3: but this can be unwieldy and complex. Another technique involves making all of the materials as pure as possible
column4: which can be costly. The scientists at UChicago took a different tack.

column1: With this approach
column2: we don't try to eliminate noise in the surroundings; instead
column3: we ""trick"" the system into thinking it doesn't experience the noise
column4: said postdoctoral researcher Kevin Miao
column5: the first author of the paper.

column1: In tandem with the usual electromagnetic pulses used to control quantum systems
column2: the team applied an additional continuous alternating magnetic field. By precisely tuning this field
column3: the scientists could rapidly rotate the electron spins and allow the system to ""tune out"" the rest of the noise.

column1: To get a sense of the principle
column2: it's like sitting on a merry-go-round with people yelling all around you
column3: Miao explained. ""When the ride is still
column4: you can hear them perfectly
column5: but if you're rapidly spinning
column6: the noise blurs into a background.""

column1: This small change allowed the system to stay coherent up to 22 milliseconds
column2: four orders of magnitude higher than without the modification—and far longer than any previously reported electron spin system. (For comparison
column3: a blink of an eye takes about 350 milliseconds). The system is able to almost completely tune out some forms of temperature fluctuations
column4: physical vibrations
column5: and electromagnetic noise
column6: all of which usually destroy quantum coherence.

column1: The simple fix could unlock discoveries in virtually every area of quantum technology
column2: the scientists said.

column1: This approach creates a pathway to scalability
column2: said Awschalom. ""It should make storing quantum information in electron spin practical. Extended storage times will enable more complex operations in quantum computers and allow quantum information transmitted from spin-based devices to travel longer distances in networks.""

column1: Though their tests were run in a solid-state quantum system using silicon carbide
column2: the scientists believe the technique should have similar effects in other types of quantum systems
column3: such as superconducting quantum bits and molecular quantum systems. This level of versatility is unusual for such an engineering breakthrough.

column1: There are a lot of candidates for quantum technology that were pushed aside because they couldn't maintain quantum coherence for long periods of time
column2: Miao said. ""Those could be re-evaluated now that we have this way to massively improve coherence.

column1: The best part is
column2: it's incredibly easy to do
column3: he added. ""The science behind it is intricate
column4: but the logistics of adding an alternating magnetic field are very straightforward.""";4681;['g1g0cse'

column6: 'g1fmuul'

column1: 62;1072;c6fa1f05a17773064ca90289cfc5153caa0e4780b78cea5593e2548b3ff70026;posted_link;r/technology;https://singularityhub.com/2022/06/07/a-photonic-quantum-device-took-microseconds-to-do-a-task-a-conventional-computer-would-spend-9000-years-on/;['v8tkxn'];['Vailhem'];[1654816232.0];['Quantum Chip Takes Microseconds to Do a Task a Supercomputer Would Spend 9
column2: 000 Years On'];[nan];2022-06-07;Shelly Fan;Quantum Chip Takes Microseconds to Do a Task a Supercomputer Would Spend 9
column3: 000 Years On;"Are quantum computers overhyped?

column1: A new study in Nature says no. A cleverly-designed quantum device developed by Xanadu
column2: a company based in Toronto
column3: Canada
column4: obliterated conventional computers on a benchmark task that would otherwise take over 9
column5: 000 years.

column1: For the quantum chip Borealis
column2: answers came within 36 microseconds.

column1: Xanadu’s accomplishment is the latest to demonstrate the power of quantum computing over conventional computers—a seemingly simple idea dubbed quantum advantage.
Theoretically
column2: the concept makes sense. Unlike conventional computers
column3: which calculate in sequence using binary bits—0 or 1—quantum devices tap into the weirdness of the quantum world
column4: where 0 and 1 can both exist at the same time with differing probabilities. The data is processed in qubits
column5: a noncommittal unit that simultaneously performs multiple calculations thanks to its unique physics.

column1: Translation? A quantum computer is like a hyper-efficient multitasker
column2: whereas conventional computers are far more linear. When given the same problem
column3: a quantum computer should be able to trounce any supercomputer in any problem in terms of speed and efficiency. The idea
column4: dubbed “quantum supremacy
column5: ” has been the driving force to push for a new generation of computers completely alien to anything previously made.

column1: The problem? Proving quantum supremacy is extremely difficult. As quantum devices increasingly leave the lab to solve more real-world problems
column2: scientists are embracing an intermediate benchmark: quantum advantage
column3: which is the idea that a quantum computer can beat a conventional one at just one task—any task.

column1: Back in 2019
column2: Google broke the internet showcasing the first example of a quantum computer
column3: Sycamore
column4: solving a computational problem in just 200 seconds with 54 qubits—compared to a conventional supercomputer’s estimate of 10
column5: 000 years. A Chinese team soon followed with a second fascinating showcase of quantum computational advantage
column6: with the machine spitting out answers that would take a supercomputer over two billion years.

column1: Yet a crucial question remains: are any of these quantum devices even close to being ready for practical use?
A Drastic Redesign
It’s easy to forget that computers rely on physics. Our current system
column2: for example
column3: taps into electrons and cleverly-designed chips to perform their functions. Quantum computers are similar
column4: but they rely on alternative particle physics. Initial generations of quantum machines looked like delicate
column5: shimmering chandeliers. While absolutely gorgeous
column6: compared to a compact smartphone chip
column7: they’re also completely impractical. The hardware often requires tightly-controlled climates—for example
column8: near absolute zero temperature—to reduce interference and boost the computer’s efficacy.

column1: The core concept of quantum computing is the same: qubits processing data in superposition
column2: a quantum physics quirk that allows them to encode 0s
column3: 1s
column4: or both at the same time. The hardware that supports the idea vastly differs.

column1: Google’s Sycamore
column2: for example
column3: uses superconducting metal loops—a setup popular with other tech giants including IBM
column4: which introduced Eagle
column5: a powerful 127-qubit quantum chip in 2021 that’s about the size of a quarter. Other iterations from companies such as Honeywell and IonQ took a different approach
column6: tapping into ions—atoms with one or more electrons removed—as their main source for quantum computing.

column1: Another idea relies on photons
column2: or particles of light. It’s already been proven useful: the Chinese demonstration of quantum advantage
column3: for example
column4: used a photonic device. But the idea’s also been shunned as a mere stepping stone towards quantum computing rather than a practical solution
column5: largely because of difficulties in engineering and setup.

column1: A Photonic Revolution
Xanadu’s team proved naysayers wrong. The new chip
column2: Borealis
column3: is marginally similar to the one in the Chinese study in that it uses photons—rather than superconducting materials or ions—for computation.

column1: But it has a huge advantage: it’s programmable. “Previous experiments typically relied on static networks
column2: in which each component is fixed once fabricated
column3: ” explained Dr. Daniel Jost Brod at the Federal Fluminense University at Rio de Janeiro in Brazil
column4: who was not involved in the study. The earlier quantum advantage demonstration in the Chinese study used a static chip. With Borealis
column5: however
column6: the optical elements “can all be readily programmed
column7: ” making it less of a single-use device and more of an actual computer potentially capable of solving multiple problems. (The quantum playground is available on the cloud for anyone to experiment and explore once you sign up.)

column1: The chip’s flexibility comes from an ingenious design update
column2: an “innovative scheme [that] offers impressive control and potential for scaling
column3: ” said Brod.

column1: The team zeroed in on a problem called Gaussian boson sampling
column2: a benchmark for evaluating quantum computing prowess. The test
column3: while extraordinarily difficult computationally
column4: doesn’t have much impact on real-world problems. However
column5: like chess or Go for measuring AI performance
column6: it acts as an unbiased judge to examine quantum computing performance. It’s a “gold standard” of sorts: “Gaussian boson sampling is a scheme designed to demonstrate the advantages of quantum devices over classical computers

column1: The setup is like a carnival funhouse mirror tent in a horror movie. Special states of light (and photons)—amusingly called “squeezed states”—are tunneled onto the chip embedded with a network of beam splitters. Each beam splitter acts like a semi-reflective mirror: depending on how the light hits
column2: it splits into multiple daughters
column3: with some reflecting back and others passing through. At the end of the contraption is an array of photon detectors. The more beam splitters
column4: the more difficult it is to calculate how any individual photon will end up at any given detector.

column1: As another visualization: picture a bean machine
column2: a peg-studded board encased in glass. To play
column3: you drop a puck into the pegs at the top. As the puck falls
column4: it randomly hits different pegs
column5: eventually landing in a numbered slot.

column1: Gaussian boson sampling replaces the pucks with photons
column2: with the goal of detecting which photon lands in which detector slot. Due to quantum properties
column3: the possible resulting distributions grow exponentially
column4: rapidly outpacing any supercomputer powers. It’s an excellent benchmark
column5: explained Brod
column6: largely because we understand the underlying physics
column7: and the setup suggests that even a few hundred photons can challenge supercomputers.

column1: Taking up the challenge
column2: the new study reimagined a photonic quantum device with an admirable 216 qubits. Contradicting classic designs
column3: the device calculated photons in bins of arrival time rather than the previous standard of direction. The trick was to introduce loops of optical fibers to delay photons so they can interfere at specific spots important for quantum computation.

column1: These tweaks led to a vastly slimmed-down device. The usual large network of beam splitters—normally needed for photon communications—can be reduced to just three to accommodate all the necessary delays for photons to interact and compute the task. The loop designs
column2: along with other components
column3: are also “readily programmable” in that a beam splitter can be fine-tuned in real time—like editing computer code
column4: but at the hardware level.

column1: The team also aced a standard sanity check
column2: certifying that the output data was correct.

column1: For now
column2: studies that reliably show quantum supremacy remain rare. Conventional computers have a half century head start. As algorithms keep evolving on conventional computers—especially those that tap into powerful AI-focused chips or neuromorphic computing designs—they may even readily outperform quantum devices
column3: leaving them struggling to catch up.

column1: But that’s the fun of the chase. “Quantum advantage is not a well-defined threshold
column2: based on a single figure of merit. And as experiments develop
column3: so too will techniques to simulate them —we can expect record-setting quantum devices and classical algorithms in the near future to take turns in challenging each other for the top spot
column4: ” said Brod.

column1: “It might not be the end of the story
column2: ” he continued. But the new study “is a leap forward for quantum physics in this race.”";8308;['ibsn6in'
column3: 'ibsri8e'
column4: 'ibsmn9i'
column5: 'ibss51q'
column6: 'ibstk9a'

column1: 63;631;d557fd7802605398f409715709e87437a907a0eed870bcbb74c3d63f7dc520de;posted_link;r/tech;https://www.newsweek.com/time-reversed-quantum-computer-1361215;['b0lm2i'];['JLBesq1981'];[1552481276.0];['Scientists have reversed time in a quantum computer'];[nan];2019-03-13;Hannah Osborne;Scientists Have Reversed Time in a Quantum Computer;"Scientists have demonstrated time reversal in a quantum computer
column2: returning three qubits (the basic unit of quantum information) to their state a fraction of a second earlier.

column1: In physics
column2: systems traveling forward in time evolve from a simple state to a more complicated one—known as the thermodynamic arrow of time. For example
column3: if you were to put a drop of ink into a glass of water
column4: initially it would have a well-defined state. However
column5: it soon starts to spread out and within a few minutes it will have uniformly dissolved into the water. If time were reversed for a human
column6: they would become younger.

column1: In a study published in the journal Scientific Reports
column2: scientists from the U.S. and Russia have experimentally demonstrated time reversal—sending a qubit from a more complicated state to a simpler one.

column1: The algorithm they suggest changes the quantum developed state so it starts to develop back in time. ""Doing this magic with the developed state of ink we will see that after the same time (time needed for the dissolving of ink in the water) the ink will again combine back into the original drop
column2: study author Andrei Lebedev told Newsweek. ""This is exactly what we did in our work where the drop of ink is state of three qubits
column3: and the water is a Hilbert state of the quantum computer.""

column1: Lead author Gordey Lesovik said in a statement: ""This is one in a series of papers on the possibility of violating the second law of thermodynamics. That law is closely related to the notion of the arrow of time that posits the one-way direction of time: from the past to the future.""
In the experiment
column2: researchers set the state of each qubit to what you would think of as zero. From this point
column3: the order is lost and the qubits became more and more complex
column4: changing to a pattern of zeros and ones. Next
column5: time was reversed by a specially developed program that allows the quantum computer to go from a state of chaos to order—going from complex to simple. As a result
column6: the qubits are sent backwards in time.

column1: The program was successful in a two qubit quantum computer around 85 percent of the time. When a third qubit was introduced
column2: more errors occurred and the success rate fell to around 50 percent. So developing a quantum computer that can reverse time on a large scale is not going to happen any time soon. Furthermore
column3: it indicates time reversal in nature is unlikely because it is too complex.

column1: Such an unfortunate growth of the complexity explains why do we not observe such time-reversed objects in the Nature
column2: Lebedev said. ""The probability of a spontaneous appearance of a time-reversed object (particle of a system of particles) is negligible.""

column1: However
column2: he also said their time reversal algorithm could be used to test quantum computer programs. ""In quantum computation
column3: unlike the classical analog
column4: we cannot interrupt the computation process until the very end.

column1: The problem is that a quantum computer is in the superposition state and if we interrupt it and measure its state we destroy this superposition and project it into one component with some probability.

Because of that it is not always obvious to verify what at the end of the computation we get is the correct result… Time reversal can help—we do time-reversal of the final state of the computer and run the same quantum program again. If the computation was correct we will arrive to the initial state of the computer.""
Commenting on the findings
column2: Henning Bostelmann
column3: from the Department of Mathematics at the U.K.'s University of York
column4: said that while the researchers have reversed the time evolution of a quantum system
column5: a far larger quantum computer would be needed to perform the experiment on a system of a reasonable size.

column1: He also said it suggests that time reversal for individual atoms or electrons is unlikely. ""Perhaps to the disappointment of science-fiction fans
column2: I should point out that the article does not discuss time travel
column3: or going back to the past
column4: or reversing the principle of cause and effect
column5: Bostelmann
column6: who was not involved in the study

column1: Lebedev said he and the team now plan to investigate time reversal further
column2: and look for situations in nature where their procedure could be more effective.";4215;['eifl5t2'

column1: 64;966;2be0d8fe7e5daa86ffb1b15af7319940e649bf382eede35623ee5b04f9068395;posted_link;r/technews;https://scitechdaily.com/free-open-access-quantum-computer-now-operational/;['meqr5g'];['MichaelTen'];[1616892067.0];['Free Open-Access Quantum Computer Now Operational'];[nan];2021-03-19;Mike O'Neill;Free Open-Access Quantum Computer Now Operational;"Scientists worldwide can use ion-based testbed at Sandia National Laboratories.

A new Department of Energy open-access quantum computing testbed is ready for the public. Scientists from Indiana University recently became the first team to begin using Sandia National Laboratories’ Quantum Scientific Computing Open User Testbed
column2: or QSCOUT.

column1: Quantum computers are poised to become major technological drivers over the coming decades. But to get there
column2: scientists need to experiment with quantum machines that relatively few universities or companies have. Now
column3: scientists can use Sandia’s QSCOUT for research that might not be possible at their home institutions
column4: without the cost or restrictions of using a commercial testbed.

column1: “QSCOUT serves a need in the quantum community by giving users the controls to study the machine itself
column2: which aren’t yet available in commercial quantum computing systems. It also saves theorists and scientists from the trouble of building their own machines. We hope to gain new insights into quantum performance and architecture as well as solve problems that require quantum computation
column3: ” said Sandia physicist and QSCOUT lead Susan Clark.

column1: She said the new testbed is a rare machine in three ways: first
column2: as a free
column3: open-access testbed; second
column4: as one made with trapped ion technology; and third
column5: as a platform that gives users an uncommon amount of control over their research.

column1: Last month
column2: Sandia began running the testbed’s first user experiment for scientists from Indiana University. Researchers from IBM
column3: Oak Ridge National Laboratory
column4: the University of New Mexico and the University of California
column5: Berkeley
column6: have also been selected to begin experiments soon. Their projects range from testing benchmarking techniques to developing algorithms that could someday solve problems in chemistry too complex for normal computers.

column1: Researchers interested in using the Quantum Scientific Computing Open User Testbed are invited to sign up for notifications by emailing [email protected]. Sandia expects to select the next round of projects in the spring
column2: subject to change.

column1: Sandia soliciting proposals
Now
column2: Sandia is getting ready for more research proposals. Anyone can submit a proposal to use QSCOUT
column3: and computing time is free thanks to funding from the DOE Office of Science
column4: Advanced Scientific Computing Research program. The next group of projects is expected to be selected in the spring.

column1: On top of providing an exceptional research opportunity
column2: QSCOUT has a rare design for a testbed. Most commercial testbeds use technology called superconducting circuits. Such machines need to be kept at ultralow temperatures
column3: making them expensive to build and operate. But Sandia’s testbed uses what is called an ion trap instead. This means Sandia’s testbed can run at warmer temperatures. Trapped ions also yield clearer signals than circuits and hold on to information longer
column4: enabling scientists to perform different types of experiments and compare the two platforms.

column1: Trapped ions are held inside QSCOUT in a so-called “trap on a chip
column2: ” a flat
column3: bow tie-shaped device
column4: about 2 cm (0.8 inches) long
column5: overlaid on a semiconductor chip. Three electrically charged atoms of the element ytterbium are suspended in place by radio waves and an electric field above a hairline channel that runs down the center of the device. Lasers encode information in each ion as a qubit
column6: comparable to a bit in a conventional computer

column1: Sandia plans to expand the system from three to 32 qubits over the next three years so scientists can perform more sophisticated tests.";3604;['gsjhqt5'

column1: 65;1182;198e2416cf4bae6d79ecf481c6468a7871e786996523c95324b8549d611ae84f;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.thesciverse.com/2022/06/uk-military-wants-to-install-quantum.html;['vc2907'];['soulpost'];[1655209245.0];['UK military wants to install quantum computers in tanks'];[nan];2022-06-14;Blogger;UK military wants to install quantum computers in tanks;"According to New Scientist
column2: the UK Ministry of Defense recently purchased a quantum computer to see if the technology may one day be used to make tanks smart.

column1: The acquisition was revealed this week by Richard Murray
column2: the CEO of quantum computing firm Orca. Part of the reason Orca's product caught the MoD's interest
column3: according to Murray
column4: is that some of their devices can fit on a standard computer shelf and work at ambient temperature.

column1: Murray told the outlet
column2: ""It lends itself to all of those sorts of things
column3: plus it's more durable."" ""I mean
column4: maybe a fighter plane one day. I believe we're concentrating on a larger-scale platform that can be deployed on the ground.""

column1: But there's a major issue: it's unclear what these computers are expected to accomplish on board any type of military equipment
column2: especially because experts have yet to demonstrate that the technology has any innovative
column3: real-world uses.

column1: This equipment we're giving to them surely won't accomplish anything a conventional computer won't
column2: Murray told New Scientist. ""I suppose
column3: in that view
column4: it's a research instrument."" ""Right now
column5: a lot of activity is being supported.

column1: That's a little hazy. Quantum computers have already been proven to dramatically accelerate the solution of extremely particular mathematical problems.
Even less obvious is how those talents may be used to assist in a combat situation.
Through applications such as picture identification and sensor management
column2: an Orca representative told New Scientist
column3: ""our hope is that this technology will make communication on the battlefield substantially simpler.""

column1: This technology will make information processing for command decisions on the battlefield more nimble
column2: while also reducing the hazards of data exchange with an undeployable processor outside the battlefield
column3: says the company.

column1: We can't help but think that Orca's agreement with the Ministry of Defense is an issue in search of a solution.
At this moment
column2: it's anyone's guess if quantum computers will allow tanks to become smarter and offer the UK military a large enough advantage on the battlefield.";2102;['icbnxoy'
