column1: 66;612;c21ef5cec094b63c1f442501cbce6fc262e8445ee93c4353c9626b48fda1bcf3;posted_link;r/science;https://newsroom.unsw.edu.au/news/science-tech/hot-qubits-made-sydney-break-one-biggest-constraints-practical-quantum-computers;['g227nl'];['______---------'];[1586989438.0];"['A new quantum processor unit cell works at temperatures 15 times greater than competing models. It still requires refrigeration
column2: but only a ""few thousand dollars\' worth
column3: rather than the millions of dollars"" currently needed.']";[nan];2020-04-16;"UNSW Media; Science";Hot qubits made in Sydney break one of the biggest constraints to practical quantum computers;"Most quantum computers being developed around the world will only work at fractions of a degree above absolute zero. That requires multi-million-dollar refrigeration and as soon as you plug them into conventional electronic circuits they’ll instantly overheat.

column1: But now researchers led by Professor Andrew Dzurak at UNSW Sydney have addressed this problem.
“Our new results open a path from experimental devices to affordable quantum computers for real world business and government applications
column2: ” says Professor Dzurak.

column1: Getting warmer
The researchers’ proof-of-concept quantum processor unit cell
column2: on a silicon chip
column3: works at 1.5 Kelvin – 15 times warmer than the main competing chip-based technology being developed by Google
column4: IBM
column5: and others
column6: which uses superconducting qubits.

column1: “This is still very cold
column2: but is a temperature that can be achieved using just a few thousand dollars’ worth of refrigeration
column3: rather than the millions of dollars needed to cool chips to 0.1 Kelvin
column4: ” explains Dzurak.

column1: “While difficult to appreciate using our everyday concepts of temperature
column2: this increase is extreme in the quantum world.”

column1: Quantum computers are expected to outperform conventional ones for a range of important problems
column2: from precision drug-making to search algorithms. Designing one that can be manufactured and operated in a real-world setting
column3: however
column4: represents a major technical challenge.

column1: The UNSW researchers believe that they have overcome one of the hardest obstacles standing in the way of quantum computers becoming a reality.
In a paper published in the journal Nature today
column2: Dzurak’s team
column3: together with collaborators in Canada
column4: Finland and Japan
column5: report a proof-of-concept quantum processor unit cell that
column6: unlike most designs being explored worldwide
column7: doesn’t need to operate at temperatures below one-tenth of one Kelvin.

column1: Dzurak’s team first announced their experimental results via the academic pre-print archive in February last year. Then
column2: in October 2019
column3: a group in the Netherlands led by a former post-doctoral researcher in Dzurak’s group
column4: Menno Veldhorst
column5: announced a similar result using the same silicon technology developed at UNSW in 2014. The confirmation of this ‘hot qubit’ behaviour by two groups on opposite sides of the world has led to the two papers being published ‘back-to-back’ in the same issue of Nature today.

column1: Qubit pairs are the fundamental units of quantum computing. Like its classical computing analogue – the bit – each qubit characterises two states
column2: a 0 or a 1
column3: to create a binary code. Unlike a bit
column4: however
column5: it can manifest both states simultaneously
column6: in what is known as a “superposition”.

column1: Cheaper and easier to integrate
The unit cell developed by Dzurak’s team comprises two qubits confined in a pair of quantum dots embedded in silicon. The result
column2: scaled up
column3: can be manufactured using existing silicon chip factories
column4: and would operate without the need for multi-million-dollar cooling. It would also be easier to integrate with conventional silicon chips
column5: which will be needed to control the quantum processor.

column1: A quantum computer that is able to perform the complex calculations needed to design new medicines
column2: for example
column3: will require millions of qubit pairs
column4: and is generally accepted to be at least a decade away. This need for millions of qubits presents a big challenge for designers.

column1: “Every qubit pair added to the system increases the total heat generated
column2: ” explains Dzurak
column3: “and added heat leads to errors. That’s primarily why current designs need to be kept so close to absolute zero.”

column1: The prospect of maintaining quantum computers with enough qubits to be useful at temperatures much colder than deep space is daunting
column2: expensive and pushes refrigeration technology to the limit.

column1: The UNSW team
column2: however
column3: have created an elegant solution to the problem
column4: by initialising and “reading” the qubit pairs using electrons tunnelling between the two quantum dots.

column1: The proof-of-principle experiments were performed by Dr Henry Yang from the UNSW team
column2: who Dzurak describes as a “brilliant experimentalist”.

column1: Team effort
Other authors on the paper include Ross Leon
column2: Jason Hwang (now at the University of Sydney)
column3: Andre Saraiva
column4: Tuomo Tanttu
column5: Wister Huang
column6: Kok-Wai Chan and Fay Hudson
column8: as well as long-time collaborators Dr Arne Laucht and Professor Andrea Morello from UNSW.

column1: Dr Kuan-Yen from Aalto University in Finland assisted the device fabrication team
column2: while Professor Kohei Itoh from Keio University in Japan provided enriched silicon-28 wafers from which the devices were made. The qubit devices incorporated nano-scale magnets to help enable qubit operation
column3: and these were designed with support from a team led by Professor Michel Pioro-Ladrière at Université de Sherbrooke in Canada
column4: including his PhD student Julien Camirand Lemyre.";4835;['fnjdeeb'
column5: 'fnjh1uj'
column6: 'fnjdtxm'

column1: 67;959;242c303d2ef7dccd3f1572bc5c8d89c1c1793e38a0330dbf421555089c5a06a9;posted_link;r/Futurology;"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/schroedingers-bacterium-could-be-a-quantum-biology-milestone/?amp;text=";['9y53lo'];['lughnasadh'];[1542538036.0];"['""Schrödinger\'s Bacterium"" Could Be a Quantum Biology Milestone - A recent experiment may have placed living organisms in a state of quantum entanglement']";[nan];2018-10-29;Jonathan O'Callaghan;“Schrödinger’s Bacterium” Could Be a Quantum Biology Milestone;"The quantum world is a weird one. In theory and to some extent in practice its tenets demand that a particle can appear to be in two places at once—a paradoxical phenomenon known as superposition—and that two particles can become “entangled
column2: ” sharing information across arbitrarily large distances through some still-unknown mechanism.

column1: Perhaps the most famous example of quantum weirdness is Schrödinger’s cat
column2: a thought experiment devised by Erwin Schrödinger in 1935. The Austrian physicist imagined how a cat placed in a box with a potentially lethal radioactive substance could
column3: per the odd laws of quantum mechanics
column4: exist in a superposition of being both dead and alive—at least until the box is opened and its contents observed.

column1: As far-out as that seems
column2: the concept has been experimentally validated countless times on quantum scales. Scaled up to our seemingly simpler and certainly more intuitive macroscopic world
column3: however
column4: things change. No one has ever witnessed a star
column5: a planet or a cat in superposition or a state of quantum entanglement. But ever since quantum theory’s initial formulation in the early 20th century
column6: scientists have wondered where exactly the microscopic and macroscopic worlds cross over. Just how big can the quantum realm be
column7: and could it ever be big enough for its weirdest aspects to intimately
column8: clearly influence living things? Across the past two decades the emergent field of quantum biology has sought answers for such questions
column9: proposing and performing experiments on living organisms that could probe the limits of quantum theory.

column1: Those experiments have already yielded tantalizing but inconclusive results. Earlier this year
column2: for example
column3: researchers showed the process of photosynthesis—whereby organisms make food using light—may involve some quantum effects. How birds navigate or how we smell also suggest quantum effects may take place in unusual ways within living things. But these only dip a toe into the quantum world. So far
column4: no one has ever managed to coax an entire living organism—not even a single-celled bacterium—into displaying quantum effects such as entanglement or superposition.

column1: So a new paper from a group at the University of Oxford is now raising some eyebrows for its claims of the successful entanglement of bacteria with photons—particles of light. Led by the quantum physicist Chiara Marletto and published in October in the Journal of Physics Communications
column2: the study is an analysis of an experiment conducted in 2016 by David Coles from the University of Sheffield and his colleagues. In that experiment Coles and company sequestered several hundred photosynthetic green sulfur bacteria between two mirrors
column3: progressively shrinking the gap between the mirrors down to a few hundred nanometers—less than the width of a human hair. By bouncing white light between the mirrors
column4: the researchers hoped to cause the photosynthetic molecules within the bacteria to couple—or interact—with the cavity
column5: essentially meaning the bacteria would continuously absorb
column6: emit and reabsorb the bouncing photons. The experiment was successful; up to six bacteria did appear to couple in this manner.

column1: Marletto and her colleagues argue the bacteria did more than just couple with the cavity
column2: though. In their analysis they demonstrate the energy signature produced in the experiment could be consistent with the bacteria’s photosynthetic systems becoming entangled with the light inside the cavity. In essence
column3: it appears certain photons were simultaneously hitting and missing photosynthetic molecules within the bacteria—a hallmark of entanglement. “Our models show that this phenomenon being recorded is a signature of entanglement between light and certain degrees of freedom inside the bacteria
column4: ” she says.

column1: According to study co-author Tristan Farrow
column2: also of Oxford
column3: this is the first time such an effect has been glimpsed in a living organism. “It certainly is key to demonstrating that we are some way toward the idea of a ‘Schrödinger’s bacterium
column4: ’ if you will
column5: ” he says. And it hints at another potential instance of naturally emerging quantum biology: Green sulfur bacteria reside in the deep ocean where the scarcity of life-giving light might even spur quantum-mechanical evolutionary adaptations to boost photosynthesis.

column1: There are many caveats to such controversial claims
column2: however. First and foremost
column3: the evidence for entanglement in this experiment is circumstantial
column4: dependent on how one chooses to interpret the light trickling through and out of the cavity-confined bacteria. Marletto and her colleagues acknowledge a classical model free of quantum effects could also account for the experiment’s results. But
column5: of course
column6: photons are not classical at all—they are quantum. And yet a more realistic “semiclassical” model using Newton’s laws for the bacteria and quantum ones for photons fails to reproduce the actual outcome Coles and his colleagues observed in their laboratory. This hints that quantum effects were at play in both the light and the bacteria. “It’s a little bit indirect
column7: but I think it’s because they’re only trying to be so rigorous in ruling out things and claiming anything too much
column9: a quantum computing researcher at IBM Zurich Research Laboratory who was not involved in either paper.

column1: The other caveat: the energies of the bacteria and the photon were measured collectively
column2: not independently. This
column3: according to Simon Gröblacher of Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands who was not part of this research
column4: is somewhat of a limitation. “There seems to be something quantum going on
column5: ” he says. “But…usually if we demonstrate entanglement
column6: you have to measure the two systems independently” to confirm any quantum correlation between them is genuine.

column1: Despite these uncertainties
column2: for many experts
column3: quantum biology’s transition from theoretical dream to tangible reality is a question of when
column4: not if. In isolation and collectively
column5: molecules outside of biological systems have already exhibited quantum effects in decades’ worth of laboratory experiments
column6: so seeking out these effects for similar molecules inside a bacterium or even our own bodies would seem sensible enough. In humans and other large multicellular organisms
column8: such molecular quantum effects should be averaged out to insignificance—but their meaningful manifestation within far smaller bacteria would not be too shocking. “I’m a little torn about how surprising [this finding] is
column9: ” Gröblacher says. “But it’s obviously exciting if you can show this in a real biological system.”

column1: Several research groups
column2: including those led by Gröblacher and Farrow
column3: are hoping to take these ideas even further. Gröblacher has designed an experiment that could place a tiny aquatic animal called a tardigrade in superposition—a proposition much more difficult than entangling bacteria with light owing to a tardigrade’s hundreds-fold–larger size. Farrow is looking at ways to improve on the bacterial experiment; in 2019 he and his colleagues hope to entangle two bacteria together
column4: rather than independently with light. “The long-term goals are foundational and fundamental
column5: ” Farrow says. “This is about understanding the nature of reality
column6: and whether quantum effects have a utility in biological functions. At the root of things
column9: with the big question being whether quantum effects play a role in how living things work.

column1: It might be
column2: for example
column3: that “natural selection has come up with ways for living systems to naturally exploit quantum phenomena
column4: ” Marletto notes
column5: such as the aforementioned example of bacteria photosynthesizing in the light-starved deep sea. But getting to the bottom of this requires starting small. The research has steadily been climbing toward macrolevel experiments
column6: with one recent experiment successfully entangling millions of atoms. Proving the molecules that make up living things exhibit meaningful quantum effects—even if for trivial purposes—would be a key next step. By exploring this quantum–classical boundary
column7: scientists could get closer to understanding what it would mean to be macroscopically quantum
column8: if such an idea is true.";8196;['e9zhmk2'

column1: 68;590;09c00dfab63ed58c4b3fb2027d11b33257a221cfe256ab78f73108b60375f009;posted_link;r/science;https://news.ku.dk/all_news/2021/06/new-invention-keeps-qubits-of-light-stable-at-room-temperature/;['o3ro5d'];['MistWeaver80'];[1624142498.0];['Researchers developed a new technique that keeps quantum bits of light stable at room temperature instead of only working at -270 degrees. In addition
column2: they store these qubits at room temperature for a hundred times longer than ever shown before. This is a breakthrough in quantum research.'];[nan];2022-08-25;Media team;New invention keeps qubits of light stable at room temperature;"New invention keeps qubits of light stable at room temperature

column1: Researchers from University of Copenhagen have developed a new technique that keeps quantum bits of light stable at room temperature instead of only working at -270 degrees. Their discovery saves power and money and is a breakthrough in quantum research.
As almost all our private information is digitalized
column2: it is increasingly important that we find ways to protect our data and ourselves from being hacked. Quantum Cryptography is the researchers’ answer to this problem
column3: and more specifically a certain kind of qubit – consisting of single photons: particles of light.

column1: Single photons or qubits of light
column2: as they are also called
column3: are extremely difficult to hack. However
column4: in order for these qubits of light to be stable and work properly they need to be stored at temperatures close to absolute zero – that is minus 270 C – something that requires huge amounts of power and resources.

column1: Yet in a recently published study
column2: researchers from University of Copenhagen
column3: demonstrate a new way to store these qubits at room temperature for a hundred times longer than ever shown before.

column1: “We have developed a special coating for our memory chips that helps the quantum bits of light to be identical and stable while being in room temperature. In addition
column2: our new method enables us to store the qubits for a much longer time
column3: which is milliseconds instead of microseconds – something that has not been possible before. We are really excited about it
column4: ” says Eugene Simon Polzik
column5: professor in quantum optics at the Niels Bohr Institute.

column1: This is why single photons are hard to hack:
- When we write emails or communicate with our bank
column2: each letter is converted into optical codes of photons. A message containing many photons makes it possible for a hacker to tap into your message and steal a part of those photons and information.

column1: - That is why researchers are working on being able to write emails using single photons (qubits of light)
column2: which are much harder to steal
column3: because they cannot be divided in smaller parts. Therefore
column4: it is easy to detect if someone is stealing your message.

column1: The special coating of the memory chips makes it much easier to store the qubits of light without big freezers
column2: which are troublesome to operate and require a lot of power. Therefore
column3: the new invention will be cheaper and more compatible with the demands of the industry in the future.

column1: “The advantage of storing these qubits at room temperature is that it does not require liquid helium or complex laser-systems for cooling. Also it is a much more simple technology that can be implemented more easily in a future quantum internet
column2: ” says Karsten Dideriksen
column3: a UCPH-PhD on the project.

column1: A special coating keeps the qubits stable
Normally warm temperatures disturb the energy of each quantum bit of light.
“In our memory chips
column2: thousands of atoms are flying around emitting photons also known as qubits of light. When the atoms are exposed to heat
column3: they start moving faster and collide with one another and with the walls of the chip. This leads them to emit photons that are very different from each other. But we need them to be exactly the same in order to use them for safe communication in the future
column4: ” explains Eugene Polzik and adds:

column1: “That is why we have developed a method that protects the atomic memory with the special coating for the inside of the memory chips. The coating consists of paraffin that has a wax like structure and it works by softening the collision of the atoms
column2: making the emitted photons or qubits identical and stable. Also we used special filters to make sure that only identical photons were extracted from the memory chips”.

column1: Even though the new discovery is a breakthrough in quantum research
column2: it stills needs more work.

column1: “Right now we produce the qubits of light at a low rate – one photon per second
column2: while cooled systems can produce millions in the same amount of time. But we believe there are important advantages to this new technology and that we can overcome this challenge in time
column3: ” Eugene concludes.

column1: Different kinds of quantum bits:

- There are different types of quantum bits that are used for different purposes. Qubits of light consist of photons (particles of light) which are constantly flying around at a high speed. This type of qubit is ideal for quantum communication
column2: because it can travel far without being disturbed.

column1: - In contrast
column2: stationary qubits (they are bound to a specific place) such as superconducting qubits and ionic qubits are well suited for quantum computing.";4568;['h2dbuwh'
column3: 'h2de6uc'
column4: 'h2edrng'
column5: 'h2deyj0'
column6: 'h2dfcqw'

column1: 69;292;7bc6583ee6d886ef9791bce115655421aacee2e4ec545f0e1919235c636699b8;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://futurism.com/researchers-achieve-first-sustained-long-distance-quantum-teleportation;['kgubyc'];['Sumit316'];[1608472353.0];['Researchers Achieve First “Sustained” Long Distance Quantum Teleportation'];[nan];2020-12-18;Victor Tangermann;"Researchers achieve first ""sustained"" long distance quantum teleportation";"A team of researchers claim to have achieved sustained
column2: long-distance quantum teleportation for the first time.

column1: The research could lay the groundwork for ""a viable quantum internet — a network in which information stored in qubits is shared over long distances through entanglement"" that could ""transform the fields of data storage
column2: precision sensing and computing
column3: according to a Fermilab statement.

column1: The team — a collaboration between the U.S. Department of Energy's Fermilab
column2: the University of Calgary
column3: and other partners —managed to teleport qubits of photons over 44 kilometers of fiber.

column1: The process doesn't actually involve teleportation in the traditional sense. Quantum teleportation is the transfer of quantum states from one location to another. Through quantum entanglement
column2: two particles in separate locations are connected by an invisible force
column3: famously referred to as ""spooky action at a distance"" by Albert Einstein.

column1: Regardless of the distance
column2: the encoded information shared by the ""entangled"" pair of particles can be passed between them.

column1: By sharing these quantum qubits
column2: the basic units of quantum computing
column3: researchers are hoping to create networks of quantum computers that can share information at blazing-fast speeds.

column1: This is an advancement towards a more readily available scaling up of such systems in different locations
column2: to build a bigger system
column3: Christoph Simon
column4: professor of physics at the University of Calgary and co-author of the accompanying study published in the Physical Review journal earlier this month
column5: said in the university's statement about the research.

column1: But keeping this information flow stable over long distances has proven extremely difficult. The previous world record was held by researchers at the University of Calgary
column2: covering a distance of just six kilometers
column3: as VICE reports.

column1: Researchers are now hoping to scale up such a system
column2: using both entanglement to send information and quantum memory to store it as well.

column1: In July
column2: the US Department of Energy unveiled a blueprint for the first quantum internet
column3: connecting several of its National Laboratories across the country.";2129;['gghoik4'
column4: 'gghnrgx'
column5: 'gghqq9v'
column6: 'gghmyfv'

column1: 70;2;d752eba1fa418dcb19b61b11069aa6250c40d25edf05b99989d793a3f5851db7;posted_link;r/technology;https://arstechnica.co.uk/gadgets/2017/03/ibm-q-50-qubit-quantum-computer/?comments=1;['5xt3u5'];['ibmzrl'];[1488805625.0];['IBM will sell 50-qubit universal quantum computer “in the next few years”'];[nan];2017-03-06;Sebastian Anthony;IBM will sell 50-qubit universal quantum computer “in the next few years”;"IBM will build and sell commercial 50-qubit universal quantum computers
column2: dubbed IBM Q
column3: ""in the next few years."" No word on pricing just yet
column4: but I wouldn't expect much change from $15 million—the cost of a non-universal D-Wave quantum computer.

column1: In other news
column2: IBM has also opened up an API (sample code available on Github) that gives developers easier access to the five-qubit quantum computer currently connected to the IBM cloud. Later in the year IBM will release a full SDK
column3: further simplifying the process of building quantum software.

column1: You can't actually do much useful computation with five qubits
column2: mind you
column3: but fortunately IBM also has news there: the company's quantum simulator can now simulate up to 20 qubits. The idea is that developers should start thinking about potential 20-qubit quantum scenarios now
column4: so they're ready to be deployed when IBM builds the actual hardware.

column1: Speaking of hardware
column2: it seems IBM has accelerated its universal quantum computing roadmap somewhat. In May last year IBM said it would like to build a 50-qubit computer ""in the next decade."" Now we're down to ""the next few years.""

column1: IBM has also fleshed out its quantum computing roadmap a little
column2: providing some guidance on how it will actually build a universal 50-qubit computer:

column1: IBM’s roadmap to scale to practical quantum computers is based on a holistic approach to advancing all parts of the system. IBM will leverage its deep expertise in superconducting qubits
column2: complex high performance system integration
column3: and scalable nanofabrication processes from the semiconductor industry to help advance the quantum mechanical capabilities.

column1: Despite the aggressive roadmap
column2: however
column3: there is no evidence that any scaling has
column4: in fact
column5: occurred. Recal the original publication
column6: which involved nine computational qubits
column7: and a total of 1000 qubits. Now IBM wants their quantum computer to be fully interconnected
column9: 225 connections. Each link seems to require 48 qubits for control
column11: 800 qubits. This is quite a jump for 1000 qubits on a board.

column1: Comparing to D-Wave
column2: which also produces boards with around 1000 qubits
column3: they always end up with one or two non-functional qubits. In this case
column4: it is most likely that a non-functional qubit will be in the connection between two computational qubits
column5: rendering not one
column6: but two nodes useless.

column1: We'll be a lot more confident in IBM's scaling when we see actual papers with increasing numbers of computational qubits.
Other than D-Wave
column2: IBM doesn't have much competition in the quantum computing space—and as we've explained in the past
column3: both companies appear to be approaching quantum computing quite differently. IBM has set its sights on building a true universal quantum computer
column4: which can be used to solve any quantum algorithm under the sun. D-Wave seems more focused on scaling up the number of qubits and ensuring its system can integrate easily with classical computers
column5: but not ensuring its qubits are actually qubits.

column1: While exact pricing
column2: availability
column3: and specs are still a long way off
column4: it's fairly safe to assume that IBM's quantum computers will be about the same price as a D-Wave (~$15 million) or perhaps a little dearer. Both systems are fundamentally the same thing: a fancy chip inside a box that contains a multi-stage dilution refrigerator from a company like BlueFors.

column1: Dilution refrigerators take about 24 hours to cool down
column2: but they can then keep the chip at close-to-absolute-zero (~5mK
column3: -273.145°C)—a prerequisite for current quantum computing chips—almost indefinitely.

column1: And finally
column2: a random factoid: the photo on the right shows me standing on a ladder next to one of IBM's dilution refrigerators at IBM Research headquarters in upstate New York back in 2013.";3758;['dekoqy3'

column1: 71;485;4a3596cd115a7baec320f82180c6385ad1e99fb79d1f7766c16fd2d4192bc170;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/technology/nsa-doesnt-think-quantum-computers-can-break-public-key-encryption/ar-AAO4Egk;['pi7q5u'];['buddyfake'];[1630822307.0];"[""NSA doesn't think Quantum Computers can Break Cryptocurrency (Public Key Encryption)""]";[nan];2021-09-03;Mayank Sharma;NSA doesn't think quantum computers can break public key encryption;"The US National Security Agency (NSA) isn’t really sure when or even if quantum computers will be able to crack public key cryptography.
Post-Quantum Cryptography (opens in new tab) is an emerging field of research
column2: with researchers devising mechanisms to shore up current encryption algorithms against the seemingly unlimited computing performance promised by quantum computers.

column1: The NSA however has expressed its reservations about the potential of quantum computing in a FAQ titled Quantum Computing and Post-Quantum Cryptography.
“NSA does not know when or even if a quantum computer of sufficient size and power to exploit public key cryptography (a CRQC) will exist
column2: ” said the security agency in response to whether it is worried about the potential of adversarial use of quantum computing.

column1: Public-key encryption drives most of the standards and protocols on the internet and the cloud
column2: which help ensure the integrity of the data even when it’s been hijacked by snoopers.

column1: In the FAQ
column2: the NSA describes a Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computer (CRQC) as a quantum computer that’s capable of actually attacking real world cryptographic systems
column3: something that’s currently infeasible.

column1: While it agrees that such a computer would be “devastating” to the digital security infrastructure
column2: it seems to suggest that it doesn’t believe such a CRQC would ever materialize.

column1: However
column2: the growing research in quantum computing has moved the agency to also support the development of post-quantum cryptographic standards
column3: along with plans for eventual transition to such standards.

column1: However
column2: speaking to industry experts
column3: The Register concludes that research on cryptography standards aren’t much of a concern to cybersecurity (opens in new tab) specialists.

column1: “In a world where users will divulge their passwords (opens in new tab) in return for chocolate or in response to an enticing phishing email (opens in new tab)
column2: the risk of quantum computers might not be our biggest threat
column3: ” Martin Lee
column4: a technical lead at Cisco's Talos security division told The Register.

72;377;77ec19395c3d2e413ba3d746532ba5c85c25ca2a9f12a19c7e2bbef47f0bb09d;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.independent.co.uk/tech/quantum-internet-breakthrough-latest-physics-computer-b2087236.html;['uxqj42'];['ParkerWHughes'];[1653511114.0];[""Scientists Take Huge Steps Towards Revolutionary 'Quantum Internet'""]";[nan];2022-05-25;Andrew Griffin;Scientists take huge step towards revolutionary ‘quantum internet’;"Scientists have taken a major step towards the creation of a quantum internet.

The technology would allow information to be “transported” in an instant. It would help bring about a promised quantum computing revolution as well as bringing radical change in how networks function.
But
column2: to get there
column3: scientists must first figure out the basic technology so that it can be used in more complex networks.

column1: Now scientists say they have done some of that fundamental work
column2: in a new study that reports a success in teleporting quantum information between two nodes of a network that are not connected to each other.

column1: In the study
column2: scientists created a three-node quantum network
column3: giving each of those nodes a name: Alice
column4: Bob and Charlie. In the network
column5: Alice was connected to Bob
column6: and Bob was connected to Charlie – but Charlie was not connected to Bob.

column1: Scientists say they have successfully shared information between Alice and Bob
column2: despite the fact they are not connected.

column1: So far
column2: researchers have only been able to demonstrate connections between neighbouring nodes
column3: and the new study represents the first success of this kind.

column1: Now scientists hope it represents a first step towards building a larger quantum network built on the sharing of quantum information.
That future is still “some way off”
column2: researchers away from the new study say. But the paper offers a “potential path forward” to building real world applications of the technology.

column1: “This achievement is not only a win for fundamental science
column2: but also represents an advance in the real-world problem solving required to move this fascinating quantum application to the next step
column3: ” write Oliver Slattery and Yong-Su Kim in an accompanying article.

column1: Actually building such systems will require more robust systems
column2: as well as new interfaces that should improve the efficiency of the system.

column1: That will be crucial to bring the breakthroughs in the work to more complex quantum systems
column2: the authors say.

column1: The success is reported in a new study
column2: ‘Qubit teleportation between non-neighbouring nodes in a quantum network’
column3: published in Nature.";2091;['i9zhwl7'

column1: 73;479;9738f872ed91cf0c477816858b210ee18477185564a813034c25685b2dd51d7a;posted_link;r/science;http://www.nature.com/news/photons-detected-without-damage-1.14179;['1qoox6'];['twembly'];[1384515007.0];['One of the cornerstones of quantum theory is the principle that you cannot measure any property of an object without affecting the object itself. Physicists
column2: however
column3: have now devised a way to detect single photons of visible light without changing any of the information that they carry.'];[nan];2013-11-14;Elizabeth Gibney ;Photons detected without being destroyed;"Technique holds promise for quantum networks.

column1: One of the cornerstones of quantum theory is the principle that you cannot measure any property of an object without affecting the object itself. Indeed
column2: detecting the very existence of a photon until now has usually meant destroying it. Physicists
column3: however
column4: have now devised a way to detect single photons of visible light without bringing about their demise. Others had done the same with microwave photons
column5: but this is the first time that it has been done in the part of the spectrum that could matter for a future 'quantum Internet'.

column1: The conventional way to detect a single particle of light is to catch it with a sensor
column2: absorbing its energy but destroying the particle in the process.

column1: In recent years
column2: physicists have developed methods to extract part of the information from a particle’s quantum state — for example showing that it is more likely to be in one place than in another — in a set of methods known as weak measurement. But in doing so
column3: they reduce the amount of information carried by the quantum state itself.

column1: The new technique instead definitively detects whether the photon is there at all
column2: while potentially leaving further quantum information intact
column3: says Stephan Ritter
column4: a physicist at the Max Planck Institute for Quantum Optics in Garching
column5: Germany
column6: and a co-author of the study. The researchers observe a trace of the photon — the 'envelope' containing the information — and pass it on without reading what is inside

column1: This could be useful in applications such as quantum networks
column2: which promise to transport data with unbreakable encryption
column3: but require delicate quantum states to be transmitted without any disturbance. Quantum networks encode information in quantum bits
column4: or qubits
column5: which can occupy multiple states simultaneously as if they were living separate histories in parallel universes at the same time. Thus
column6: unlike the information-carrying bits in conventional computers
column7: qubits can be in a superposition of both '0' and '1' at the same time. But any disturbance will force the qubit to pick one of the two states

column1: Optical trickery
In their experiments
column2: described today in Science1
column3: Ritter and his colleagues set up an optical cavity consisting of two mirrors facing each other just half a millimetre apart
column4: which can confine between them photons of specific 'resonant' energies. Inside
column5: the team trapped a single atom in a superposition of two states
column6: one of which was resonant with the cavity. An atom in this resonant state prevents photons of the same energy from entering the cavity.

column1: When the team fired a photon at the cavity
column2: the atom’s dual personality caused two things to happen at once. In one of the 'parallel universes' of its superposition
column3: the one in which the atom was resonant with the cavity
column4: the photon did not enter: it just bounced back from the outside of one of the mirrors. In the other parallel universe
column5: the photon entered the cavity
column6: bounced between the two mirrors
column7: and then exited again the same way it came in. The overall quantum state of the photon was not affected
column8: but the state of the atom was: The phase between the coupled and the uncoupled state was shifted by 180 degrees. By reading this shift
column9: the researchers could detect the passage of the photon

column1: Serge Haroche
column2: a physicist at the Collège de France in Paris
column3: pioneered a similar technique2 in the 1990s as part of research for which he went on to win a Nobel prize in 2012. However
column4: he and his collaborators were able to achieve the feat only with photons in the microwave range
column5: which are not suitable for quantum communications.

column1: Philippe Grangier
column2: a physicist at the Institute of Optics in Palaiseau
column3: France
column4: says that Ritter's technique might form part of a toolbox needed to create a quantum repeater
column5: a key component of a future quantum Internet.

column1: However
column2: Gilles Nogues
column3: a physicist at the Néel Institute in Grenoble
column4: France
column5: who worked with Haroche on the microwave-photon experiments
column6: says that this stage is some way off. For any quantum applications to work
column7: the device needs to operate with photons in superpositions of states
column8: something that Ritter's team has yet to demonstrate. ""Non-destructive measurements are boring as long as you just measure 0 or 1. But they become fascinating as soon as you use them on a quantum superposition of those two values

column1: 74;334;7c0c1e52d386d5cdbd519547f499f1645a08e82a90a5e41cdd4f01ab8c1561b3;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.newscientist.com/article/2151032-googles-quantum-computing-plans-threatened-by-ibm-curveball/;['77rj8k'];['mvea'];[1508561821.0];['Google’s quantum computing plans threatened by IBM curveball - “IBM has come up with a way to simulate quantum computers that have 56 quantum bits
column2: or qubits
column3: on a non-quantum supercomputer – a task previously thought to be impossible.”'];[nan];2017-10-20;Mark Kim;Google's quantum computing plans threatened by IBM curveball;"Just when it was looking like the underdog
column4: classical computing is striking back. IBM has come up with a way to simulate quantum computers that have 56 quantum bits
column5: or qubits
column6: on a non-quantum supercomputer – a task previously thought to be impossible. The feat moves the goalposts in the fight for quantum supremacy
column7: the effort to outstrip classical computers using quantum ones.

column1: It used to be widely accepted that a classical computer cannot simulate more than 49 qubits because of memory limitations. The memory required for simulations increases exponentially with each additional qubit.
The closest anyone had come to putting the 49-qubit limit to a test was a 45-qubit simulation at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich
column2: which needed 500 terabytes of memory. IBM’s new simulation upends the assumption by simulating 56 qubits with only 4.5 terabytes.

column1: The simulation is based on a mathematical trick that allows a more compact numerical representation of different arrangements of qubits
column2: known as quantum states.

column1: A quantum computing operation is typically represented by a table of numbers indicating what should be done to each qubit to produce a new quantum state. Instead
column2: researchers at IBM’s T. J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights
column3: New York
column4: used tensors – effectively multidimensional tables augmented with axes beyond rows and columns.

column1: Thanks to the additional axes
column2: much more information can be squashed into a few tensors
column3: so long as we know how to write it down in the language of tensors. The researchers found a way to do just that for quantum computing operations.

column1: Embarrassingly parallel
While writing down the operations in tensor form
column2: they also found out a way to divide the simulation task into what they call “embarrassingly parallel” chunks
column3: which allowed them to use the many processors of a supercomputer simultaneously. This won them the final bit of efficiency needed to simulate a 56-qubit quantum computer.

column1: “IBM pushed the envelope
column2: ” says Itay Hen at the University of Southern California. “It’s going to be much harder for quantum-device people to exhibit [quantum] supremacy.”

column1: IBM now has a functional 56-qubit quantum computer living in their supercomputer. But while that’s an improvement on the previous record
column2: Andrew Childs at the University of Maryland says it’s not a huge leap forward. “I don’t think they’re claiming that this is going to give them an efficient simulation of quantum systems on a classical computer
column3: ” he says.

column1: Even so
column2: they’ve upped the ante in the race to outperform classical computers with quantum systems. Google previously said they were on track to build a working 49-qubit processor by the end of 2017
column3: but that will no longer win them the achievement of quantum supremacy.

column1: Bob Wisnieff
column2: the principal investigator of the IBM study
column3: says their current simulation runs about “a billion times slower” than the theoretical estimates for an actual 56-qubit quantum computer.

column1: Wisnieff’s team plans to experiment with supercomputers whose processors can communicate efficiently with one another. They expect to be able to squeeze out a few more qubits from these communication channels
column2: which help speed up the parallel computation needed for the simulation.

column1: IBM’s goal is to build a quantum computer that can “explore practical problems” such as quantum chemistry
column2: says Wisnieff. He hopes to check the accuracy of quantum computers against his simulations before putting real quantum computers to the test.

column1: “I want to be able to write algorithms that I know the answers for before I run them on a real quantum computer
column2: ” he says.";3617;['doo7vcy'

column1: 75;1249;2e61a3b5db1353cdfe631e5d3503b0d15195aded0b1317486e81220121a3b43c;posted_link;r/science;http://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2011/01/quantum-birds/;['facw0'];['nomdeweb'];[1296170599.0];['Birds can maintain quantum entanglement in their eyes a full 20 microseconds longer than the best laboratory systems'];[nan];2011-01-27;"Condé Nast; Lisa Grossman";In the Blink of Bird's Eye
column2: a Model for Quantum Navigation;"European robins may maintain quantum entanglement in their eyes a full 20 microseconds longer than the best laboratory systems
column3: say physicists investigating how birds may use quantum effects to “see” Earth’s magnetic field.

column1: Quantum entanglement is a state where electrons are spatially separated
column2: but able to affect one another. It's been proposed that birds' eyes contain entanglement-based compasses.

column1: Conclusive proof doesn't yet exist
column2: but multiple lines of evidence suggest it. Findings like this one underscore just how sophisticated those compasses may be.

column1: How can a living system have evolved to protect a quantum state as well -- no
column2: better -- than we can do in the lab with these exotic molecules?"" asked quantum physicist Simon Benjamin of Oxford University and the National University of Singapore
column3: a co-author of the new study. ""That really is an amazing thing.""

column1: Many animals -- including not only birds
column2: but some mammals
column3: fish
column4: reptiles
column5: even crustaceans and insects -- navigate by sensing the direction of Earth's magnetic field. Physicist Klaus Schulten of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign proposed in the late 1970s that bird navigation relied on some geomagnetically sensitive
column6: as-yet-unknown biochemical reaction taking place in their eyes.

column1: Research since then has revealed the existence of special optical cells containing a protein called cryptochrome. When a photon enters the eye
column2: it hits cryptochrome
column3: giving a boost of energy to electrons that exist in a state of quantum entanglement.

column1: One of the electrons migrates a few nanometers away
column2: where it feels a slightly different magnetic field than its partner. Depending on how the magnetic field alters the electron's spin
column3: different chemical reactions are produced. In theory
column4: the products of many such reactions across a bird's eye could create a picture of Earth's magnetic field as a varying pattern of light and dark.

column1: >'N@C60 is quite a sexy
column2: interesting
column3: promising molecule.'

column1: However
column2: these quantum states are notoriously fragile. Even in laboratory systems
column3: atoms are cooled to near–absolute-zero temperatures to maintain entanglement for more than a few thousandths of a second. Biological systems would seem too warm and too wet to hold quantum states for long
column4: yet that's exactly what they appear to do.

column1: Researchers led by University of California
column2: Irvine physicist Thorsten Ritz (.pdf) showed in 2004 that
column3: although robins had no trouble pointing their beaks toward Africa under the influence of Earth's magnetic field alone
column4: adding a second
column5: shifting field destroyed their inner compasses. That second field was so weak -- less than one-third of 1 percent of Earth's field -- that it could only have influenced a quantum-sensitive system.

column1: It shouldn’t be the case that the birds would even know that this had happened
column2: Benjamin said. ""If someone changed the brightness of the scene that you’re seeing by a-third of 1 percent
column3: you would struggle to know that it even happened. It certainly wouldn’t muck up your vision.

column1: In a new paper in Physical Review Letters
column2: Benjamin and colleagues built a mathematical model of Ritz's experiment
column3: including the Earth's magnetic field
column4: the slight secondary field
column5: and the quantum systems that might make up the birds' magnetic sense.";3271;['c1eh028'
column6: 'c1eh4p3'

column1: 76;963;f46c396edc7a3ded7d1932c53ab7497da08b2389dfa4186760135a0031b051a2;posted_link;r/science;https://www.sciencenews.org/article/alien-quantum-communication-extraterrestrial-communication-signal;['vspj24'];['MistWeaver80'];[1657112542.0];['Aliens could send quantum messages to Earth
column2: calculations suggest. Particles of light
column3: or photons
column4: could be transmitted over vast
column5: interstellar distances without losing their quantum nature.That means scientists searching for extraterrestrial signals could also look for quantum messages.'];[nan];2022-07-05;"Science News Magazine; Emily Conover";Aliens could send quantum messages to Earth
column6: calculations suggest;"An intelligent alien civilization could beam quantum messages to Earth.

column1: Particles of light
column2: or photons
column3: could be transmitted over vast
column4: interstellar distances without losing their quantum nature
column5: researchers report June 28 in Physical Review D. That means scientists searching for extraterrestrial signals could also look for quantum messages (SN: 1/28/19).

column1: Scientists are currently developing Earth-based quantum communication
column2: a technology that uses quantum particles to send information and has the potential to be more secure than standard
column3: or classical
column4: communication (SN: 6/15/17). Intelligent extraterrestrials
column5: if they’re out there
column6: may have also adopted quantum communication

column1: A major obstacle to quantum communication is decoherence
column2: in which a quantum particle loses its quantumness as it interacts with its surroundings. “Quantum states you generally think of as very delicate
column3: and if there’s any kind of external interaction
column4: you kind of destroy that state
column5: ” Berera says.

column1: Since the average density of matter in space is much less than on Earth
column2: particles could be expected to travel farther before succumbing to decoherence. So Berera and theoretical physicist Jaime Calderón Figueroa
column3: both of the University of Edinburgh
column4: calculated how far light — in particular
column5: X-rays — could travel unscathed through interstellar space.

column1: X-ray photons could more than traverse the Milky Way
column2: potentially traveling hundreds of thousands of light-years or even more
column3: the researchers found.

column1: Based on the findings
column2: Berera and Calderón Figueroa considered strategies to search for E.T.’s quantum dispatches. One potential type of communication to search for is quantum teleportation
column3: in which the properties of a distant particle can be transferred to another (SN: 7/7/17). Since the technology requires both quantum and classical signals
column4: scientists could look for such simultaneous signals to identify any alien quantum missives.";1967;['if2icoq'
column5: 'if2t1n3'
column6: 'if3hnrv'

column1: 77;219;df5416072c5502fcd179e7bbd9d59634a2c264451b25fe13950f576dac0663db;posted_link;r/technews;https://www.engadget.com/amazon-web-services-quantum-networking-center-162244465.html;['vhi49g'];['sankscan'];[1655831137.0];['Amazon is opening a center for quantum networking research'];[nan];2022-06-21;Kris Holt;Amazon is opening a center for quantum networking research | Engadget;"Several major companies are working on projects
column2: including and . Amazon is also in the mix. The company the AWS Center for Quantum Computing last year and has via Amazon Web Services since 2019. It's expanding that work to what it says is an essential aspect of helping quantum tech reach its full potential: quantum networking. As such
column3: the company has the AWS Center for Quantum Networking (CQN).

column1: As with quantum computing
column2: it's early days for quantum networking. It will likely before researchers start getting the most out of quantum tech. However
column3: Amazon has more resources than most to invest in the field.

column1: Amazon notes that quantum networks will be able to connect quantum devices using single photons rather than laser beams (which are utilized in modern optical communications). However
column2: along with enabling certain capabilities of quantum networks
column3: there are some hurdles to overcome when it comes to using a single photon. Quantum mechanics limits the amplification of a single photon
column4: which restricts the range of a network. ""Also
column5: the weakness of single photons complicates interfacing them with today’s quantum computing devices
column6: CQN research scientists Denis Sukachev and Mihir Bhaskar wrote in a blog post.

column1: Researchers at the center will work on new technologies
column2: such as quantum repeaters and transducers
column3: to allow for the creation of global quantum networks. They'll develop hardware
column4: software and apps for quantum networks.

column1: Among the potential applications of quantum networking is ""enabling global communications protected by quantum key distribution with privacy and security levels not achievable using conventional encryption techniques
column2: Sukachev and Bhaskar wrote. ""Quantum networks will also provide powerful and secure cloud quantum servers by connecting together and amplifying the capabilities of individual quantum processors.""";1858;['id7i69d'
column3: 'id7iewr'
column4: 'id8xia8'
column5: 'id7hu11'
column6: 'id7gk6i'

column1: 78;296;3a6b62ee4038bc1caf0f1c89fbe182f03c80a3eebf93bac19a30cc56911cf07c;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://futurism.com/quantum-research-reality-subjective;['dwz9ks'];['izumi3682'];[1573862750.0];['Bizarre new quantum research: Reality itself may be subjective'];[nan];2019-11-15;Victor Tangermann;Bizarre new quantum research: Reality itself may be subjective;"Researchers are making a counter-intuitive claim: reality itself may be subjective
column2: thanks to quantum weirdness on a microscopic scale.

column1: In a new paper in the journal Science Advances
column2: an international team of quantum physicists argue that thanks to the unusual rules of quantum mechanics
column3: facts themselves could depend on who's looking at them. In other words
column4: reality could be twisted by observation.

column1: On a quantum level
column2: it's long been understood that particles can be in several states at once. That changes once those particles are observed
column3: breaking the so-called ""superposition"" — a mind-bending principle most famously described by the ""Schrödinger's cat"" thought experiment.

column1: Say you tossed a coin in a closed room and your friend is outside that room trying to figure out the outcome of your coin toss. Once you've tossed the coin
column2: you know for a fact what the result is. Your friend
column3: however
column4: cannot tell the outcome from the outside: to them
column5: the two states
column6: ""heads"" or ""tails

column1: Quantum physicists describe this difference in established facts as a contradiction — your friend observes a superimposed state
column2: while you observe a definite answer.

column1: In an experimental test at the Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh
column2: the researchers built a small-scale quantum computer. Their aim was to scientifically prove that measurements in quantum mechanics are actually subjective to a particular observer.

column1: They measured the polarization of three pairs of photons. One pair acted as two coins
column2: meaning each one can be either heads or tails depending on its polarization. Then they used the two remaining pairs to measure the first pair's polarization in each of the two boxes — acting
column3: essentially
column4: as ""observers."" Two separate photons outside of each box act as a control.

column1: After weeks of calculations
column2: the researchers found something strange: the polarization states didn't match up. The inside and outside photon observers couldn't agree on the outcome or polarization state of each photon inside the box.

column1: Eventually
column2: we succeeded in showing that quantum mechanics might indeed be incompatible with the assumption of objective facts — we violated the inequality!"" lead researchers Alessandro Fedrizzi and Massimiliano Proietti
column3: quantum physicists at Heriot-Watt University
column4: wrote in a recent piece for The Conversation.

column1: The insight we gained is that quantum observers may indeed be entitled to their own facts
column2: wrote Fedrizzi in a September statement. That brings up the question: do the rules of quantum mechanics apply to much larger objects? Or are the rules different for single atoms or photons?

column1: It's a fascinating experiment that seemingly brings up more questions than it's able to answer.
Clearly these are all deeply philosophical questions about the fundamental nature of reality
column2: wrote Fedrizzi and Proietti in The Conversation. ""Whatever the answer

column1: 79;977;986a55784c03dcdb71c5897432551c692e182caa7e21577e732794bbe0f05cff;posted_link;r/technews;https://scitechdaily.com/new-quantum-technology-to-make-charging-electric-cars-as-fast-as-pumping-gas/;['tki5ld'];['sankscan'];[1647997410.0];['New Quantum Technology To Make Charging Electric Cars As Fast as Pumping Gas'];[nan];2022-03-21;Mike O'Neill;New Quantum Technology To Make Charging Electric Cars As Fast as Pumping Gas;"Quantum charging will cut the charging time of electric vehicles from ten hours to three minutes.
Whether it’s photovoltaics or fusion
column2: sooner or later
column3: human civilization must turn to renewable energies. This is deemed inevitable considering the ever-growing energy demands of humanity and the finite nature of fossil fuels. As such
column4: much research has been pursued in order to develop alternative sources of energy
column5: most of which utilize electricity as the main energy carrier. The extensive R&D in renewables has been accompanied by gradual societal changes as the world adopted new products and devices running on renewables. The most striking change as of recently is the rapid adoption of electric vehicles. While they were hardly seen on the roads even 10 years ago
column6: now millions of electric cars are being sold annually. The electric car market is one of the most rapidly growing sectors
column7: and it helped propel Elon Musk to become the wealthiest man in the world.

column1: Unlike traditional cars which derive energy from the combustion of hydrocarbon fuels
column2: electric vehicles rely on batteries as the storage medium for their energy. For a long time
column3: batteries had far lower energy density than those offered by hydrocarbons
column4: which resulted in very low ranges of early electric vehicles. However
column5: gradual improvement in battery technologies eventually allowed the drive ranges of electric cars to be within acceptable levels in comparison to gasoline-burning cars. It is no understatement that the improvement in battery storage technology was one of the main technical bottlenecks which had to be solved in order to kickstart the current electric vehicle revolution.

column1: However
column2: despite the vast improvements in battery technology
column3: today consumers of electric vehicles face another difficulty – slow battery charging speed. Currently
column4: cars take about 10 hours to fully recharge at home. Even the fastest superchargers at the charging stations require up to 20-40 minutes to fully recharge the vehicles. This creates additional costs and inconvenience to the customers.

column1: To address this problem
column2: scientists looked for answers in the mysterious field of quantum physics. Their search has led to the discovery that quantum technologies may promise new mechanisms to charge batteries at a faster rate. Such concept of “quantum battery” has been first proposed in a seminal paper published by Alicki and Fannes in 2012. It was theorized that quantum resources
column3: such as entanglement
column4: can be used to vastly speed up the battery charging process by charging all cells within the battery simultaneously in a collective manner.

column1: This is particularly exciting as modern large-capacity batteries can contain numerous cells. Such collective charging is not possible in classical batteries
column2: where the cells are charged in parallel independently of one another. The advantage of this collective versus parallel charging can be measured by the ratio called the ‘quantum charging advantage’. Later
column3: around the year 2017
column4: it was noticed that there can be two possible sources behind this quantum advantage – namely ‘global operation’ (in which all the cells talk to all others simultaneously
column5: i.e.
column6: “all sitting at one table”) and ‘all-to-all coupling’ (every cell can talk with every other
column10: but every discussion has only two participants”). However
column11: it is unclear whether both these sources are necessary and whether there are any limits to the charging speed that can be achieved.

column1: Recently
column2: scientists from the Center for Theoretical Physics of Complex Systems within the Institute for Basic Science (IBS) further explored these questions. The paper
column3: which was chosen as an “Editor’s Suggestion” in the journal Physical Review Letters
column4: showed that all-to-all coupling is irrelevant in quantum batteries and that the presence of global operations is the only ingredient in the quantum advantage. The group went further to pinpoint the exact source of this advantage while ruling out any other possibilities and even provided an explicit way of designing such batteries.

column1: In addition
column2: the group was able to precisely quantify how much charging speed can be achieved in this scheme. While the maximum charging speed increases linearly with the number of cells in classical batteries
column3: the study showed that quantum batteries employing global operation can achieve quadratic scaling in charging speed. To illustrate this
column4: we will consider a typical electric vehicle with a battery that contains about 200 cells. Employing this quantum charging would lead to a 200 times speedup over classical batteries
column5: which means that at home charging time would be cut from 10 hours to about 3 minutes. At high-speed charging stations
column6: the charge time would be cut from 30 minutes to mere seconds.

column1: Researchers say that consequences can be far-reaching and that the implications of quantum charging can go well beyond electric cars and consumer electronics. For example
column2: it may find key uses in future fusion power plants
column3: which require large amounts of energy to be charged and discharged in an instant. Of course
column4: quantum technologies are still in their infancy and there is a long way to go before these methods can be implemented in practice. Research findings such as these
column5: however
column6: create a promising direction and can incentivize the funding agencies and businesses to further invest in these technologies. If employed
column7: it is believed that quantum batteries would completely revolutionize the way we use energy and take us a step closer to our sustainable future.";5573;['i1qryn3'

column1: 80;14;a07261de5bb92629f60fa08aef46f806f7aec71b8f3701978271004774030b9f;posted_link;r/science;http://arstechnica.com/science/news/2010/08/quantum-memory-may-topple-heisenbergs-uncertainty-principle.ars?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss;['cwfqs'];['spastichabits'];[1280760074.0];"[""Quantum memory may topple Heisenberg's uncertainty principle""]";[nan];2010-08-02;Casey Johnston;Quantum memory may topple Heisenberg's uncertainty principle;"A quantum memory may be all scientists need to beat the limit of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle
column2: according to a paper published in Nature Physics. According to a group of researchers
column3: maximally entangling a particle with a quantum memory and measuring one of the particle's variables
column4: like its position
column5: should snap the quantum memory in a corresponding state
column6: which could then be measured. This would allow them to do something long thought verboten by the laws of physics: figure out the state of certain pairs of variables at the exact same time with an unprecedented amount of certainty.

column1: Our ability to observe particles at the quantum level is currently limited by Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. Heisenberg noticed that when someone measured one variable of a particle
column2: such as its position
column3: there were some other variables
column4: like momentum
column5: that could not be simultaneously measured with as much precision—there was a small amount of uncertainty applied to one or both of the measurements.

column1: The physical reasoning behind this is hard to follow. But Paul Dirac
column2: another physicist
column3: made up a scenario to illustrate why some variables have this contentious relationship.

column1: Dirac pointed out that one of the only ways to measure a particle's position is by bouncing a photon off of it
column2: and seeing where and how that photon lands on a detector. How the photon lands completely describes the particle's position
column3: but by hitting it
column4: the measurement changes the particle's momentum.

column1: Likewise
column2: a measure of momentum would change the particle's position. Because of this quirk
column3: scientists thought it was impossible to know certain pairs of variables that affect one another at the same exact time with a very high degree of precision.

column1: Then along came entanglement. When two particles are entangled
column2: reading even one variable of one of the particles collapses the wavefunction of both particles
column3: giving finite values to all related variables.

column1: The cadre of scientists behind the current paper realized that
column2: by using the process of entanglement
column3: it would be possible to essentially use two particles to figure out the complete state of one. They might even be able to measure incompatible variables like position and momentum. The measurements might not be perfectly precise
column4: but the process could allow them to beat the limit of the uncertainty principle.

column1: The system the researchers worked out involves maximally entangling a particle with a quantum memory
column2: meaning all states and all degrees of freedom in the particle would be tied to all of the quantum memory's states. Once they were entangled and separated
column3: an observer would make a measurement of one of the particle's properties
column4: and then tell the keeper of the quantum memory which variable they measured.

column1: In theory
column2: there should be a measurement of the quantum memory that would yield the same result as the measurement done on the particle. The uncertainty relation between the measurement and any other incompatible variables wouldn't be present in the quantum memory
column3: however
column4: allowing observers to see exact measurements for two incompatible variables at the exact same instant in time.

column1: Of course
column2: the operative phrase here is ""in theory."" The research paper
column3: thought a bit esoteric and lacking in detail
column4: supports its argument with math involving Hilbert systems and entropy. But no experiment has yet taken place because our equipment isn't advanced enough yet.

column1: While quantum computing appears in the news regularly
column2: it's still only taking baby steps. Researchers are currently working with
column3: at most
column4: a handful of qubits at once
column5: so it will be a while until they create a quantum memory that could contain knowledge of all the particle's possible states and variables. Entangling all of this memory with a particle may prove even more difficult
column6: as entangled states are notoriously fragile.

column1: Still
column2: a process that could make Heisenberg's uncertainty principle a distant memory has the potential to shake the core of our particle knowledge. The authors of the paper particularly look forward to using the process to study the nature of entanglement itself
column3: a process we still don't fully understand. Even when the memory and the particle are less than maximally entangled
column4: measuring the two pieces could give scientists some solid numbers on the upper bound of how disordered the states of particles can be.";4369;['c0vs4pn'

column1: 81;476;71b37250c7f3bb15759597474e927385f2aff6ac610a14792688bfdc4e575a4d;posted_link;r/science;https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-00591-1;['m28nfw'];['MistWeaver80'];[1615410656.0];['Scientists captured the smallest measurement of gravity on record. Experiment shows that Newton’s law of gravity holds even for two masses as small as about 90 milligrams. The findings take us a step nearer to measuring gravitational fields that are so weak that they could enter the quantum regime.'];[nan];2021-03-10;"Rothleitner; Christian";Ultra-weak gravitational field detected;"An experiment shows that Newton’s law of gravity holds even for two masses as small as about 90 milligrams. The findings take us a step nearer to measuring gravitational fields that are so weak that they could enter the quantum regime.
Four fundamental forces are known in physics: the weak and strong interactions
column2: and the electromagnetic and gravitational forces. The gravitational force is the weakest of these four. For this reason
column3: and because experiments cannot be shielded from Earth’s gravity
column4: measurements of the gravitational field of a test object are difficult to do in the laboratory — even for objects that have multi-kilogram masses. But writing in Nature
column5: Westphal et al.1 report the detection of the gravitational coupling between two masses of only about 90 milligrams.

column1: The weak
column2: strong and electromagnetic interactions have been unified in the standard model of physics
column3: but the gravitational force cannot be integrated into that model. The best model currently available to describe gravity is the general theory of relativity. This theory has not failed any test so far
column4: but something is odd about it
column5: because it cannot be explained in terms of quantum mechanics.

column1: For most scientific purposes
column2: however
column3: we do not need to use the general theory of relativity to explain gravity — Isaac Newton’s law of universal gravitation2 works perfectly. Published in 1687
column4: Newton’s law states that the gravitational attraction between two bodies is proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. This has proved to be correct not only for describing most astronomical observations
column5: but also in laboratory experiments. For example
column6: the trajectory of a freely falling object (such as an apple falling from a tree) can be measured with a precision of less than ten parts in one billion3
column7: and the results are in good agreement with what would be expected from Newton’s law.

column1: During the twentieth century
column2: however
column3: doubts emerged about the general correctness of this law: an anomalous velocity distribution of stars in galaxies was observed4 in the early 1930s
column4: and could not be explained using Newton’s law alone5. Even the general theory of relativity cannot account for this phenomenon. One explanation is to postulate the existence of dark matter6 — an invisible
column5: but gravity-generating
column6: component of the Universe. However
column7: nobody really knows what this dark matter is made of.

column1: Another explanation
column2: which is controversial but easier to integrate into models than is dark matter
column3: is that Newton’s gravitational law needs a correction. One theory that attempts such a correction was proposed in the 1980s
column4: and is called modified Newtonian dynamics7. The basis of this theory is that gravitational field strength (the acceleration due to gravity) does not follow Newton’s inverse-square law over large distances.

column1: A further mystery is that the gravitational force is about 36 orders of magnitude weaker than the electromagnetic force. This is called the hierarchy problem8.
A framework known as string theory
column2: which was developed in part to provide a quantum-theoretical description of gravity
column3: addresses this problem by proposing that there are more spatial dimensions than the three that we can observe. Gravity — unlike the three other fundamental forces — is assumed to permeate these extra dimensions. If true
column4: then this could explain why the gravitational force is so much weaker than the electromagnetic force9. Another consequence would be that
column5: over a certain spatial range
column6: the gravitational force cannot be described by Newton’s inverse-square law.

column1: A further peculiar thing about gravity is that independent measurements of Newton’s gravitational constant (G
column2: a fundamental constant used in calculations of gravitational effects) have varied broadly10. Experimental determinations of other fundamental constants
column3: such as the Boltzmann constant11 or the speed of light12
column4: have converged as the number and precision of the measurements has increased. This has not happened for G.

column1: Westphal and colleagues’ experiments might take us a step closer to understanding the mysteries of gravity. They have investigated the gravitational force using a miniature version of a torsion balance — a device that was first used by Henry Cavendish in 1798 to measure Earth’s density13 (an experiment that is equivalent to measuring G)
column2: and which is still the gold-standard device for determining G14.

column1: A torsion balance consists of a horizontal bar suspended at the middle from a vertically hanging wire
column2: and with test masses attached to the ends. Earth’s gravitational attraction acts in the vertical direction
column3: along which the wire has a large stiffness. But in the horizontal direction
column4: the wire is easily twisted and has a tiny spring constant — very weak forces applied at right angles to the bar cause large rotations of the bar. The balance therefore generates an almost gravity-free environment (more accurately described as a microgravity) in the horizontal plane. This is perfect for detecting small forces
column5: such as the gravitational pull exerted on the bar by a nearby object (the source mass).

column1: In typical determinations of G
column2: the source masses were heavy (several kilograms)
column3: to compensate for the weakness of the gravitational force. By contrast
column4: Westphal and co-workers used gold spheres only 92 milligrams in mass (Fig. 1)
column5: about the mass of 4 houseflies. This is the lowest source mass ever used in such an experiment.

column1: A calculation using Newton’s law of gravitation shows that the force acting between two spherical masses of 90?mg with a centre-of-mass separation of 2.5 millimetres (approximately the parameters of Westphal and colleagues’ experiment) is only about 9?×?10–14 newtons. This is roughly the same force that acts on a mass of 9 picograms (1?pg is 10–12?g) in Earth’s gravity field; to put that into perspective
column2: 9?pg is about one-third the mass of a human red-blood cell15. The big challenge was therefore to extract this extremely small gravitational signal from background ‘noise’ in the experiment
column3: and from the effects of other forces (such as electromagnetic interactions) that become stronger than gravitational forces when the source and test masses are separated by small distances.

column1: Westphal et al. therefore modulated the signal by periodically varying the position of the source mass with respect to the test mass in the torsion balance. As a consequence of the time-dependent gravitational interaction
column2: the balance oscillated in the horizontal plane at the frequency of the signal modulation (12.7 millihertz). Because the gravitational field of a spherical mass is nonlinear (a consequence of Newton’s inverse-square law)
column3: the balance is also stimulated to oscillate at higher frequencies that are multiples of the modulation frequency (known as higher harmonics). This effect could be clearly identified in the experiment
column4: thus providing a signature of the gravitational coupling between the masses.

column1: The detection of such a minuscule gravitational signal is itself an exciting result
column2: but the authors went even further by determining a value for G from their experiment. Their estimate deviates from the internationally agreed value (see go.nature.com/2bwkrqz) by about 9% — a small amount
column3: given that the experimental uncertainties of their system have not yet not been optimized for precise measurements of G. The experiment is therefore the first to show that Newton’s law of gravity holds even for source masses as small as these.

column1: The next step is to push on to even smaller masses — Westphal et al. suggest that gravitational fields of masses of the order of 10–8?kg could eventually be measured. However
column2: much work will need to be done to achieve this goal. The first task will be to substantially reduce damping of the oscillations of the torsion balance
column3: which won’t be easy. But if it can be done
column4: then perhaps quantum gravitational effects will finally be observed.";7983;['gqhsqw1'
