column1: 94;1077;9b95d8115a3397140d17c3dd01a6a153a137c85ed13485fe7f152f8bee1d4eaf;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.space.com/google-invents-time-crystal;['prk79l'];['EricFromOuterSpace'];[1632098711.0];"[""Researchers working in partnership with Google may have just used the tech giant's quantum computer to create a completely new phase of matter—a time crystal. With the ability to forever cycle between two states without ever losing energy
column2: time crystals seem to dodge the 2nd law of thermodynamics.""]";[nan];2021-09-18;Ben Turner;Otherworldly 'time crystal' made inside Google quantum computer could change physics forever;"Researchers working in partnership with Google may have just used the tech giant's quantum computer to create a completely new phase of matter (opens in new tab) — a time crystal.

column1: With the ability to forever cycle between two states without ever losing energy
column2: time crystals dodge one of the most important laws of physics — the second law of thermodynamics (opens in new tab)
column3: which states that the disorder
column4: or entropy
column5: of an isolated system must always increase. These bizarre time crystals remain stable
column6: resisting any dissolution into randomness
column7: despite existing in a constant state of flux.

column1: According to a research article posted July 28 to the preprint database arXiv (opens in new tab)
column2: scientists were able to create the time crystal for roughly 100 seconds using qubits (quantum computing's version of the traditional computer bit) inside the core of Google's Sycamore quantum processor.

column1: The existence of this weird new matter phase
column2: and the entirely new realm of physical behaviors it reveals
column3: is incredibly exciting to physicists
column4: especially as time crystals were only first predicted to exist just nine years ago.

column1: This was a big surprise
column2: Curt von Keyserlingk
column3: a physicist at the University of Birmingham in the U.K. who was not involved in the study
column4: told Live Science. ""If you asked someone 30
column5: 20 or maybe even 10 years ago
column6: they would not have expected this.""

column1: Time crystals are fascinating objects to physicists because they essentially sidestep the second law of thermodynamics
column2: one of the most ironclad laws in physics. It states that entropy (a rough analog for the amount of disorder in a system) always increases. If you want to make something more ordered
column3: you need to put more energy into it.

column1: This tendency for disorder to grow explains a lot of things
column2: such as why it's easier to stir ingredients into a mixture than it is to separate them out again
column3: or why headphone cords get so tangled in pants' pockets. It also sets the arrow of time
column4: with the past universe always more ordered than the present; watching a video in reverse
column5: for instance
column6: is likely to look strange to you primarily because you're witnessing the counterintuitive reversal of this entropic flow.(opens in new tab)

column1: Time crystals don't follow this rule. Instead of slowly approaching thermal equilibrium — ""thermalizing"" so that their energy or temperature is equally distributed throughout their surroundings
column2: they get stuck between two energy states above that equilibrium state
column3: cycling back and forth between them indefinitely.

column1: To explain how deeply unusual this behavior is
column2: von Keyserlingk said to picture a sealed box filled with coins before being shaken a million times. As the coins ricochet from
column3: and bounce around
column4: each other
column5: they ""become more and more chaotic
column6: exploring all of the sorts of configurations that they can explore"" until the shaking stops
column7: and the box is opened to reveal the coins in a random configuration
column8: with roughly half of the coins facing up and half facing down. We can expect to see this random
column10: half-down endpoint regardless of the way we first arranged the coins in the box.

column1: Inside the ""box"" of Google's Sycamore
column2: we can view the quantum processor's qubits much like we would our coins. In the same way that the coins can be either heads or tails
column3: qubits can be either a 1 or a 0 — the two possible positions in a two-state system — or a weird mix of the probabilities of both states called a superposition. What's weird about time crystals
column4: von Keyserlingk says
column5: is that no amount of shaking
column6: or zapping from one state to another
column7: can move the time crystal's qubits into the lowest energy state
column8: which is a random configuration; they can only flip it from its starting state to its second state

column1: It just sort of flip-flops
column2: von Keyserlingk said. ""It doesn't end up looking random
column3: it just gets jammed stuck. It's like it remembers what it looked like initially
column4: and it repeats that pattern over time.""

column1: In this sense
column2: a time crystal is like a pendulum that never stops swinging.

column1: Even if you totally physically isolate a pendulum from the universe
column2: so there's no friction and no air resistance
column3: it will eventually stop. And that's because of the second law of thermodynamics
column4: Achilleas Lazarides
column5: a physicist at the University of Loughborough in the U.K. who was among the scientists to first discover the theoretical possibility of the new phase in 2015
column6: told Live Science. ""Energy starts out concentrated in the pendulum's center of mass
column7: but there's all of these internal degrees of freedom — like the ways the atoms (opens in new tab) can vibrate inside the rod — that it will eventually be transferred into.""

column1: In fact
column2: there's no way for a large-scale object to behave like a time crystal without sounding absurd
column3: because the only rules that enable time crystals to exist are the spooky and surreal rules that govern the world of the very small — quantum mechanics (opens in new tab).

column1: In the quantum world
column2: objects behave both like point particles and little waves at the same time
column3: with the magnitude of these waves in any given region of space representing the probability of finding a particle at that location. But randomness (such as random defects in a crystal's structure or a programmed randomness in the interaction strengths between qubits) can cause a particle's probability wave to cancel itself out everywhere apart from one very small region. Rooted in place
column4: unable to move
column5: change states or thermalize with its surroundings
column6: the particle becomes localized.

column1: The researchers used this localization process as the foundation of their experiment. Using 20 strips of superconducting aluminum (opens in new tab) for their qubits
column2: the scientists programmed each one into one of two possible states. Then
column3: by blasting a microwave beam over the strips
column4: they were able to drive their qubits to flip states; the researchers repeated the experiment for tens of thousands of runs and stopped at different points to record the states their qubits were in. What they found was that their collection of qubits was flipping back and forth between only two configurations
column5: and the qubits weren't absorbing heat from the microwave beam either — they had made a time crystal.

column1: They also saw a key clue that their time crystal was a phase of matter. For something to be considered a phase
column2: it usually has to be very stable in the face of fluctuations. Solids will not melt if the temperatures (opens in new tab) around them vary slightly; neither will slight fluctuations cause liquids to evaporate or freeze suddenly. In the same way
column3: if the microwave beam used to flip the qubits between states was adjusted to be close to but slightly off from the exact 180 degrees needed for a perfect flip
column4: the qubits still nonetheless flipped to the other state.

column1: It's not the case that if you're not exactly at the 180 degrees you will scramble them
column2: Lazarides said. ""It [the time crystal] magically will always tip a bit in
column3: even if you're making slight mistakes.""

column1: Another hallmark of moving from one phase to another is the breaking of physical symmetries
column2: the idea that the laws of physics are the same for an object at any point in time or space. As a liquid
column3: the molecules in water follow the same physical laws at every point in space and in every direction
column4: but cool water down enough so that it transforms into ice and its molecules will pick regular points along a crystal structure — or lattice — to arrange themselves across. Suddenly
column5: the water molecules have preferred points in space to occupy
column6: and they leave the other points empty — the spatial symmetry of the water has been spontaneously broken.

column1: In much the same way that ice becomes a crystal in space by breaking with spatial symmetry
column2: time crystals become crystals in time by breaking with time symmetry. At first
column3: before their transformation into the time crystal phase
column4: the row of qubits will experience a continuous symmetry between all moments in time. But the periodic cycle of the microwave beam chops the constant conditions experienced by the qubits down into discrete packets (making the symmetry imposed by the beam a discrete time-translation symmetry). Then
column5: by flipping back and forth at twice the period of the wavelength of the beam
column6: the qubits break with the discrete time-translation symmetry imposed by the laser. They are the first objects we know of that are able to do this.

column1: All of this weirdness makes time crystals rich in new physics
column2: and the control that Sycamore provides researchers beyond other experimental setups could make it an ideal platform for further investigation. That's not to say it cannot be improved
column3: however. Like all quantum systems
column4: Google's quantum computer needs to be perfectly isolated from its environment to prevent its qubits from undergoing a process called decoherence
column5: which eventually breaks down the quantum localization effects
column6: destroying the time crystal. The researchers are working on ways to better isolate their processor and mitigate the impact of decoherence
column7: but it's unlikely they will eliminate the effect for good.

column1: Despite this
column2: Google's experiment is likely to remain the best way to study time crystals for the foreseeable future. Though numerous other projects have succeeded in making what convincingly appear to be time crystals in other ways — with diamonds
column3: helium-3 superfluids
column4: quasiparticles called magnons and with Bose-Einstein condensates (opens in new tab) — for the most part the crystals produced in these setups dissipate too quickly for detailed study.

column1: The theoretical newness of the crystals is in some ways a double-edged sword
column2: as physicists currently struggle to find clear applications for them
column3: although von Keyserlingk has suggested that they could be used as highly accurate sensors. Other proposals include using the crystals for better memory storage or for developing quantum computers with even faster processing power.

column1: But in another sense
column2: the greatest application of time crystals may already be here: They allow scientists to probe the boundaries of quantum mechanics.

column1: It allows you to not just study what shows up in nature
column2: but to actually design it and look at what quantum mechanics lets you do and doesn't let you do
column3: Lazarides said. ""If you don't find something in nature then it doesn't mean it can't exist — we just created one of those things.""";10385;['hdjjmgg'
column4: 'hdja9uq'
column5: 'hdjvci6'
column6: 'hdjbmk5'

column1: 95;685;eaaffba4c5f53b9a0962c45494864cde9445a0e328778180f8d0e1238fc94f76;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2022-07-mathematical-quantum-interstellar-space.html;['vt3f6a'];['criticalbeta37'];[1657148982.0];['Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible'];[nan];2022-07-06;Bob Yirka;Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible;"Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible

A team of physicists at the University of Edinburgh's School of Physics and Astronomy has used mathematical calculations to show that quantum communications across interstellar space should be possible. In their paper published in the journal Physical Review D
column2: the group describes their calculations and also the possibility of extraterrestrial beings attempting to communicate with us using such signaling.

column1: Over the past several years
column2: scientists have been investigating the possibility of using quantum communications as a highly secure form of message transmission. Prior research has shown that it would be nearly impossible to intercept such messages without detection. In this new effort
column3: the researchers wondered if similar types of communications might be possible across interstellar space. To find out
column4: they used math that describes that movement of X-rays across a medium
column5: such as those that travel between the stars. More specifically
column6: they looked to see if their calculations could show the degree of decoherence that might occur during such a journey.

column1: With quantum communications
column2: engineers are faced with quantum particles that lose some or all of their unique characteristics as they interact with obstructions in their path—they have been found to be quite delicate
column3: in fact. Such events are known as decoherence
column4: and engineers working to build quantum networks have been devising ways to overcome the problem. Prior research has shown that the space between the stars is pretty clean. But is it clean enough for quantum communications? The math shows that it is. Space is so clean
column5: in fact
column6: that X-ray photons could travel hundreds of thousands of light years without becoming subject to decoherence—and that includes gravitational interference from astrophysical bodies. They noted in their work that optical and microwave bands would work equally well.

column1: The researchers noted that because quantum communication is possible across the galaxy
column2: if other intelligent beings exist in the Milky Way
column3: they could already be trying to communicate with us using such technology and we could begin looking for them. They also suggest that quantum teleportation across interstellar space should be possible.";2318;['if5byup'
column4: 'if5gl2q'

column1: 96;1119;28dc4cea2e5191b861553243d4fc662a282c4e7db068ca311a33f044e0d08df6;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://www.technologyreview.com/news/544421/googles-quantum-dream-machine/;['3xbugx'];['Simcurious'];[1450433148.0];"['Inside Google\'s Quantum Computing Lab - ""In 10 years there’s nothing but quantum machine learning""']";[nan];2015-12-18;Tom Simonite;Google’s Quantum Dream Machine;"Physicist John Martinis could deliver one of the holy grails of computing to Google—a machine that dramatically speeds up today’s applications and makes new ones possible.

John Martinis used the arm of his reading glasses to indicate the spot where he intends to demonstrate an almost unimaginably powerful new form of computer in a few years. It is a cylindrical socket an inch and a half across
column2: at the bottom of a torso-sized stack of plates
column3: blocks
column4: and wires of brass
column5: copper
column6: and gold. The day after I met with him this fall
column7: he loaded the socket with an experimental superconducting chip etched with a microscopic Google logo and cooled the apparatus to a hundredth of a degree Celsius above absolute zero. To celebrate that first day of testing the machine
column8: Martinis threw what he called “a little party” at a brewpub with colleagues from his newly outfitted Google lab in Santa Barbara

column1: John Martinis has been researching how quantum computers could work for 30 years. Now he could be on the verge of finally making a useful one.

That party was nothing compared with the celebration that will take place if Martinis and his group can actually create the wonder computer they seek. Because it would harness the strange properties of quantum physics that arise in extreme conditions like those on the ultracold chip
column2: the new computer would let a Google coder run calculations in a coffee break that would take a supercomputer of today millions of years. The software that Google has developed on ordinary computers to drive cars or answer questions could become vastly more intelligent. And earlier-stage ideas bubbling up at Google and its parent company
column3: such as robots that can serve as emergency responders or software that can converse at a human level
column4: might become real.

column1: The theoretical underpinnings of quantum computing are well established. And physicists can build the basic units
column2: known as qubits
column3: out of which a quantum computer would be made. They can even operate qubits together in small groups. But they have not made a fully working
column4: practical quantum computer.

column1: Martinis is a towering figure in the field: his research group at the University of California
column2: Santa Barbara
column3: has demonstrated some of the most reliable qubits around and gotten them running some of the code a quantum computer would need to function. He was hired by Google in June 2014 after persuading the company that his team’s technology could mature rapidly with the right support. With his new Google lab up and running
column4: Martinis guesses that he can demonstrate a small but useful quantum computer in two or three years. “We often say to each other that we’re in the process of giving birth to the quantum computer industry
column5: ” he says.

column1: Google and quantum computing are a match made in algorithmic heaven. The company is often said to be defined by an insatiable hunger for data. But Google has a more pressing strategic addiction: to technology that extracts information from data
column2: and even creates intelligence from it. The company was founded to commercialize an algorithm for ranking Web pages
column3: and it built its financial foundations with systems that sell and target ads. More recently
column4: Google has invested heavily in the development of AI software that can learn to understand language or images
column5: perform basic reasoning
column6: or steer a car through traffic—all things that remain tricky for conventional computers but should be a breeze for quantum ones. “Machine learning is a core
column7: transformative way by which we’re rethinking how we’re doing everything
column10: recently informed investors. Supporting that effort would be the first of many jobs for Martinis’s new quantum industry.

column1: Dream maker
As recently as last week the prospect of a quantum computer doing anything useful within a few years seemed remote. Researchers in government
column2: academic
column3: and corporate labs were far from combining enough qubits to make even a simple proof-of-principle machine. A well-funded Canadian startup called D-Wave Systems sold a few of what it called “the world’s first commercial quantum computers” but spent years failing to convince experts that the machines actually were doing what a quantum computer should (see “The CIA and Jeff Bezos Bet on Quantum Computing”).

column1: Then NASA summoned journalists to building N-258 at its Ames Research Center in Mountain View
column2: California
column3: which since 2013 has hosted a D-Wave computer bought by Google. There Hartmut Neven
column4: who leads the Quantum Artificial Intelligence lab Google established to experiment with the D-Wave machine
column5: unveiled the first real evidence that it can offer the power proponents of quantum computing have promised. In a carefully designed test
column6: the superconducting chip inside D-Wave’s computer—known as a quantum annealer—had performed 100 million times faster than a conventional processor.

column1: As recently as last week the prospect of a quantum computer doing anything useful within a few years seemed remote. Then NASA summoned journalists to its Ames Research Center in Mountain View.
However
column2: this kind of advantage needs to be available in practical computing tasks
column3: not just contrived tests. “We need to make it easier to take a problem that comes up at an engineer’s desk and put it into the computer
column4: ” said Neven
column5: a talkative machine-learning expert. That’s where Martinis comes in. Neven doesn’t think D-Wave can get a version of its quantum annealer ready to serve Google’s engineers quickly enough
column6: so he hired Martinis to do it. “It became clear that we can’t just wait
column7: ” Neven says. “There’s a list of shortcomings that need to be overcome in order to arrive at a real technology.” He says the qubits on D-Wave’s chip are too unreliable and aren’t wired together thickly enough. (D-Wave’s CEO
column9: responds that he’s not worried about competition from Google.)

column1: Google will be competing not only with whatever improvements D-Wave can make
column2: but also with Microsoft and IBM
column3: which have substantial quantum computing projects of their own (see “Microsoft’s Quantum Mechanics” and “IBM Shows Off a Quantum Computing Chip”). But those companies are focused on designs much further from becoming practically useful. Indeed
column4: a rough internal time line for Google’s project estimates that Martinis’s group can make a quantum annealer with 100 qubits as soon as 2017. D-Wave’s latest chip already has 1
column5: 097 qubits
column6: but Neven says a high-quality chip with fewer qubits will probably be useful for some tasks nonetheless. A quantum annealer can run only one particular algorithm
column7: but it happens to be one well suited to the areas Google most cares about. The applications that could particularly benefit include pattern recognition and machine learning
column9: a senior staff member at MIT Lincoln Laboratory who has studied the potential of quantum computing.

column1: John Martinis
column3: is the perfect person to wrestle a mind-bogglingly complex strand of quantum physics research into a new engineering discipline. Not only can he dive into the esoteric math
column4: but he loves to build things. Operating even a single qubit is a puzzle assembled from deep quantum theory
column5: solid-state physics
column6: materials science
column10: who is tall with a loud
column12: makes a point of personally mastering the theory and technical implementation of every piece. Giving a tour of his new lab at Google
column13: he is as excited about the new soldering irons and machine tools in the conventional workshop area as he is about the more sophisticated equipment that chills chips and operates them. “To me it’s fun
column14: ” he says. “I’ve been able to do experiments no one else could do
column15: because I could build my own electronics.”

column1: Martinis and his team have to be adept at so many things because qubits are fickle. They can be made in various ways—Martinis uses aluminum loops chilled with tiny currents until they become superconductors—but all represent data by means of delicate quantum states that are easily distorted or destroyed by heat and electromagnetic noise
column2: potentially ruining a calculation.

column1: Qubits use their fragile physics to do the same thing that transistors use electricity to do on a conventional chip: represent binary bits of information
column2: either 0 or 1. But qubits can also attain a state
column3: called a superposition
column4: that is effectively both 0 and 1 at the same time. Qubits in a superposition can become linked by a phenomenon known as entanglement
column5: which means an action performed on one has instant effects on the other. Those effects allow a single operation in a quantum computer to do the work of many
column6: many more operations in a conventional computer. In some cases
column7: a quantum computer’s advantage over a conventional one should grow exponentially with the amount of data to be worked on.

column1: The difficulty of creating qubits that are stable enough is the reason we don’t have quantum computers yet. But Martinis has been working on that for more than 11 years and thinks he’s nearly there. The coherence time of his qubits
column2: or the length of time they can maintain a superposition
column3: is tens of microseconds—about 10
column4: 000 times the figure for those on D-Wave’s chip.

column1: Martinis’s confidence in his team’s hardware even has him thinking he can build Google an alternative to a quantum annealer that would be even more powerful. A universal quantum computer
column2: as it would be called
column3: could be programmed to take on any kind of problem
column4: not just one kind of math. The theory behind that approach is actually better understood than the one for annealers
column5: in part because most of the time and money in quantum computing research have been devoted to universal quantum computing. But qubits have not been reliable enough to translate the theory into a working universal quantum computer.

column1: Until March
column2: that is
column3: when Martinis and his team became the first to demonstrate qubits that crossed a crucial reliability threshold for a universal quantum computer (see “Google Researchers Make Quantum Computing Components More Reliable”). They got a chip with nine qubits to run part of an error-checking program
column4: called the surface code
column5: that’s necessary for such a computer to operate (IBM has since gotten part of the surface code working on four qubits). “We demonstrated the technology to a point where I knew we could scale up
column6: ” says Martinis. “This was for real.”

column1: Martinis aims to show off a complete universal quantum computer with about 100 qubits around the same time he delivers Google’s new quantum annealer
column2: in about two years. That would be a milestone in computer science
column3: but it would be unlikely to help Google’s programmers right away. Such is the complexity of the surface code that although a chip with 100 qubits could run the error-checking program
column4: it would be unable to do any useful work in addition to that
column5: says Robert McDermott
column6: who leads a quantum computing research group at the University of Wisconsin. Yet Martinis thinks that once he can get his qubits reliable enough to put 100 of them on a universal quantum chip
column7: the path to combining many more will open up. “This is something we understand pretty well
column8: ” he says. “It’s hard to get coherence but easy to scale up.”

column1: Stupid algorithms
When Martinis explains why his technology is needed at Google
column2: he doesn’t spare the feelings of the people working on AI. “Machine-learning algorithms are really kind of stupid
column3: ” he says
column4: with a hint of wonder in his voice. “They need so many examples to learn.”

column1: Indeed
column2: the machine learning used by Google and other computing companies is pathetic next to the way humans or animals pick up new skills or knowledge. Teaching a piece of software new tricks
column3: such as how to recognize cars and cats in photos
column4: generally requires thousands or millions of carefully curated and labeled examples. Although a technique called deep learning has recently produced striking advances in the accuracy with which software can learn to interpret images and speech
column5: more complex faculties like understanding the nuances of language remain out of machines’ reach.

column1: Figuring out how Martinis’s chips can make Google’s software less stupid falls to Neven. He thinks that the prodigious power of qubits will narrow the gap between machine learning and biological learning—and remake the field of artificial intelligence. “Machine learning will be transformed into quantum learning
column2: ” he says. That could mean software that can learn from messier data
column3: or from less data
column4: or even without explicit instruction. For instance
column5: Google’s researchers have designed an algorithm they think could allow machine-learning software to pick up a new trick even if as much as half the example data it’s given is incorrectly labeled. Neven muses that this kind of computational muscle could be the key to giving computers capabilities today limited to humans. “People talk about whether we can make creative machines–the most creative systems we can build will be quantum AI systems
column6: ” he says.

column1: More practically
column2: with only D-Wave’s machine to practice on for now
column3: Google’s researchers can’t do much more than speculate about what exactly they could or should do with the chips Martinis is building. Even when they do get their hands on them
column4: it will take time to invent and build the infrastructure needed to operate large numbers of the exotic devices so they can contribute materially to Google’s business.

column1: Neven is confident that Google’s quantum craftsmen and his team can get through all that. He pictures rows of superconducting chips lined up in data centers for Google engineers to access over the Internet relatively soon. “I would predict that in 10 years there’s nothing but quantum machine learning–you don’t do the conventional way anymore
column2: ” he says. A smiling Martinis warily accepts that vision. “I like that
column3: but it’s hard
column4: ” he says. “He can say that
column5: but I have to build it.”";13940;['cy3e3vy'

column1: 97;132;d45caf5dc4b7ebe37992e86dd880268fd8a8135798ba62b101ea91258cdab0d1;posted_link;r/Physics;http://uk.businessinsider.com/solvay-conference-1927-2015-4?r=US;['33h71e'];['ritish1415'];[1429712736.0];"[""The world's brightest scientific minds posed for this 1927 photo after historic debates about quantum mechanics""]";[nan];2016-04-22;Amanda Macias;The world's brightest scientific minds posed for this 1927 photo after historic debates about quantum mechanics;"""Einstein
column2: stop telling God what to do
column3: physicist Niels Bohr once told Albert Einstein
column4: who in a room full of the world's most notable scientific minds argued ""God does not play dice.""

column2: Einstein and Bohr were two of the 29 scientists (more than half of whom were or would later become Nobel Prize recipients) in attendance at the Fifth Solvay Institut International de Physique in Brussels to discuss the foundations of the newly formed quantum theory.

column1: During the conference
column2: Einstein led a series of thought experiments in which he tried to prove that the ""Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle (and hence quantum mechanics itself) was just plain wrong
column3: according to Jonathan Dowling
column4: codirector of the Horace Hearne Institute for Theoretical Physics.

column1: Each sleepless night
column2: Bohr would worry and fume and ruminate about Einstein's attack
column3: and then he would respond the next day with a keen rebuttal
column4: showing where Einstein has missed something
column5: and salvage Heisenberg's principle. This debate went on for days at that Solvay conference and continued on 3 years later at the next conference
column6: Dowling writes in his book
column7: Schrödinger's Killer App: Race to Build the World's First Quantum Computer.

column1: Bohr's counterattack involved using Einstein's own theory of relativity against him — and it reportedly won the argument. Eight years later
column2: Einstein still struggled to prove that the theory was incorrect
column3: instead describing it as ""incomplete.""

column1: Curie
column2: the only woman in attendance
column3: was also the only one among them to win a Nobel Prize in two separate disciplines: chemistry and physics.";1589;['cql26e3'

column1: 98;1195;ebbcdfdd912f2a99319852cd2e7232e10117d4c3883bb74ea9837c5564146cef;posted_link;r/HighStrangeness;https://thenextweb.com/news/google-may-have-achieved-breakthrough-time-crystals/amp;['ow6h37'];['irrelevantappelation'];[1627874576.0];['Google’s ‘time crystals’ could be the greatest scientific achievement of our lifetimes: Alleged development of a new
column2: Newtonian physics breaking
column3: phase of matter could be the key to unlocking the full potential of quantum computing.'];[nan];2021-12-27;Tristan Greene;Google’s ‘time crystals’ could be the greatest scientific achievement of our lifetimes ;"EurekaEurekaEurekaEureka!

column1: Eureka! A research team featuring dozens of scientists working in partnership with Google’s quantum computing labs may have created the world’s first time crystal inside a quantum computer.
This is the kind of news that makes me want to jump up and do a happy dance.

These scientists may have produced an entirely new phase of matter. I’m going to do my best to explain what that means and why I personally believe this is the most important scientific breakthrough in our lifetimes.
However
column2: for the sake of clarity
column3: there’s two points I need to make first:

column1: 1. Time crystals are a wickedly difficult concept to understand and even harder to explain.

2. The Google team might have created time crystals. This is pre-print research and has yet to receive full peer-review. Until the rest of the scientific community has time to review and replicate the work
column2: we can’t say for sure it’s legitimate.

column1: What’s a time crystal?
In colloquial terms
column2: it’s a big screw you to Sir Isaac Newton.

column1: Time crystals are a new phase of matter. For the sake of simplicity
column2: let’s imagine a cube of ice.

column1: When you put a cube of ice in glass of water
column2: you’re introducing two separate entities (the ice cube and the liquid water) to each other at two different temperatures.

column1: Everyone knows that the water will get colder (that’s why we put the ice in there) and
column2: over time
column3: the ice will get warmer and turn into water. Eventually you’ll just have a glass of room-temperature water.

column1: We call this process “thermal equilibrium.”
Most people are familiar with Newton’s first law of motion
column2: it’s the one that says “an object at rest tends to stay at rest and an object in motion tends to stay in motion.”

column1: An important side-effect of this law of physics is that it means a perpetual motion machine is classically impossible.
According to classical physics
column2: the universe is always moving towards entropy. In other words: if we isolate an ice cube and a room-temperature glass of water from all other external forces
column3: the water will always melt the ice cube.

column1: The entropy (the movement towards change) of any system will always remain the same if there are no processes
column2: and it will always increase if there are processes.

column1: Since our universe has stars exploding
column2: black holes sucking
column3: and people lighting things on fire – chemical processes – entropy is always increasing.

column1: Except when it comes to time crystals. Time crystals don’t give a damn what Newton or anyone else thinks. They’re lawbreakers and heart takers. They can
column2: theoretically
column3: maintain entropy even when they’re used in a process.

column1: What’s that mean
Think about a crystal you’re familiar with
column2: such as a snowflake. Snowflakes aren’t just beautiful because each one is unique
column3: they’re also fascinating formations that nearly break the laws of physics themselves.

column1: Crystalline structures form in the physical world because
column2: for whatever fundamental scientific reason
column3: the atoms within them “want” to exist in certain exact points.

column1: “Want” is a really weird word to use when we’re talking about atoms – I’m certainly not implying they’re sentient – but it’s hard to describe the tendency toward crystalline structures in abstracts such as “why.”
A time crystal is a new phase of matter that
column2: simplified
column3: would be like having a snowflake that constantly cycled back and forth between two different configurations. It’s a seven-pointed lattice one moment and a ten-pointed lattice the next
column4: or whatever.

column1: What’s amazing about time crystals is that when they cycle back and forth between two different configurations
column2: they don’t lose or use any energy.

column1: Time crystals can survive energy processes without falling victim to entropy. The reason they’re called time crystals is because they can have their cake and eat it too.
They can be in a state of having eaten the whole cake
column2: and then cycle right back to a state of still having the cake – and they can
column3: theoretically
column4: do this forever and ever.

column1: Most importantly
column2: they can do this inside of an isolated system. That means they can consume the cake and then magically make it reappear over and over again forever
column3: without using any fuel or energy.

column1: Who cares? What’s this going to mean for me?
Literally everyone should care. As I wrote back in 2018
column2: time crystals could be the miracle quantum computing needs.

column1: Nearly every far-future tech humans can imagine
column2: from teleportation to warp drives and from artificial food synthesizers to perpetual motion reactors capable of powering the world without burning fuels or harnessing energy
column3: will require quantum computing systems.

column1: Quantum computers can solve really hard problems. Unfortunately
column2: they’re brittle. It’s hard to build them
column3: hard to maintain them
column4: hard to get them to do anything
column5: and even harder to interpret the results they give. This is because of something called “decoherence
column6: ” which works a lot like entropy.

column1: Computer bits in the quantum world
column2: qubits
column3: share a funky feature of quantum mechanics that makes them act differently when observed than when they’re left alone. That sort of makes any direct measurements of qubit states (reading the computer’s output) difficult.

column1: But time crystals want to be coherent. So putting them inside a quantum computer
column2: and using them to conduct computer processes could potentially serve an incredibly important function: ensuring quantum coherence.

column1: So Google solved quantum computing?
No. No
column2: no
column3: no
column4: no no. Don’t get me wrong. This is baby steps. This is infancy research. This is Antony van Leeuwenhoek becoming the first person to use a microscope to look at a drop of water under magnification.

column1: What Google’s done
column2: potentially
column3: is prove that humans can manufacture time crystals. In the words of the researchers themselves:

column1: These results establish a scalable approach to study non-equilibrium phases of matter on current quantum processors.
Basically they believe they’ve proven the concept
column2: so now it’s time to see what can be done with it.

column1: Then why is this so exciting?
Time crystals have always been theoretical. And by “always
column2: ” I mean: since 2012 when they were first hypothesized.

column1: If Google’s actually created time-crystals
column2: it could accelerate the timeline for quantum computing breakthroughs from “maybe never” to “maybe within a few decades.”

column1: At the far-fetched
column2: super-optimistic end of things – we could see the creation of a working warp drive in our lifetimes. Imagine taking a trip to Mars or the edge of our solar system
column3: and being back home on Earth in time to catch the evening news.

column1: And
column2: even on the conservative end with more realistic expectations
column3: it’s not hard to imagine quantum computing-based chemical and drug discovery leading to universally-effective cancer treatments.

column1: This could be the big eureka we’ve all been waiting for. I can’t wait to see what happens in peer-review.";6839;['h7e0ktp'

column1: 99;694;ec6950e4738a52f153382ef5921a5a769042fdbd47c85d9fcf242ea396ced227;posted_link;r/technews;https://phys.org/news/2022-11-fluxonium-qubits-creation-quantum-closer.html;['z2kc6l'];['dont_step_on_toes'];[1669194570.0];['Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer'];[nan];2022-11-21;"The National University; Technology MISIS";Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer;"Fluxonium qubits bring the creation of a quantum computer closer

Russian scientists from University of Science and Technology MISIS and Bauman Moscow State Technical University were one of the first in the world to implement a two-qubit operation using superconducting fluxonium qubits. Fluxoniums have a longer life cycle and a greater precision of operations
column2: so they are used to make longer algorithms. An article on research that brings the creation of a quantum computer closer to reality has been published in npj Quantum Information.

column1: One of the main questions in the development of a universal quantum computer is about qubits. Namely
column2: which quantum objects are the best to make processors for quantum computers: electrons
column3: photons
column4: ions
column5: superconductors
column6: or other ""quantum transistors."" Superconducting qubits have become one of the most successful platforms for quantum computing during the past decade. To date
column7: the most commercially successful superconducting qubits are transmons
column8: which are actively investigated and used in the quantum developments of Google
column9: IBM and other world leading laboratories.

column1: The main task of a qubit is to store and process information without errors. Accidental noise and even mere observation can lead to the loss or alteration of data. The stable operation of superconducting qubits often requires extremely low ambient temperatures—close to zero Kelvin
column2: which is hundreds of times colder than the temperature of open space.

column1: Russian physicists from the Superconducting Metamaterials laboratory at MISIS University and Bauman Moscow State Technical University were one of the first in the world to implement a two-qubit operation using superconducting fluxonium qubits. To protect qubits from noise
column2: the researchers added to the circuit a superinductor (a superconducting element with a high level of resistance to alternating current) which is a chain of 40 Josephson contacts—structures of two superconductors separated by a thin layer of dielectric.

column1: Fluxonium qubits are more complex and less studied than transmons. The main advantage of fluxoniums is that they can be operated at a low frequency of about 600 MHz. We know that the lower the frequency
column2: the longer the lifetime of qubits
column3: which means that more operations can be performed with them. During the tests
column4: it turned out that the dielectric losses of fluxonium qubits allow to keep the state of the superposition longer than that of transmons
column5: said Ilya Besedin
column6: one of the authors of the study
column7: an engineer of the scientific project at the NUST MISIS Superconducting Metamaterials laboratory.

column1: To implement a universal set of logical operations
column2: scientists used high-precision two-qubit gates: fSim and CZ. In order to bring the qubits into resonance with each other
column3: parametric modulation of the flow of one of the qubits of the system was used. The authors of the study note
column4: that due to the tunable coupling element
column5: it was simultaneously possible not only to obtain the accuracy of two-qubit operations above 99.22%
column6: but also to suppress the residual ZZ interaction between the qubits
column7: which allowed to perform parallel single-qubit operations with an accuracy of 99.97%.

column1: The low frequency of computational qubits opens the way not only to longer qubits' lifetimes and accuracy of valve operations
column2: which will lead to making longer algorithms
column3: but also makes it possible to use subgigahertz electronics in qubit control lines
column4: which significantly reduces the complexity of the quantum processor control system
column5: said Ilya Besedin.

column1: The obtained results reveal an interesting and promising approach toward fault-tolerant quantum computing with low-frequency qubits that can be a good alternative to the transmon system.
In the future
column2: scientists plan to continue research with computations based on fluxonium qubits
column3: optimizing the qubit control system
column4: improving readout rates and beginning to develop multi-qubit systems based on them.";3948;['ixhg9bs'

column1: 100;247;5bc1ffd228762a38db88ee2a503f11d78a1f4cdb834a1d8670e6f6a4dde215ab;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.engadget.com/ibm-wants-its-quantum-supercomputers-running-at-4000-plus-qubits-by-2025-110012129.html;['umhgq1'];['KingSash'];[1652185392.0];['IBM wants its quantum supercomputers running at 4
column2: 000-plus qubits by 2025'];[nan];2022-05-10;Andrew Tarantola;IBM wants its quantum supercomputers running at 4
column3: 000-plus qubits by 2025 | Engadget;"Forty years after it first began to dabble in quantum computing
column4: IBM is ready to expand the technology out of the lab and into more practical applications — like supercomputing! The company has already hit a number of development milestones since it released its previous quantum roadmap in 2020
column5: including the 127-qubit Eagle processor that uses quantum circuits and the Qiskit Runtime API. IBM announced on Wednesday that it plans to further scale its quantum ambitions and has revised the 2020 roadmap with an even loftier goal of operating a 4
column6: 000-qubit system by 2025.

column1: Before it sets about building the biggest quantum computer to date
column2: IBM plans release its 433-qubit Osprey chip later this year and migrate the Qiskit Runtime to the cloud in 2023
column3: “bringing a serverless approach into the core quantum software stack
column4: ” per Wednesday’s release. Those products will be followed later that year by Condor
column5: a quantum chip IBM is billing as “the world’s first universal quantum processor with over 1
column6: 000 qubits.”

column1: This rapid four-fold jump in quantum volume (the number of qubits packed into a processor) will enable users to run increasingly longer quantum circuits
column2: while increasing the processing speed — measured in CLOPS (circuit layer operations per second) — from a maximum of 2
column3: 900 OPS to over 10
column4: 000. Then it’s just a simple matter of quadrupaling that capacity in the span of less than 24 months.

column1: To do so
column2: IBM plans to first get sets of multiple processors to communicate with one another both in parallel and in series. This should help develop better error mitigation schemes and improve coordination between processors
column3: both necessary components of tomorrow’s practical quantum computers. After that
column4: IBM will design and deploy chip-level couplers
column5: which “will closely connect multiple chips together to effectively form a single and larger processor
column6: ” according to the company
column7: then build quantum communication links to connect those larger multi-processors together into even bigger clusters — essentially daisy-chaining increasingly larger clumps of processors together until they form a functional

column1: “As quantum computing matures
column2: we’re starting to see ourselves as more than quantum hardware
column3: ” IBM researcher Jay Gambetta wrote on Wednesday. “We’re building the next generation of computing. In order to benefit from our world-leading hardware
column4: we need to develop the software and infrastructure capable of taking advantage of it.”

column1: As such
column2: IBM released a set of ready-made primitive programs earlier this year
column3: “pre-built programs that allows developers easy access to the outputs of quantum computations without requiring intricate understanding of the hardware
column4: ” per the company. IBM intends to expand that program set in 2023
column5: enabling developers to run them on parallelized quantum processors. “We also plan to enhance primitive performance with low-level compilation and post-processing methods
column6: like introducing error suppression and mitigation tools
column7: ” Gambetta said. “These advanced primitives will allow algorithm developers to use Qiskit Runtime services as an API for incorporating quantum circuits and classical routines to build quantum workflows.”

column1: These workflows will take a given problem
column2: break it down into smaller quantum and classical programs
column3: chew through those processes in either parallel or series depending on which is more efficient
column4: and then use an orchestration layer to “circuit stitch” all those various data streams back into a coherent result that classical computers can understand. IBM calls its proprietary stitching infrastructure Quantum Serverless and
column5: per the new roadmap
column6: will deploy the feature to its core quantum software stack in 2023.

column1: “We think by next year
column2: we’ll begin prototyping quantum software applications for users hoping to use Qiskit Runtime and Quantum Serverless to address specific use cases
column3: ” Gambetta said. We’ll begin to define these services with our first test case — machine learning — working with partners to accelerate the path toward useful quantum software applications. By 2025
column4: we think model developers will be able to explore quantum applications in machine learning
column5: optimization
column6: finance

column1: “For many years
column2: CPU-centric supercomputers were society’s processing workhorse
column3: with IBM serving as a key developer of these systems
column4: ” he continued. “In the last few years
column5: we’ve seen the emergence of AI-centric supercomputers
column6: where CPUs and GPUs work together in giant systems to tackle AI-heavy workloads. Now
column7: IBM is ushering in the age of the quantum-centric supercomputer
column8: where quantum resources — QPUs — will be woven together with CPUs and GPUs into a compute fabric. We think that the quantum-centric supercomputer will serve as an essential technology for those solving the toughest problems
column9: those doing the most ground-breaking research
column10: and those developing the most cutting-edge technology.”

column1: Together
column2: these hardware and software systems will become IBM Quantum System Two with the first prototype scheduled to be operational at some point next year.";5120;['i81jgpq'

column1: 101;564;aadb1f281f6e55b296321264cc37677a39e867259d257e3a4c75a99fc9e2e4a4;posted_link;r/science;https://news.griffith.edu.au/2020/08/18/new-quantum-paradox-reveals-contradiction-between-widely-held-beliefs/;['ijeucg'];['rustoo'];[1598802604.0];['Quantum physicists have unveiled a new paradox that says
column2: when it comes to certain long-held beliefs about nature
column3: “something’s gotta give”. The paradox means that if quantum theory works to describe observers
column4: scientists would have to give up one of three cherished assumptions about the world.'];[nan];2020-08-18;Contributed;New quantum paradox reveals contradiction between widely-held beliefs;"Quantum physicists at Griffith University have unveiled a new paradox that says
column5: when it comes to certain long-held beliefs about nature
column6: “something’s gotta give”.

column1: Quantum theory is practically perfect at predicting the behaviour we observe when we perform experiments on tiny objects like atoms. But applying quantum theory at scales much larger than atoms
column2: in particular to observers who make the measurements
column3: raises difficult conceptual issues.

column1: In a paper published in Nature Physics
column2: an international team led from Griffith University in Australia has sharpened those issues into a new paradox.

column1: “The paradox means that if quantum theory works to describe observers
column2: scientists would have to give up one of three cherished assumptions about the world
column3: ” said Associate Professor Eric Cavalcanti
column4: a senior theory author on the paper.

column1: “The first assumption is that when a measurement is made
column2: the observed outcome is a real
column3: single event in the world. This assumption rules out
column4: for example
column5: the idea that the universe can split
column6: with different outcomes being observed in different parallel universes.”

column1: “The second assumption is that experimental settings can be freely chosen
column2: allowing us to perform randomised trials. And the third assumption is that once such a free choice is made
column3: its influence cannot spread out into the universe faster than light
column4: ” he said.

column1: “Each of these fundamental assumptions seems entirely reasonable
column2: and is widely believed. However
column3: it is also widely believed that quantum experiments can be scaled up to larger systems
column4: even to the level of observers. But we show that one of these widely held beliefs must be wrong! Giving up any one of them has far-reaching consequences for our understanding of the world.”

column1: The team has established the paradox by analysing a scenario with well-separated entangled quantum particles combined with a quantum ‘observer’ – a quantum system which can be manipulated and measured from the outside
column2: but which can itself make measurements on a quantum particle.

column1: “Based on the three fundamental assumptions
column2: we have mathematically determined limits on what experimental results are possible in this scenario. But quantum theory
column3: when applied to observers
column4: predicts results which violate these limits. In fact
column5: we have already performed a proof-of-principle experiment using entangled photons (particles of light)
column6: ” said Dr Nora Tischler
column7: a senior experimental author. “And we found a violation just as quantum theory predicted.”

column1: “But our ‘observer’ had a very small ‘brain’
column2: so to speak. It has just two memory states
column3: which are realised as two different paths for a photon. That’s why we call it a proof-of-principle experiment
column4: not a conclusive demonstration that one of the three fundamental assumptions in our paradox must be wrong
column5: ” she said.

column1: “For a more definitive implementation of the paradox
column2: our dream experiment is one where the quantum observer is a human-level artificial intelligence program running on a massive quantum computer
column3: ” said Professor Howard Wiseman
column4: the leader of the project and Director of Griffith’s Centre for Quantum Dynamics
column5: where the theoretical and experimental teams are based.

column1: “That would be a pretty convincing test of whether quantum theory fails for observers
column2: or whether one of the three fundamental assumptions is false. But that’s probably decades away.”

column1: The Centre for Quantum Dynamics laboratory in which the experiment was performed is also part of the Centre for Quantum Computation and Communication Technology
column2: an Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence.

column1: “It has long been recognised that quantum computers will revolutionise our ability to solve hard computational problems
column2: ” Professor Wiseman said.

column1: “What we didn’t realise until we started this research is that they may also help answer hard philosophical problems – the nature of the physical world
column2: the mental world
column3: and their relationship.”";3916;['g3delmw'

column1: 102;969;bf6a3f9f89db6856533071a8847047c64a0c9b42ab2de3ce220e399c4b9da886;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://scitechdaily.com/sustained-high-fidelity-quantum-teleportation-achieved-for-the-first-time/;['kg2fcm'];['Sorin61'];[1608357476.0];['Sustained
column2: High-Fidelity Quantum Teleportation Achieved for the First Time'];[nan];2020-12-18;Mike O'Neill;Sustained
column3: High-Fidelity Quantum Teleportation Achieved for the First Time;"A viable quantum internet — a network in which information stored in qubits is shared over long distances through entanglement — would transform the fields of data storage
column4: precision sensing and computing
column5: ushering in a new era of communication.

column1: This month
column2: scientists at Fermilab
column3: a U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science national laboratory
column4: and their partners took a significant step in the direction of realizing a quantum internet.

column1: In a paper published in PRX Quantum
column2: the team presents for the first time a demonstration of a sustained
column3: long-distance (44 kilometers of fiber) teleportation of qubits of photons (quanta of light) with fidelity greater than 90%. The qubits were teleported over a fiber-optic network using state-of-the-art single-photon detectors and off-the-shelf equipment.

column1: “We’re thrilled by these results
column2: ” said Fermilab scientist Panagiotis Spentzouris
column3: head of the Fermilab quantum science program and one of the paper’s co-authors. “This is a key achievement on the way to building a technology that will redefine how we conduct global communication.”

column1: Quantum teleportation is a “disembodied” transfer of quantum states from one location to another. The quantum teleportation of a qubit is achieved using quantum entanglement
column2: in which two or more particles are inextricably linked to each other. If an entangled pair of particles is shared between two separate locations
column3: no matter the distance between them
column4: the encoded information is teleported.

column1: The joint team — researchers at Fermilab
column2: AT&T
column3: Caltech
column4: Harvard University
column5: NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory and University of Calgary — successfully teleported qubits on two systems: the Caltech Quantum Network
column6: or CQNET
column8: or FQNET. The systems were designed
column10: commissioned and deployed by Caltech’s public-private research program on Intelligent Quantum Networks and Technologies

column1: “We are very proud to have achieved this milestone on sustainable
column2: high-performing and scalable quantum teleportation systems
column3: ” said Maria Spiropulu
column4: Shang-Yi Ch’en professor of physics at Caltech and director of the IN-Q-NET research program. “The results will be further improved with system upgrades we are expecting to complete by Q2 2021.”

column1: CQNET and FQNET
column2: which feature near-autonomous data processing
column3: are compatible both with existing telecommunication infrastructure and with emerging quantum processing and storage devices. Researchers are using them to improve the fidelity and rate of entanglement distribution
column4: with an emphasis on complex quantum communication protocols and fundamental science.

column1: The achievement comes just a few months after the U.S. Department of Energy unveiled its blueprint for a national quantum internet at a press conference in Chicago.
“With this demonstration we’re beginning to lay the foundation for the construction of a Chicago-area metropolitan quantum network
column2: ” Spentzouris said. The Chicagoland network
column3: called the Illinois Express Quantum Network
column4: is being designed by Fermilab in collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory
column5: Caltech
column6: Northwestern University and industry partners.

column1: This research was supported by DOE’s Office of Science through the Quantum Information Science-Enabled Discovery (QuantISED) program.
“The feat is a testament to success of collaboration across disciplines and institutions
column2: which drives so much of what we accomplish in science
column3: ” said Fermilab Deputy Director of Research Joe Lykken. “I commend the IN-Q-NET team and our partners in academia and industry on this first-of-its-kind achievement in quantum teleportation.”";3617;['ggcb1h9'
