column1: 103;6;b7d51cbde40c66a71609a3010ab85ddf373a1089402da7d3fa50a956b510d20f;posted_link;r/science;http://arstechnica.com/science/2012/12/quantum-networks-may-be-more-realistic-than-we-thought/;['14ubs8'];['Boris740'];[1355493316.0];['Quantum networks may be more realistic than we thought'];[nan];2012-12-13;Chris Lee;Quantum networks may be more realistic than we thought;"The quantum Internet is a term that has been bandied about a lot recently. And
column2: for the moment it is utter nonsense. The Internet connects computers
column3: so the quantum Internet pre-supposes the existence of useful quantum computers. The Internet also involves arbitrary on-the-fly routing through many intermediate stations
column4: while current quantum communications protocols rely on point-to-point connections. I can't think of anything less Internet-like than that.

column1: The nice thing about buzzwords
column2: though
column3: is that some people take them seriously while also recognizing the problems inherent to the idea. That leads to some fantastic research. A group of Japanese and British researchers have come up with a communications protocol that overcomes many of the fundamental problems associated with transferring quantum information over long distances. We still don't have a quantum computer
column4: but when we do
column5: these guys know how to connect them up.

column1: Quantum static on your phone line
The issue boils down to the very nature of the quantum state. Usually
column2: when we consider a quantum bit (qubits) of information
column3: we are talking about a single photon. In any optical fiber
column4: there is a certain probability the photon will be absorbed
column5: which increases exponentially with distance. Generally
column6: this limits point-to-point quantum data transfer to distances under 100km.

column1: To expand that range
column2: you need to entangle qubits at distant locations. The idea is that you send photon pairs over short distances and entangle them with neighboring photon pairs. That entangles the two most distance photons with each other. This can be repeated
column3: transferring entanglement over large distances.

column1: The process of entangling two photons is
column2: however
column3: not always successful. So
column4: in a chain of photon pair sources
column5: you might manage half the links on the first attempt. These should be stored in a memory
column6: while the other half tries again. After several repetitions
column7: the end-points are entangled with each other. Unfortunately
column8: this requires a long-lasting quantum memory that can store a lot of different photons. This way
column9: the right photon can be used once the entire entangled chain is established. Such a memory doesn't exist yet.

column1: Quantum entanglement
Quantum entanglement is one of the most misused concepts around. Entanglement is delicate
column2: rare
column3: and short-lived. At its heart
column4: quantum entanglement is nothing more or less than a correlation between two apparently separate quantum objects. Having discovered that
column5: you might ask ""so what is all the fuss about?"" The answer lies deep in quantum mechanics.Read more…

column1: Spreading your bets on photon survival

This would all be so much easier if the quantum state was stored across multiple photons. This is what a team of Japanese and British researchers have been considering. Drawing on early results from optical quantum computing schemes
column2: they realized the error correcting mechanisms proposed for those systems could be used to extend the distance over which a quantum state could be transported.

column1: Their scheme relies on the fact that no one really wants to send a single qubit
column2: instead we want to send lots. These individual qubits can then be blocked together to make one larger quantum state that is the superposition of the individual quantum states. In addition
column3: we add more qubits whose values are determined by the results of mathematical operations on the data qubits. When we do this
column4: a tiny bit of each qubit's state is held by several of the photons within the block
column5: creating lots of redundancy.

column1: Now
column2: it turns out that on the receiving end
column3: one can retrieve the entire quantum state of the data block provided a couple of conditions are met. At least one logical qubit within the block must make it through without loss. And
column4: for each logical qubit
column5: one physical qubit (a photon) survives.

column1: So
column2: if you have a block of a thousand photons—encoding 10 logical qubits in 10 photons with the remaining 990 photons being redundant—we require that one of those 10 photons makes it through cleanly. We also require the remaining photons that make it through contain information about the state of all the remaining qubits. If that occurs
column3: you can retrieve the other 10 from the built-in redundancy.

column1: The downside is
column2: of course
column3: that it takes many more physical qubits to encode a single logical qubit
column4: so you might think that the data rate will be rather low. Not so fast
column5: say the researchers. Information can be encoded on many different quantum states of the qubit
column6: so one qubit could be stored in a superposition of polarization states
column7: while another could be stored in phase
column8: and another in spatial mode profiles
column9: etc. (The nature of these states are unimportant save that we can play with one and not change the other.)

column1: Quantum superposition
Superposition is nothing more than addition for waves. Let's say we have two sets of waves that overlap in space and time. At any given point
column2: a trough may line up with a peak
column3: their peaks may line up
column4: or anything in between. Superposition tells us how to add up these waves so that the result reconstructs the patterns that we observe in nature.Read more…

column1: Those of you paying attention will be questioning this assumption though. Imagine in our previous example that we store three logical qubit states in a single photon. Well
column2: if that photon is absorbed
column3: we have lost three different qubits. Now
column4: our encoding scheme relies on one logical qubit making it through in its entirety. Naively
column5: we might think that this would reduce the chances of this occurring by a factor of three
column6: which would be disastrous.

column1: Luckily
column2: the researchers are not as naive as me
column3: and they have an answer. The encoding system works by blocking data and encoding it together into a single giant quantum state. The trick is to make sure the different quantum states of the same photon are used to encode qubits from different blocks of data. This way
column4: the loss of a photon still results in losing three qubits
column5: but they are from different blocks
column6: making them the equivalent of losing three independent photons.

column1: But wait
column2: it's a router too

column1: The big advantage
column2: though
column3: is this scheme also allows something that looks like quantum routing. The basic process is that the photonic qubits are generated from matter qubits at one end and stored into matter qubits at a node. The storage process involves the emission of photons that can be used to determine the channel losses and appropriately decode the actual quantum data from the block. But
column4: unlike point-to-point schemes
column5: the decoding process doesn't involve measuring the quantum state
column6: it only involves picking the right bits and performing operations on them. This is important
column7: because a measurement would destroy the quantum state. Since the quantum state is preserved
column8: it can be re-encoded in a new block and sent on to a new node.

column1: One can then imagine blocks are chunked into super-blocks with the first block containing routing information
column2: and the remaining blocks being data. The first block could be entirely classical and contain routing information
column3: or it could be stored in qubits
column4: which are read at a node (destroying the quantum nature of the state)
column5: and then re-encoded in new qubits. Either way would work.

column1: Where do I order my quantum router?
All through reading this paper
column2: I had my doubts. But it really is a solid bit of work. It is also
column3: I think
column4: going to be regarded as a key paper should quantum networks become ubiquitous and significant. Implementation
column5: though
column6: is going to be challenging. This is because the number of qubits per photon and the number of photons per qubit scale very fast. For instance
column7: if we limit ourselves to losses of 50 percent—that is
column8: the link destroys 50 percent of the photons sent to the receiver—and only store a single logical qubit per photon
column9: then we require over 7000 photons (physical qubits) to transmit 10 logical qubits.

column1: If we go the more complicated route and store multiple qubits per photon
column2: then things get better: only 75 photons are required to transmit 15 photons. But
column3: that assumes that 15 qubits are encoded on each photon
column4: so
column5: we actually need to send a minimum of 15 blocks of data
column6: adding up to 1125 photons for 225 logical qubits.

column1: Why do I care about these numbers? Well
column2: that means we require 1125 matter qubits that can be set to the right value and retained until they are transferred to a photon. Furthermore
column3: we require that each photon acquires 15 different qubits. To do that successfully 98 percent of the time
column4: it will involve an encoding operation that works 99.8 percent of the time. At the moment
column5: these operations have probabilities that are much lower
column6: effectively limiting experiments to a couple of logical qubits per photon.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: these experimental difficulties are well-known and understood. Over time
column3: the situation will improve and in a few years (less than 10)
column4: we will see encoding schemes similar to this that can encode more qubits per photon. The quantum Internet may yet lie ready
column5: awaiting the arrival of a quantum computer.";9025;['c7ghtqt'
column6: 'c7gi42s'

column1: 104;92;0a9f941a476c58fc469bf97cd70f942f7ef868e1607e5e6f53402f644c2879f7;posted_link;r/gadgets;http://m.bbc.com/news/science-environment-27264552;['2aislr'];['itspclar'];[1405185750.0];['Canadian company develops first commercially available Quantum Computer.'];[nan];2014-05-19;Paul Rincon;D-Wave: Is $15m machine a glimpse of future computing?;"A Canadian firm has courted controversy with its claim to have built a practical quantum computer
column2: a feat thought to be decades away. Now
column3: independent researchers are trying to understand whether it really can tap the strange world of quantum physics.

column1: For the modest sum of $15m (£9m)
column2: a start-up near Vancouver will sell you a black box the size of a garden shed with its logo emblazoned on the side in white neon.

column1: Not sold yet?
What if I told you the contents of the box were kept colder than the temperature of interstellar space?
You still need some convincing - I get it.
How about this: The box contains a machine that can solve some of the thorniest mathematical problems and could revolutionise computing.
The Canadian start-up in question is called D-Wave and their monolithic machine is - they claim - nothing less than a real
column2: working quantum computer. But not everyone is convinced.

column1: Quantum computing exploits the weird physics that takes hold at tiny (atomic or sub-atomic) scales. Computers that tap the quantum realm could carry out complex calculations much faster than their conventional - or classical - counterparts.
While the basic units of information in classical computers are called ""bits"" and are stored as a string of 1s and 0s
column2: their equivalents in a quantum system - qubits - can be both 1s and 0s at the same time.

column1: This phenomenon would enable multiple calculations to be performed simultaneously. But the qubits need to be synchronised using a quantum effect known as entanglement
column2: which Albert Einstein termed ""spooky action at a distance"".

column1: Scientists have struggled to entangle more than a handful of qubits
column2: and to maintain them in their quantum state. Lab devices suffer from drop-out
column3: where the qubits lose their ambiguity and become straightforward 1s and 0s. This has ensured that quantum computers remain confined to the lab - proofs of principle capable of solving only elementary problems.

column1: The original vision of the company was simple: build a commercially useful quantum computer as soon as possible
column2: Vern Brownell
column3: D-Wave's chief executive
column4: tells me.

column1: We just want to provide quantum computing resources to researchers and businesses around the world so they can solve really hard problems
column2: better than they can today.""

column1: So when
column3: D-Wave staged a demonstration of a quantum processor called Orion that could solve Sudoku puzzles and search a public database of drugs to find the closest match to a specific molecule - both impressive achievements in this field - it was greeted with deep scepticism.

column1: Four years later
column2: the company unveiled the ""first commercially available quantum computer""
column3: a 128-qubit machine called the D-Wave One
column4: and this time its claims weren't so easily dismissed. The announcement coincided with the publication of a study supporting the machine's quantum credentials in Nature
column5: one of the most prestigious peer-reviewed journals in the world.

column1: This tempered some of the criticism
column2: but fell short of winning over vocal sceptics like Scott Aaronson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). He thinks the firm's computers show ""pretty good"" evidence for entanglement at a local level
column3: though not necessarily on a large scale. But he sees no evidence that this is helping boost the performance of D-Wave's machines.

column1: Prof Aaronson told BBC News: ""The questions about 'the explanation for the speedup' haven't even been activated yet
column2: since so far there's no speedup to explain!""

column1: Mr Brownell comments: ""What I think is really interesting is that scientists and researchers are no longer arguing about whether it works
column2: it's how fast does it work? What's the scalability going to be?""

column1: The company's first commercial machine was followed in 2013 by the D-Wave Two
column2: powered by a 512-qubit chip called Vesuvius. Like its predecessor
column3: this computer is not for conventional use
column4: but was designed for solving optimisation problems
column5: a particular class of mathematical challenge that entails finding the best solution from all the possible solutions.

column1: Lockheed is using its D-Wave computer - housed at the University of Southern California - to verify and validate flight software. Google's machine
column2: which is shared with Nasa at the space agency's Ames Research Center
column3: is being used for machine learning
column4: a branch of artificial intelligence with applications in areas as diverse as voice recognition and detecting credit card fraud.

column1: The big name buy-in has generated serious buzz
column2: but sceptics have not been swayed.

column1: I don't care if the Messiah has come to Earth on a flaming chariot
column2: not to usher in an age of peace but simply to spend $10m on D-Wave's new Vesuvius chip
column3: Scott Aaronson wrote on his blog
column4: adding that the considered opinion of an academic expert of his choice ""would mean more to me than 500
column5: 000 business deals"".

column1: D-Wave was founded in 1999 as a University of British Columbia spin-out by Rose - who holds a PhD in physics and a light-heavyweight world title in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu - and his academic mentor Haig Farris.
The team spent about five years
column2: with collaborators in various kinds of academic environments
column3: coming to a view on the fastest way to come to market with something useful
column4: says Mr Brownell.

column1: The so-called gate model underpins the vast majority of academic research into quantum computing. This idea is based on developing the quantum equivalents of the logic gates that form the building blocks of circuits in classical computing.
But D-Wave settled on an approach called quantum annealing. Outlined in a seminal 2000 paper by Eddie Farhi of MIT
column2: and others
column3: this technique is fundamentally different to the theory of quantum gates.

column1: In Rose's chosen martial art of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu
column2: opponents start off on their feet and typically end up grappling on the mat. The aim in quantum annealing is also to reach the ""ground state"" - in this case
column3: the lowest energy point.

column1: One common analogy is that of a cross-section through a mountain range. The altitude of the landscape describes the energy
column2: or cost
column3: of the solution. The aim is to find the lowest point on the map and read the coordinates
column4: as this gives the lowest energy
column5: or ""best""
column6: solution to the problem.

column1: The way you would do it in classical computing is to walk up and down the valleys and hills until you've found it
column2: said Prof Alan Woodward
column3: a computing expert from the University of Surrey.

column1: What the quantum annealing process does for you is effectively to tunnel through the mountain... until it announces: 'The lowest point I found was X'.""
It shortcuts everything
column2: and that's how it speeds up.""

column1: Experts say quantum annealing can't offer the performance boost theoretically possible with gates
column2: but proponents of D-Wave's approach point to innate advantages
column3: such as greater robustness to the ""drop-out"" problem that plagues gate model quantum computing.

column1: Dr Rose has even branded quantum gates the ""single worst thing that ever happened to quantum computing"".
Whatever the route taken
column2: efforts to build a quantum computer must overcome daunting engineering hurdles. The circuits in D-Wave's processors are superconducting
column3: which means they have zero electrical resistance and generate no heat. In order to get quantum effects
column4: liquid helium is used to cool the chip to 0.02 Kelvin
column5: a shade above the temperature known as absolute zero.

column1: The whole system is enclosed in a so-called Faraday Cage
column2: which blocks external electrical fields that could interfere with quantum mechanical behaviour.

column1: Prof Andrew Steane
column2: from the department of physics at Oxford University
column3: says: ""If you go back five or 10 years
column4: the initial statements coming out of D-Wave - before they had a device to look at - were seen as something you could ignore
column5: because it just didn't seem credible.

column1: Then they produced this device
column2: so they came up with the goods. And it's a non-negligible device - it has serious computing power. It's just a question of whether what it's achieving is beyond what could have been done with a system based on classical physics.""

column1: Significant academic effort is now being thrown at this question. Last year saw the publication of several scientific studies favourable to the company's case
column2: including indirect evidence for entanglement of qubits and research by Catherine McGeoch
column3: a professor of computer science at Amherst College
column4: that found the system performed 3
column5: 600 times faster on some tests than did a standard desktop machine.

column1: But in January 2014
column2: a team led by Matthias Troyer
column3: of ETH Zurich in Switzerland
column4: published results of its benchmarking of Lockheed's unit. Team members won't comment publicly until the work is published in a peer-reviewed journal
column5: but in some tests devised by them
column6: the D-Wave machine was found to perform no faster than a classical computer.

column1: However
column2: company executives counter that the tests used were not the sort where the quantum computer offers any advantage over conventional types.

column1: Then in February
column2: a team led by Prof Umesh Vazirani
column3: of the University of California
column4: Berkeley
column5: published a study concluding that a simple
column6: classical computing model of interacting magnets could explain behaviour in D-Wave's machines.

column1: At a high level
column2: we know what the machine is doing: namely
column3: it's doing annealing to the ground state
column4: with superconducting Josephson junctions (paired superconductors) at 20mK (milliKelvin) temperature
column5: in a way that's 'mostly classical' but that has some quantum effects present
column6: at least at the local level

column1: I think this research has actually reached some pretty firm conclusions: most importantly
column2: that the current device is not getting a speedup on the problem distributions currently being tried
column3: he explains.

column1: Andrew Steane says the computers show promise
column2: but on the question of whether they are exploiting quantum effects for performance gains he says the studies by Troyer and Vazirani ""suggest they can't yet really make that claim"".

column1: Mr Brownell comments: ""How many trillions have been invested in classical computing? How many innovations and iterations of hardware since John Von Neumann and the Bletchley Park folks?
How much algorithm work and research around software and applications and compilers and efficiency? We've come up with something in 10 years that performs just as well
column2: and maybe outperforms in some narrow cases that entire ecosystem.""

column1: Geordie Rose told BBC News: ""Scepticism implies a healthy and unbiased doubt about new technological capabilities or scientific advancements. Much of that has gone away as we've continued to advance our technology so far beyond what anyone else has done.""
The negativity against pioneering companies though comes from small but vocal groups concerned about losing access to funding
column2: and from commercial competitors. I believe the former will go away once these folks realise that our success means more money for their basic science
column3: not less.""

column1: D-Wave's next chip
column2: consisting of 1
column3: 024-qubits
column4: is currently undergoing calibration ahead of its planned release later this year. In addition to its aforementioned customers
column5: D-Wave has others it won't name. The firm is now looking to expand into other potentially lucrative markets.

column1: As we get some more internal resources to support customers adequately
column2: we would like to branch out into other areas like bioinformatics
column3: energy exploration
column4: finance
column5: says Vern Brownell. ""We know already there are huge applications in each of these areas for quantum computing.""

column1: Documents leaked by Edward Snowden reveal that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has been conducting ""basic research"" to determine whether it was possible to build a quantum computer that would be useful for cracking encrypted communications.
But D-Wave's quantum annealing approach isn't well suited to this application. Cryptanalysis is an area where researchers seem to agree that the logic gate model offers more promise.
Of the company's efforts
column2: Alan Woodward says: ""The engineering difficulties [of building quantum computers] are enormous
column3: because of susceptibilities to interactions from the environment and so on. What Geordie said was - let's build what we can
column4: instead of always thinking about things that are out of reach. And you've got to admire that.

column1: I suspect it's something that's helping to move on the state-of-the-art from an engineering perspective
column2: even if it turns out not to be the ultimate shape of things to come.""

column1: Andrew Steane comments: ""I'm gently pleased by their boldness
column2: to have a go and make the thing.

column1: It's a bit like 'Make it and they will come'. They haven't quite got to 'they will come'. But they've made something.""";12601;['civq6zx'

column1: 105;297;5ffd6dc1aba43e9b6f6d958fe511d036bf25c619fc9e6577413f656f7e925fea;posted_link;r/technology;http://futurism.com/links/19279/;['3wd3u3'];['yattaah'];[1449833108.0];['Google Says its Quantum Computer Works
column2: Is 100 Million Times Faster Than Traditional PC'];[nan];2015-09-12;Jappy Lim;Google Says its Quantum Computer Works
column3: Is 100 Million Times Faster Than Traditional PC;"The Breakthrough

column1: Google claims that a controversial computer it purchased in 2013 is capable of using quantum physics to solve math much faster than regular computers. They note that the type of math it solves is crucial to the development of artificial intelligence (AI).
Companies such as Microsoft
column2: IBM
column3: and Google (as well as several governments) have been trying to develop quantum computers which use quantum mechanics to handle data. It is believed that quantum computers can make AI computers much more powerful. NASA has high hopes for the technology
column4: as well. “It is a truly disruptive technology that could change how we do everything
column5: ” said Deepak Biswas
column6: director of exploration technology at NASA’s Ames Research Center in Mountain View

column1: Google bought the machine from Canadian startup D-Wave systems and is marketed as “the world’s first commercial quantum computer.” The computer is located at NASA’s Ames Research Center in Mountain View
column2: California
column3: and uses a superconducting chip called a quantum annealer
column4: which is hard-coded with an algorithm suited to dealing with “optimization problems.”

column1: D-Wave’s chips are controversial among quantum physicists
column2: mainly because no one has been able to conclusively prove that the devices can tap into quantum physics to beat out conventional computers. But Hartmut Neven
column3: leader of Google’s Quantum AI Lab in Los Angeles
column4: claims that his team of researchers now have that proof.

column1: They had the D-Wave computer race against a conventional model with a single processor. “For a specific
column2: carefully crafted proof-of-concept problem we achieve a 100-million-fold speed-up
column3: ” said Neven.

column1: The Implications
Quantum hardware that would not be limited to optimization problems is also being explored. This so-called ""universal quantum computer"" could take on any problem. It will
column2: however
column3: be some time before such a computer has been perfected.

column1: John Giannandrea
column2: VP of engineering at Google
column3: said that quantum annealers could find many uses powering up Google’s machine-learning software if only they were more practical. “We’ve already encountered problems in the course of our products impractical to solve with existing computers
column4: and we have a lot of computers
column5: ” he said. However
column6: Giannandrea added
column7: “it may be several years before this research makes a difference to Google products.”";2356;['cxv96pg'

column1: 106;800;d4266d0f1f1a7e73b80cbb33dc86c1256f76882d9a6ec1e295970f756850dedc;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/engineering/extreme-machines/two-big-steps-toward-the-quantum-computer-16682595??src=rss;['22p527'];['Libertatea'];[1397142672.0];"[""Two Big Steps Toward the Quantum Computer: Two research teams
column2: at Harvard University and the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics in Germany
column3: have just announced that they have independently forged the building blocks for tomorrow's quantum computers. As they published today in the journal Nature""]";[nan];2014-04-10;William Herkewitz;Two Big Steps Toward the Quantum Computer;"It's a machine that could calculate solutions to problems so impossibly time-consuming that even the most powerful supercomputers could never handle them. And it would do so in an instant. This is the quantum computer
column4: made possible by the bizarre nature of quantum mechanics. And though the idea is still in its infancy
column5: it's no fantasy.

column1: Two research teams
column2: at Harvard University and the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics in Germany
column3: have just announced that they have independently forged the building blocks for tomorrow's quantum computers. As they published today in the journal Nature (1
column5: the scientists discovered a way to hook up atoms and particles of light to create a new type of switch and logic-gate‚ quantum versions of the connecting structures that link bits of data in modern computers.

column1: Quantum Computers
When you dive down into the circuits
column2: all modern computers are basically the same: a huge collection of data arranged with simple rules. Each piece of data is called a bit and shows just one fragment of information‚ a 0 or a 1. You can think of a bit as a lightbulb that's either shining or not.

column1: But quantum theory‚ the physics that rules the tiny world of atoms and particles‚ tells us that there are certain circumstances in which a piece of matter can be two things at the same time. It's possible to have an atom that's spinning in two opposite directions at once
column2: or even to have your lightbulb both shining and not shining. Items with this wacky dual state are said to be in ""superposition."" (Physicist Niels Bohr once said
column3: ""Those who are not shocked when they first come across quantum theory cannot possibly have understood it."" So don't worry if you're confused‚ Bohr was one of the founders of quantum theory.)

column1: The most important catch (there are plenty) is that this superposition state is fragile and possible only for incredibly tiny bits of matter.
But for computers
column2: this very idea poses an interesting prospect. If you could somehow harness this odd state of matter to put individual bits of information into superposition
column3: then suddenly you've packed more data into the tiniest package possible. Your bits can now show a 0
column4: a 1
column5: or a combo of both. This is called a quantum bit
column6: or a qubit. And if qubits were linked together like normal bits are linked in a computer
column7: then you'd have a machine could calculate at insane speeds.

column1: At this point
column2: very small-scale quantum computers already exist
column3: says Mikhail Lukin
column4: the head of the Harvard research team. ""We're able to link
column5: roughly
column6: up to a dozen qubits together. But a major challenge facing this community is scaling these systems up to include more and more qubits.""

column1: The problem of adding more qubits
column2: Lukin explains
column3: is tied to the fragility of the superposition state. Unless the entire quantum computer is kept at extremely cold temperatures and free of any interfering particles or other noise
column4: the superposition state will entirely collapse for all the qubits
column5: ruining the computer. What makes this even harder is that today's qubits must be close to one another to be connected
column6: and it takes a massive apparatus of machinery
column8: and lasers to support the superposition state of just a single fleck of matter. That dumps an increasing amount of grit into the system
column9: increasing the chance that the entire quantum computer will fail.

column1: It's just very difficult to address one qubit without interfering with all the rest of them; to take a laser beam and shine it one particular qubit and not another
column2: says Gerhard Rempe
column3: the head of the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics research team. ""And if
column4: for example
column5: you want to use 10
column6: 000 qubits
column9: 000 lasers you have to worry about.""

column1: The Ol' Gate and Switch
The new quantum logic gate and switch unveiled today promise to ameliorate some of these problems. Both use a new method: They harness trapped atoms (in both cases
column2: rubidium) that can transfer information through photons
column3: the particles that make up light. Photons
column4: which can be directed through fiber-optic cable
column5: are the prime candidate for sending information at great distances and keeping qubits apart.

column1: Here is how it works: The scientists trap a heavy rubidium atom between two mirror-like sheets using a laser technique that keeps the atom relatively immobile. The scientists then send a photon straight at this atom sandwich. Normally
column2: the photon would hit the first mirror and bounce right back where it came from. But if the atom is put in a specific energetic state
column3: the photon will go straight through that first mirror
column4: hang out with the atom for a moment
column5: and then exit where it came from. As a going-away present
column6: the photon also has a slight change in polarization. This is pretty much how any switch in a computer works. If something is ""on
column7: then one thing happens. If it's ""off

column1: But here's the tricky part. The scientists can put the rubidium atom in superposition
column2: so that it is simultaneously in that energetic state and not in the energetic state. It's on and off. Because of this
column3: the photon both does and does not enter the mirror
column4: mingle
column5: and gain its polarization change. And the photon
column6: by virtue of having both changed and not changed
column7: carries that superposition information and can bring it to a different atom-based qubit.

column1: A similar process happens with the quantum logic gate. A normal logic gate is just a series of switches set up in a way that together
column2: they perform a logical operation when given multiple inputs. The German team created a quantum version by having multiple photons repeatedly bounce off the mirror-trapped and superpositioned rubidium atom. Then
column3: using another funky attribute of quantum physics called entanglement swapping
column4: the scientists made it so that the photons share the same information. These entangled photons can become the multiple inputs required for any logic gate.

column1: Even with this new advancement
column2: we're still a long way from building large-scale quantum computers
column3: with thousands of qubits linked together. ""We're not going to see quantum computers being built for the average American consumer in ten years
column4: or anything like that
column5: says Jeff Thompson
column6: a physicist with the Harvard research team.

column1: Rempe says that while this technology seems promising for solving the qubit-closeness issue
column2: neither team is actually attempting to link multiple qubits. And that endeavor will probably open up a new world of unknowns.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: ""It's exciting to see this [photon-based] technology is coming into its own
column3: says Jacob Taylor
column4: a physicist at the University of Maryland who was not involved with the projects. Whatever future difficulties arise
column5: he says
column6: scientists are learning valuable information about one of the most fundamental aspects of physics. Everything we know about quantum mechanics would lead us to believe that large-scale quantum computers should be theoretically possible. But even if ""you couldn't build a large-scale quantum computer
column9: too. That tells us that our theory of quantum mechanics might be breaking down somewhere
column10: that we still have much to learn.""";7152;['cgp4ajp'

column1: 107;803;4326dcdc37496ba3e721c53880540206f67c06167aa8d233b208c05474f7520e;posted_link;r/science;http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-05-quantum-limit.html;['h2duc'];['quadcem'];[1304356014.0];['Scientists succeeded for the first time in transferring quantum information encoded in a single photon onto a single atom '];[nan];2011-05-02;Max Planck Institute;Single atom stores quantum information;"A data memory can hardly be any smaller: researchers working with Gerhard Rempe at the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics in Garching have stored quantum information in a single atom. The researchers wrote the quantum state of single photons
column2: i.e. particles of light
column3: into a rubidium atom and read it out again after a certain storage time. This technique can be used in principle to design powerful quantum computers and to network them with each other across large distances.

column1: Quantum computers will one day be able to cope with computational tasks in no time where current computers would take years. They will take their enormous computing power from their ability to simultaneously process the diverse pieces of information which are stored in the quantum state of microscopic physical systems
column2: such as single atoms and photons. In order to be able to operate
column3: the quantum computers must exchange these pieces of information between their individual components. Photons are particularly suitable for this
column4: as no matter needs to be transported with them. Particles of matter however will be used for the information storage and processing. Researchers are therefore looking for methods whereby quantum information can be exchanged between photons and matter. Although this has already been done with ensembles of many thousands of atoms
column5: physicists at the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics in Garching have now proved that quantum information can also be exchanged between single atoms and photons in a controlled way.

column1: Using a single atom as a storage unit has several advantages - the extreme miniaturization being only one
column2: says Holger Specht from the Garching-based Max Planck Institute
column3: who was involved in the experiment. The stored information can be processed by direct manipulation on the atom
column4: which is important for the execution of logical operations in a quantum computer. ""In addition
column5: it offers the chance to check whether the quantum information stored in the photon has been successfully written into the atom without destroying the quantum state
column6: says Specht. It is thus possible to ascertain at an early stage that a computing process must be repeated because of a storage error.

column1: The fact that no one had succeeded until very recently in exchanging quantum information between photons and single atoms was because the interaction between the particles of light and the atoms is very weak. Atom and photon do not take much notice of each other
column2: as it were
column3: like two party guests who hardly talk to each other
column4: and can therefore exchange only a little information. The researchers in Garching have enhanced the interaction with a trick. They placed a rubidium atom between the mirrors of an optical resonator
column5: and then used very weak laser pulses to introduce single photons into the resonator. The mirrors of the resonator reflected the photons to and fro several times
column6: which strongly enhanced the interaction between photons and atom. Figuratively speaking
column7: the party guests thus meet more often and the chance that they talk to each other increases.

column1: The photons carried the quantum information in the form of their polarization. This can be left-handed (the direction of rotation of the electric field is anti-clockwise) or right-handed (clock-wise). The quantum state of the photon can contain both polarizations simultaneously as a so-called superposition state. In the interaction with the photon the rubidium atom is usually excited and then loses the excitation again by means of the probabilistic emission of a further photon. The Garching-based researchers did not want this to happen. On the contrary
column2: the absorption of the photon was to bring the rubidium atom into a definite
column3: stable quantum state. The researchers achieved this with the aid of a further laser beam
column4: the so-called control laser
column5: which they directed onto the rubidium atom at the same time as it interacted with the photon.

column1: The spin orientation of the atom contributes decisively to the stable quantum state generated by control laser and photon. Spin gives the atom a magnetic moment. The stable quantum state
column2: which the researchers use for the storage
column3: is thus determined by the orientation of the magnetic moment. The state is characterized by the fact that it reflects the photon's polarization state: the direction of the magnetic moment corresponds to the rotational direction of the photon's polarization
column4: a mixture of both rotational directions being stored by a corresponding mixture of the magnetic moments.

column1: This state is read out by the reverse process: irradiating the rubidium atom with the control laser again causes it to re-emit the photon which was originally incident. In the vast majority of cases
column2: the quantum information in the read-out photon agrees with the information originally stored
column3: as the physicists in Garching discovered. The quantity that describes this relationship
column4: the so-called fidelity
column5: was more than 90 percent. This is significantly higher than the 67 percent fidelity that can be achieved with classical methods
column6: i.e. those not based on quantum effects. The method developed in Garching is therefore a real quantum memory.

column1: The physicists measured the storage time
column2: i.e. the time the quantum information in the rubidium can be retained
column3: as around 180 microseconds. ""This is comparable with the storage times of all previous quantum memories based on ensembles of atoms
column4: says Stephan Ritter
column5: another researcher involved in the experiment. Nevertheless
column6: a significantly longer storage time is necessary for the method to be used in a quantum computer or a quantum network. There is also a further quality characteristic of the single-atom quantum memory from Garching which could be improved: the so-called efficiency. It is a measure of how many of the irradiated photons are stored and then read out again. This was just under 10 percent.

column1: The storage time is mainly limited by magnetic field fluctuations from the laboratory surroundings
column2: says Ritter. ""It can therefore be increased by storing the quantum information in quantum states of the atoms which are insensitive to magnetic fields."" The efficiency is limited by the fact that the atom does not sit still in the centre of the resonator
column3: but moves. This causes the strength of the interaction between atom and photon to decrease. The researchers can thus also improve the efficiency: by greater cooling of the atom
column4: i.e. by further reducing its kinetic energy.

column1: The researchers at the Max Planck Institute in Garching now want to work on these two improvements. ""If this is successful
column2: the prospects for the single-atom quantum memory would be excellent
column3: says Stephan Ritter. The interface between light and individual atoms would make it possible to network more atoms in a quantum computer with each other than would be possible without such an interface; a fact that would make such a computer more powerful. Moreover
column4: the exchange of photons would make it possible to quantum mechanically entangle atoms across large distances. The entanglement is a kind of quantum mechanical link between particles which is necessary to transport quantum information across large distances. The technique now being developed at the Max Planck Institute of Quantum Optics could some day thus become an essential component of a future ""quantum Internet"".";7348;['c1s2kh5'
column5: 'c1s4ld0'
column6: 'c1s69uc'

column1: 108;897;52e5e253ceed8b18e801a995cb2c37ddd3f422f0ba1340be083677cc77064b3a;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.sciencealert.com/scientists-achieve-transformational-breakthrough-in-scaling-up-quantum-computers;['lbixzh'];['izumi3682'];[1612340111.0];"['Scientists Achieve \'Transformational\' Breakthrough in Scaling Quantum Computers - Novel ""cryogenic computer chip"" can allow for thousands of qubits
column2: rather than just dozens']";[nan];2021-02-02;Peter Dockrill;Scientists Achieve 'Transformational' Breakthrough in Scaling Quantum Computers;"Scientists have developed a new kind of cryogenic computer chip capable of functioning at temperatures so cold
column3: it approaches the theoretical limit of absolute zero.

column1: This cryogenic system
column2: called Gooseberry
column3: lays the groundwork for what could be a revolution in quantum computing – enabling a new generation of machines to perform calculations with thousands of qubits or more
column4: whereas today's most advanced devices comprise only dozens.

column1: This small scale is partly because of limits to the physical architecture that control the qubits.""
That physical architecture is constrained because of the extreme conditions qubits need to perform quantum mechanical calculations.
Unlike the binary bits in traditional computers
column2: which take either a 0 or 1 value
column3: qubits occupy what is known as the quantum superposition – an undefined and unmeasured state that can effectively represent both 0 and 1 at the same time in the context of a larger mathematical operation.

column1: This esoteric principle of quantum mechanics means quantum computers can theoretically solve vastly complex mathematical problems that classic computers would never be able to answer (or take years trying).
Like with conventional technology
column2: though
column3: more is always better
column4: and to date
column5: researchers have been limited in how many qubits they've been able to successfully deploy into quantum systems.

column1: One of the reasons for that is qubits need extreme levels of cold to function (in addition to other controlled conditions)
column2: and the electrical wiring used in today's quantum computer systems inevitably output small but sufficient levels of heat that disrupt the thermal requirements.

column1: Scientists are looking into ways to get around that
column2: but many quantum innovations to date have depended on contriving bulky wiring rigs to keep temperatures stable for increasing qubit counts
column3: but that solution has its own limits.

column1: Current machines create a beautiful array of wires to control the signals; they look like an inverted gilded birds' nest or chandelier
column2: Reilly says.

column1: They're pretty
column2: but fundamentally impractical. It means we can't scale the machines up to perform useful calculations. There is a real input–output bottleneck.""

column1: The solution to that bottleneck could be Gooseberry: a cryogenic control chip that can operate at 'millikelvin' temperatures just a tiny fraction of a degree above absolute zero
column2: as described in a new study.

column1: That extreme thermal capacity means it can sit inside the super-cold refrigerated environment with the qubits
column2: interfacing with them and passing signals from the qubits to a secondary core that sits outside in another extremely cold tank
column3: immersed in liquid helium.

column1: In doing so
column2: it removes all the excess wiring and the surplus heat they generate
column3: meaning contemporary qubit bottlenecks in quantum computing could soon be a thing of the past.

column1: The chip is the most complex electronic system to operate at this temperature
column2: Reilly explained to Digital Trends.

column1: This is the first time a mixed-signal chip with 100
column2: 000 transistors has operated at 0.1 kelvin
column3: [the equivalent to] –459.49-degrees Fahrenheit
column4: or –273.05-degrees Celsius.""

column1: Ultimately
column2: the team expects their system could enable thousands of qubits to be controlled by the cryogenic chip – roughly a 20-fold increase in what's possible today. In the future
column3: the same sort of approach might enable quantum computers on a whole other level.

column1: Why not start thinking about billions of qubits?"" Reilly told the Australian Financial Review. ""The more qubits we can control
column2: the better.""

column1: While it may be some time before we see this cryogenic breakthrough put to practical use outside the lab
column2: there's no doubting we're looking at a big step forward in quantum computing
column3: experts say.

column1: This is going to be transformational in the next few years
column2: Andrew White
column3: the director of the ARC Centre of Excellence for Engineered Quantum Systems
column4: who wasn't involved with the study but oversees quantum research in Australia
column5: told ABC News.

column1: If everyone [developing quantum computers] isn't using this chip
column2: they will be using something inspired by it.""";4090;['glvghhy'

column1: 109;1183;3dcbf054c8e4e2b550d07f6fab0930e7ec23109555161fde9930d5ec4b1c9335;posted_link;r/tech;https://www.theverge.com/2019/10/23/20928294/google-quantum-supremacy-sycamore-computer-qubit-milestone;['dly2n8'];['mtimetraveller'];[1571831063.0];['Google confirms ‘quantum supremacy’ breakthrough'];[nan];2019-10-23;Jon Porter;Google confirms ‘quantum supremacy’ breakthrough;"Google has officially announced that it’s achieved quantum supremacy in a new article published in the scientific journal Nature. The announcement comes exactly one month after it initially leaked
column2: when Google’s paper was accidentally published early. Now
column3: however
column4: it’s official
column5: meaning the full details of the research are public
column6: and the broader scientific community can fully scrutinize what Google says it’s achieved.

column1: Google says that its 54-qubit Sycamore processor was able to perform a calculation in 200 seconds that would have taken the world’s most powerful supercomputer 10
column2: 000 years. That would mean the calculation
column3: which involved generated random numbers
column4: is essentially impossible on a traditional
column5: non-quantum computer.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: IBM
column3: the company that operates the supercomputer that Google claims to have beaten
column4: and a key quantum computer competitor
column5: is disputing Google’s claims. In a blog post published pre-emptively on Monday
column6: the company said that the same task could be performed on a classical system in just 2.5 days
column8: 000 years that Google is claiming. IBM says that Google “failed to fully account for plentiful disk storage” when estimating how long its traditional supercomputer would take to perform the calculation.

column1: Despite IBM’s attempts to downplay Google’s achievement
column2: many in the research community welcomed the news
column3: with scientists quoted by The New York Times likening Google’s breakthrough to the Wright brothers’ first plane flight in 1903. We may still be years away from having quantum computers that are useful for practical tasks
column4: but Google’s findings could finally have provided proof that such a future is possible in the first place.";1709;['f4uzexd'
column5: 'f4v29yc'
column6: 'f4w8wpf'

column1: 110;12;627e5c4ed66e2d000629812cffb2f121d5aa63b35098daba4d934b40436062c2;posted_link;r/tech;https://arstechnica.com/science/2022/06/quantum-computer-succeeds-where-a-classical-algorithm-fails/;['v9b372'];['Sariel007'];[1654877085.0];['Quantum computer succeeds where a classical algorithm fails. Quantum computers coupled with traditional machine learning show clear benefits.'];[nan];2022-06-09;John Timmer;Quantum computer succeeds where a classical algorithm fails;"People have performed many mathematical proofs to show that a quantum computer will vastly outperform traditional computers on a number of algorithms. But the quantum computers we have now are error-prone and don't have enough qubits to allow for error correction. The only demonstrations we've had involve quantum computing hardware evolving out of a random configuration and traditional computers failing to simulate their normal behavior. Useful calculations are an exercise for the future.

But a new paper from Google's quantum computing group has now moved beyond these sorts of demonstrations and used a quantum computer as part of a system that can help us understand quantum systems in general
column2: rather than the quantum computer. And they show that
column3: even on today's error-prone hardware
column4: the system can outperform classical computers on the same problem.

column1: Probing quantum systems
To understand what the new work involves
column2: it helps to step back and think about how we typically understand quantum systems. Since the behavior of these systems is probabilistic
column3: we typically need to measure them repeatedly. The results of these measurements are then imported into a classical computer
column4: which processes them to generate a statistical understanding of the system's behavior. With a quantum computer
column5: by contrast
column6: it can be possible to mirror a quantum state using the qubits themselves
column7: reproduce it as often as needed
column8: and manipulate it as necessary. This method has the potential to provide a route to a more direct understanding of the quantum system at issue.

column1: Much of the paper is devoted to describing situations where this should be the case
column2: in part elaborating on ideas described in earlier papers.

column1: The first of these ideas describes some property of a quantum system involving an arbitrary number of items—like a quantum computer with n qubits. This is exactly the circumstance described above
column2: where repeated measurements need to be made before a classical computer can reliably identify a property. By contrast
column3: a quantum computer can store a copy of the system in its memory
column4: allowing it to be repeatedly duplicated and processed.

column1: These problems
column2: the authors show
column3: can be solved on a quantum computer in what's called polynomial time
column4: where the number of qubits is raised to a constant power (denoted nk). Using classical hardware
column5: by contrast
column6: the time scales as a constant raised to the power related to the number of qubits. As the number of qubits increases
column7: the time needed for classical hardware rises much faster.

column1: Options two and three
The second task they identify is a quantum principal component analysis
column2: where computers are used to identify the property that has the largest influence on the quantum system's behavior. This was chosen in part because this analysis is thought to be relatively insensitive to the noise introduced by errors in today's quantum processors. Mathematically
column3: the team shows that the number of times you'd need to repeat the measurements for analysis on a classical system grows exponentially with the number of qubits. Using a quantum system
column4: the analysis can be done with a constant number of repeats.

column1: The final situation involves allowing a physical process to influence the state of a quantum system
column2: causing it to evolve to a new state. The goal is to find a model of the process that can accurately predict what the new state would be. Again
column3: using a classical system means the challenge of getting enough measurements scales exponentially with the number of qubits but grows much more slowly when quantum computing is used.

column1: Why does a quantum computer perform so much better? The researchers say that a key step is storing two copies of the examined system and then entangling them. This method is something that's only possible on quantum hardware.";3808;['ibw48v7'

column1: 111;802;a4b3539cd3b8f8f35ad0bbcfb2ce862ca28d38597a0e9dd3360b5ed0a28c94b0;posted_link;r/science;http://www.physorg.com/news/2012-01-quantum-mechanics-naked-eye.html;['o98pb'];['stephenbp66'];[1326114418.0];['Seeing quantum mechanics with the naked eye'];[nan];2012-01-09;University;Seeing quantum mechanics with the naked eye;" A Cambridge team have built a semiconductor chip that converts electrons into a quantum state that emits light but is large enough to see by eye. Because their quantum superfluid is simply set up by shining laser beams on the device
column2: it can lead to practical ultrasensitive detectors. Their research is published today
column3: 08 January in Nature Physics.

column1: Quantum mechanics normally shows its influence only for tiny particles at ultralow temperatures
column2: but the team mixed electrons with light to synthesise supersized quantum particles the thickness of a human hair
column3: that behave like superconductors.

column1: Building microscopic cavities which tightly trap light into the vicinity of electrons within the chip
column2: they produced new particles called polaritons which weigh very little
column3: encouraging them to roam widely.

column1: Dr. Gab Christmann working with Professor Jeremy Baumberg and Dr. Natalia Berloff of the University of Cambridge
column2: together with a team in Crete
column3: produced the special new samples needed which allow the polaritons to flow around at will without getting stuck.

column1: Injecting them in two laser spots
column2: they found that the resulting quantum fluid spontaneously started oscillating backwards and forwards
column3: in the process forming some of the most characteristic quantum pendulum states known to scientists
column4: but thousands of times larger than normal.

column1: According to Christmann: These polaritons overwhelmingly prefer to march in step with each other
column2: entangling themselves quantum mechanically.

column1: The resulting quantum liquid has some peculiar properties
column2: including trying to repel itself. It can also only swirl around in fixed amounts
column3: producing vortices laid out in regular lines.

column1: By moving the laser beams apart
column2: Dr. Christmann and his colleagues directly controlled the sloshing of the quantum liquid
column3: forming a pendulum beating a million times faster than a human heart.

column1: Dr. Christmann added: This is not something we ever expected to see directly
column2: and it is miraculous how mirror-perfect our samples have to be.We can steer our rivers of polariton quantum liquid on the fly by scanning around the laser beams that create them.

column1: Increasing the number of laser beams creates even more complicated quantum states.
The goal of the work is to make such quantum states using an electrical battery and at room temperature
column2: which would allow a new generation of ultrasensitive gyroscopes to measure gravity
column3: magnetic field
column4: and create quantum circuits.

column1: But as Christmann says: Just to see and prod quantum mechanics working in front of your eyes is amazing.";2541;['c3fezpw'

column1: 112;213;114ddbdcf8b2be7577e97087177aa6ab51e2af0352cabaafaef7decb9a607d41;posted_link;r/science;http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2013-11/uoo-qwr111313.php;['1qowyb'];['mubukugrappa'];[1384525338.0];['Quantum world record smashed: A normally fragile quantum state has been shown to survive at room temperature for a world record 39 minutes
column2: overcoming a key barrier towards building ultrafast quantum computers.'];[nan];2013-11-14;;Quantum world record smashed;"A normally fragile quantum state has been shown to survive at room temperature for a world record 39 minutes
column3: overcoming a key barrier towards building ultrafast quantum computers.

column1: An international team including Stephanie Simmons of Oxford University
column2: UK
column3: report in this week's Science a test performed by Mike Thewalt of Simon Fraser University
column4: Canada
column5: and colleagues. In conventional computers data is stored as a string of 1s and 0s. In the experiment quantum bits of information
column6: 'qubits'
column7: were put into a 'superposition' state in which they can be both 1s and 0 at the same time – enabling them to perform multiple calculations simultaneously.

column1: In the experiment the team raised the temperature of a system
column2: in which information is encoded in the nuclei of phosphorus atoms in silicon
column3: from -269 °C to 25 °C and demonstrated that the superposition states survived at this balmy temperature for 39 minutes – outside of silicon the previous record for such a state's survival at room temperature was around two seconds. The team even found that they could manipulate the qubits as the temperature of the system rose
column4: and that they were robust enough for this information to survive being 'refrozen' (the optical technique used to read the qubits only works at very low temperatures).

column1: '39 minutes may not seem very long but as it only takes one-hundred-thousandth of a second to flip the nuclear spin of a phosphorus ion – the type of operation used to run quantum calculations – in theory over 20 million operations could be applied in the time it takes for the superposition to naturally decay by one percent. Having such robust
column2: as well as long-lived
column3: qubits could prove very helpful for anyone trying to build a quantum computer
column4: ' said Stephanie Simmons of Oxford University's Department of Materials
column5: an author of the paper.

column1: 'This opens up the possibility of truly long-term coherent information storage at room temperature
column2: ' said Mike Thewalt of Simon Fraser University.

column1: The team began with a sliver of silicon doped with small amounts of other elements
column2: including phosphorus. Quantum information was encoded in the nuclei of the phosphorus atoms: each nucleus has an intrinsic quantum property called 'spin'
column3: which acts like a tiny bar magnet when placed in a magnetic field. Spins can be manipulated to point up (0)
column4: down (1)
column5: or any angle in between
column6: representing a superposition of the two other states.

column1: The team prepared their sample at just 4 °C above absolute zero (-269 °C) and placed it in a magnetic field. Additional magnetic field pulses were used to tilt the direction of the nuclear spin and create the superposition states. When the sample was held at this cryogenic temperature
column2: the nuclear spins of about 37 per cent of the ions – a typical benchmark to measure quantum coherence – remained in their superposition state for three hours. The same fraction survived for 39 minutes when the temperature of the system was raised to 25 °C.

column1: 'These lifetimes are at least ten times longer than those measured in previous experiments
column2: ' said Stephanie Simmons. 'We've managed to identify a system that seems to have basically no noise. They're high-performance qubits.'

column1: There is still some work ahead before the team can carry out large-scale quantum computations. The nuclear spins of the 10 billion or so phosphorus ions used in this experiment were all placed in the same quantum state. To run calculations
column2: however
column3: physicists will need to place different qubits in different states. 'To have them controllably talking to one another – that would address the last big remaining challenge
column4: ' said Simmons.";3624;['cdf4mf5'

column1: 113;495;07698e25250aeb2ae46643c4368163206d47232bc778c342d729ad0ed59c8afd;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/cryptocurrency/will-bitcoin-be-threatened-by-the-development-of-quantum-computing-9286091.html;['xz0qo7'];['azaxslo'];[1665255860.0];['Can a quantum computing be a threat for BTC mining in the future?'];[nan];2022-10-09;Murtuza Merchant;Will Bitcoin be threatened by the development of quantum computing?;"Back in 2009
column2: when Bitcoin established a peer-to-peer (P2P) lending system supported by its native Bitcoin (BTC) currency
column3: the world regarded a decentralised financial system with amazement and scepticism.

column1: More than a decade later
column2: BTC has not only become the most valuable cryptocurrency in the world by market cap but has also accelerated the adoption of blockchain technology across several sectors.

column1: Blockchain technology
column2: which uses cryptographic encryption techniques to provide a trustless and decentralised ledger system for recording transactions immutably
column3: has given rise to a number of applications
column4: including DeFi or decentralised finance
column5: which is revolutionising how people conduct business online.

column1: However
column2: the supremacy of blockchain-based protocols like Bitcoin may soon be challenged by a new generation of quantum computers that employ quantum bits
column3: often known as “qubits”
column4: to do computations orders of magnitude quicker than even the most powerful supercomputers.

column1: How quantum computing works and how it may lead to dangerous attacks?
While conventional computers utilise bits
column2: which alternate between 0 and 1
column3: quantum computers employ qubits
column4: which may exist in both states simultaneously.

column1: These computers are millions of times quicker than the fastest supercomputers available today because they can calculate and take into account several configurations at once.
With this level of processing power
column2: bad actors might leverage the benefits of quantum computing to target protocols like Bitcoin in an effort to steal money from the millions of cryptocurrency users who already conduct online transactions.

column1: Such elements may theoretically deploy potent quantum computers to attack susceptible wallet addresses or even target transactions while they are being processed on the blockchain by using various tactics
column2: such as transit attacks or storage assaults.

column1: While transit attacks are beyond the capabilities of the majority of the quantum computers now in use
column2: storage attacks appear to be more likely since they depend on how securely tokens are maintained by different users.

column1: Is Bitcoin's hegemony currently under threat?
Today's borderless transaction systems
column2: such as Bitcoin and other blockchain protocols
column3: are not especially vulnerable to quantum computing assaults.

column1: This is due to the fact that the processing power of quantum computers has not advanced above 100 qubits
column2: greatly restricting the likelihood of an attack on a protocol as vast and safe as Bitcoin.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: given how quickly technology is developing
column3: it is predicted that over the next 10 years
column4: quantum computers with more than a million qubits will likely become a reality.

column1: With so much computing power
column2: a concerted attack on the Bitcoin network in its current state would be seriously undermined
column3: with even transit attacks being a very real possibility for cybercriminals.

column1: However
column2: given the restricted time
column3: depending on the block processing time of each protocol
column4: and the enormous amount of qubits needed to launch a successful attack
column5: transit assaults would still be a very difficult undertaking.

column1: Quantum computing used by projects that aim to resist any potential attacks
There are several initiatives underway seeking to modify or implement new designs that would make protocols like Bitcoin even more secure
column2: despite the fact that quantum computers have not yet developed the degree of computational power required to pose a danger to them.

column1: Furthermore
column2: blockchain technology itself is constantly developing as developers and business owners compete to be the most innovative.

column1: One of the most pressing jobs for the crypto development community will be to abandon elliptic curve cryptography (ECC)
column2: which relies on a set of public and private keys to encrypt data.

column1: Numerous teams are looking at alternative cryptographic techniques to safeguard the future iteration of Bitcoin and other protocols because they see the need for stronger and more attack-proof solutions.
Block lattice technique
column2: used by the QAN Platform
column3: directed acyclic graph (DAG) technology
column4: used in the Iota blockchain
column5: and even quantum key distribution (QKD)
column6: which was jointly created by Toshiba and JPMorgan
column7: are some significant instances of quantum-resistant technologies.

column1: The key message is still that the crypto developer community is doing everything possible to prepare for the risks posed by quantum computing
column2: despite the fact that each of these methods has adopted a different strategy to make sure that their respective networks can withstand quantum computing attacks.";4556;['irjmh0s'

column1: 114;1124;236d45237096ac1a311ebab83fa4c60991ce36a89cc7dac86edff0f8d541922c;posted_link;r/science;https://www.tcd.ie/news_events/top-stories/featured/our-brains-use-quantum-computation/;['y8t01q'];['ctparty'];[1666256415.0];['New research suggests our brains use quantum computation'];[nan];2022-10-19;Trinity College Dublin;Our brains use quantum computation;"Scientists from Trinity believe our brains could use quantum computation after adapting an idea developed to prove the existence of quantum gravity to explore the human brain and its workings. The discovery may shed light on consciousness
column2: the workings of which remain scientifically difficult to understand and explain. Quantum brain processes could also explain why we can still outperform supercomputers when it comes to unforeseen circumstances
column3: decision making
column4: or learning something new

column1: Scientists from Trinity believe our brains could use quantum computation after adapting an idea developed to prove the existence of quantum gravity to explore the human brain and its workings.
The brain functions measured were also correlated to short-term memory performance and conscious awareness
column2: suggesting quantum processes are also part of cognitive and conscious brain functions.

column1: If the team’s results can be confirmed – likely requiring advanced multidisciplinary approaches –they would enhance our general understanding of how the brain works and potentially how it can be maintained or even healed. They may also help find innovative technologies and build even more advanced quantum computers.
Dr Christian Kerskens
column2: lead physicist at the Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience (TCIN)
column3: is the co-author of the research article that has just been published in the Journal of Physics Communications. He said:

column1: “We adapted an idea
column2: developed for experiments to prove the existence of quantum gravity
column3: whereby you take known quantum systems
column4: which interact with an unknown system. If the known systems entangle
column5: then the unknown must be a quantum system
column6: too. It circumvents the difficulties to find measuring devices for something we know nothing about.

column1: “For our experiments we used proton spins of ‘brain water’ as the known system. ‘Brain water’ builds up naturally as fluid in our brains and the proton spins can be measured using MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). Then
column2: by using a specific MRI design to seek entangled spins
column3: we found MRI signals that resemble heartbeat evoked potentials
column4: a form of EEG signals. EEGs measure electrical brain currents
column5: which some people may recognise from personal experience or simply from watching hospital dramas on TV.”

column1: Electrophysiological potentials like the heartbeat evoked potentials are normally not detectable with MRI and the scientists believe they could only observe them because the nuclear proton spins in the brain were entangled.
Dr Kerskens added:
“If entanglement is the only possible explanation here then that would mean that brain processes must have interacted with the nuclear spins
column2: mediating the entanglement between the nuclear spins. As a result
column3: we can deduce that those brain functions must be quantum.

column1: “Because these brain functions were also correlated to short-term memory performance and conscious awareness
column2: it is likely that those quantum processes are an important part of our cognitive and conscious brain functions.

column1: “Quantum brain processes could explain why we can still outperform supercomputers when it comes to unforeseen circumstances
column2: decision making
column3: or learning something new. Our experiments performed only 50 metres away from the lecture theatre
column4: where Schrödinger presented his famous thoughts about life
column5: may shed light on the mysteries of biology
column6: and on consciousness which scientifically is even harder to grasp.”";3410;['it1qbvo'

column1: 115;1131;cbb4100206db823969c7c8cec86a75e9e818befaf4a8bf3433d4bc707e912c20;posted_link;r/science;https://www.technologyreview.com/s/613092/a-quantum-experiment-suggests-theres-no-such-thing-as-objective-reality/;['b1ksk6'];['SushiJuice'];[1552687110.0];['A quantum experiment suggests there’s no such thing as objective reality'];[nan];2019-03-12;Emerging Technology;A quantum experiment suggests there’s no such thing as objective reality;"Back in 1961
column2: the Nobel Prize–winning physicist Eugene Wigner outlined a thought experiment that demonstrated one of the lesser-known paradoxes of quantum mechanics. The experiment shows how the strange nature of the universe allows two observers—say
column3: Wigner and Wigner’s friend—to experience different realities.

column1: Since then
column2: physicists have used the “Wigner’s Friend” thought experiment to explore the nature of measurement and to argue over whether objective facts can exist. That’s important because scientists carry out experiments to establish objective facts. But if they experience different realities
column3: the argument goes
column4: how can they agree on what these facts might be?

column1: That’s provided some entertaining fodder for after-dinner conversation
column2: but Wigner’s thought experiment has never been more than that—just a thought experiment.

column1: Last year
column2: however
column3: physicists noticed that recent advances in quantum technologies have made it possible to reproduce the Wigner’s Friend test in a real experiment. In other words
column4: it ought to be possible to create different realities and compare them in the lab to find out whether they can be reconciled.

column1: And today
column2: Massimiliano Proietti at Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh and a few colleagues say they have performed this experiment for the first time: they have created different realities and compared them. Their conclusion is that Wigner was correct—these realities can be made irreconcilable so that it is impossible to agree on objective facts about an experiment.

column1: Wigner’s original thought experiment is straightforward in principle. It begins with a single polarized photon that
column2: when measured
column3: can have either a horizontal polarization or a vertical polarization. But before the measurement
column4: according to the laws of quantum mechanics
column5: the photon exists in both polarization states at the same time—a so-called superposition.

column1: Wigner imagined a friend in a different lab measuring the state of this photon and storing the result
column2: while Wigner observed from afar. Wigner has no information about his friend’s measurement and so is forced to assume that the photon and the measurement of it are in a superposition of all possible outcomes of the experiment.

column1: Wigner can even perform an experiment to determine whether this superposition exists or not. This is a kind of interference experiment showing that the photon and the measurement are indeed in a superposition.
From Wigner’s point of view
column2: this is a “fact”—the superposition exists. And this fact suggests that a measurement cannot have taken place.

column1: But this is in stark contrast to the point of view of the friend
column2: who has indeed measured the photon’s polarization and recorded it. The friend can even call Wigner and say the measurement has been done (provided the outcome is not revealed).

column1: So the two realities are at odds with each other. “This calls into question the objective status of the facts established by the two observers
column2: ” say Proietti and co.

column1: That’s the theory
column2: but last year Caslav Brukner
column3: at the University of Vienna in Austria
column4: came up with a way to re-create the Wigner’s Friend experiment in the lab by means of techniques involving the entanglement of many particles at the same time.

column1: The breakthrough that Proietti and co have made is to carry this out. “In a state-of-the-art 6-photon experiment
column2: we realize this extended Wigner’s friend scenario
column3: ” they say.

column1: They use these six entangled photons to create two alternate realities—one representing Wigner and one representing Wigner’s friend. Wigner’s friend measures the polarization of a photon and stores the result. Wigner then performs an interference measurement to determine if the measurement and the photon are in a superposition.
The experiment produces an unambiguous result. It turns out that both realities can coexist even though they produce irreconcilable outcomes
column2: just as Wigner predicted.

column1: That raises some fascinating questions that are forcing physicists to reconsider the nature of reality.

The idea that observers can ultimately reconcile their measurements of some kind of fundamental reality is based on several assumptions. The first is that universal facts actually exist and that observers can agree on them.

But there are other assumptions too. One is that observers have the freedom to make whatever observations they want. And another is that the choices one observer makes do not influence the choices other observers make—an assumption that physicists call locality.
If there is an objective reality that everyone can agree on
column2: then these assumptions all hold.

column1: But Proietti and co’s result suggests that objective reality does not exist. In other words
column2: the experiment suggests that one or more of the assumptions—the idea that there is a reality we can agree on
column3: the idea that we have freedom of choice
column4: or the idea of locality—must be wrong.

column1: Of course
column2: there is another way out for those hanging on to the conventional view of reality. This is that there is some other loophole that the experimenters have overlooked. Indeed
column3: physicists have tried to close loopholes in similar experiments for years
column4: although they concede that it may never be possible to close them all.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the work has important implications for the work of scientists. “The scientific method relies on facts
column3: established through repeated measurements and agreed upon universally
column4: independently of who observed them
column5: ” say Proietti and co. And yet in the same paper
column6: they undermine this idea

column1: The next step is to go further: to construct experiments creating increasingly bizarre alternate realities that cannot be reconciled. Where this will take us is anybody’s guess. But Wigner
column2: and his friend
column3: would surely not be surprised.";5743;['eimdobm'
