column1: 116;1254;3792e76792f25f2eaffc6e5cf9dfc1e229f6ed9189f86c02ebe2d118e50851d4;posted_link;r/Futurology;http://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2013/06/d-wave-quantum-computer-usc/;['1h8p19'];['Simcurious'];[1372416675.0];"[""Google's Quantum Computer Proven To Be Real Thing (Almost)""]";[nan];2013-06-28;"Condé Nast; Cade Metz";Google's Quantum Computer Proven To Be Real Thing (Almost);"Google bought one. So did Lockheed Martin
column2: one of the world's largest defense contractors. But we still can't agree on what it is they bought.

column1: D-Wave
column2: the company that built the thing
column3: calls it the world's first quantum computer
column4: a seminal creation that foretells the future of mathematical calculation. But many of the world's experts see it quite differently
column5: arguing the D-Wave machine is something other than the computing holy grail the scientific community has sought since the mid-1980s.

column1: No doubt
column2: the argument will continue. But today
column3: researchers at the University of Southern California published a paper that comes that much closer to showing the D-Wave is indeed a quantum computer. USC houses and operates the D-Wave system owned by Lockheed
column4: and the researchers -- led by Daniel Lidar
column5: a professor of electrical engineering
column6: chemistry
column7: and physics -- say they have at least shown the machine is not using a computing model known as ""simulated annealing
column8: which obeys the laws of classical physics (the physics of everyday life) rather than the more elusive properties of quantum physics.

column1: [Our research] rules out one type of classical model that has been argued as a proper description of the D-Wave machine
column2: Lidar says. ""A lot of people thought that when D-Wave came on the market their machine was just doing that
column3: [but] we ruled that out.""

column1: >'Our research rules out one type of classical model that has been argued as a proper description of the D-Wave machine. A lot of people thought that when D-Wave came on the market their machine was just doing that
column2: but we ruled that out.'

column1: Daniel Lidar
The paper
column2: Experimental Signature of Programmable Quantum Annealing
column3: appears in the well-respected academic journal Nature Communications. Quantum annealing is a computing model that
column4: yes
column5: operates in the quantum realm
column6: and according to Lidar
column7: the team's research shows ""strong agreement"" between quantum annealing and the way the D-Wave system operates.

column1: First proposed in 1985 by British physicist David Deutsch
column2: a quantum computer is a machine that operates according to the mind-bending principles of quantum mechanics
column3: the physics of very small things like electrons and photons. With a classical computer
column4: a transistor stores a single ""bit"" of information. If the transistor is ""on
column5: it holds a ""1."" If it’s ""off
column6: it holds a ""0."" With quantum computer
column7: information is held in a system that can exist in two states at the same time
column8: thanks to what's called the superposition principle of quantum mechanics.

column1: This ""qubit"" can store a ""0"" and ""1"" simultaneously. If you build two qubits
column2: they can hold four values at once -- 00
column5: and 11. As you tack on additional qubits
column6: you can fashion a machine exponentially more powerful than a classical computer.

column1: The rub is building even a single qubit is difficult. When you look at — i.e. read information from — a quantum system
column2: it decoheres. In other words
column3: it turns into an ordinary bit capable of holding only a single value. It ceases to be a quantum computer.

column1: There are many ways around this problem
column2: and the minds at D-Wave
column3: including founder and CTO Geordie Rose
column4: believe they've found one. In 2007
column5: the company released what it called a 16-qubit quantum computer
column6: and the company's current model is billed as a 512-qubit machine. This is what Google is using.

column1: According to D-Wave
column2: the machine contains 512 superconducting circuits
column3: each a tiny loop of flowing current. These are cooled to almost absolute zero
column4: the company says
column5: so they enter a quantum state where the current flows both clockwise and counterclockwise at the same time. When you feed the machine a task
column6: it uses a set of algorithms to map a calculation across these qubits -- and then execute that calculation. Basically
column7: this involves determining the probability that a given set of circuits will emerge in a particular pattern when the temperature inside the system is raised.";3918;['cas0l7h'

column1: 117;683;de1eac47673a31e950609e65c143cbddeece587fb56c7f84157676a013e2fe95;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.pcgamer.com/amd-teleportation-quantum-computing-multi-simd-patent/;['phpeiq'];['Dr_Singularity'];[1630752823.0];['AMD files teleportation patent to supercharge quantum computing'];[nan];2021-09-03;Katie Wickens;AMD files teleportation patent to supercharge quantum computing;"AMD has proposed a patent for 'teleportation
column2: ' meaning things could be about to get much more efficient around here. With the incredible technological feats humanity achieves on a daily basis
column3: and Nvidia's Jensen going off on one last year about GeForce holodecks and time machines (opens in new tab)
column4: it's easy for us to slip into a headspace that lets us believe genuine human teleportation is just around the corner.

column1: Finally
column2: you sigh
column3: mouthing the headline to yourself. ""Goodbye work commute
column4: hello popping to Japan for an authentic Ramen on my lunch break.""

column1: I'm sorry to say the reality is much less... palpable.
Our colleagues over at Tom's Hardware (opens in new tab) spotted the new patent lain down by AMD engineers
column2: named 'Look-ahead teleportation for reliable computation in multi-SIMD quantum processor.' As the title suggests
column3: it looks like the company has been researching systems involving quantum teleportation (opens in new tab) processes. The aim is to improve the current reliability of quantum computing
column4: and even reduce the number of qubits necessary to make accurate calculations.

column1: How to buy a graphics card (opens in new tab): tips on buying a graphics card in the barren silicon landscape that is 2021
The patent file (opens in new tab) [pdf warning] contains step by step diagrams detailing the proposed process. Essentially
column2: the 'out-of-order' execution method AMD is looking to lay claim to ensures some Qubits that would be left idle—waiting for their calculation step to come around—are able to execute independent of a prior result. Where usually they would need to wait for previous Qubits to provide instructions
column3: they can calculate simultaneously
column4: no need to wait in line.

column1: So
column2: no
column3: we're not going to be zipping through wormholes just yet. But if AMD's designs come through
column4: we could be looking at much more efficient
column5: scalable and stable quantum computing architecture than we have now.";1921;['hbkey8y'
column6: 'hbkc4yk'

column1: 118;806;2dc077e03f75d19188520680483bf674707a4e730f533c2a7e8aa7aa4f5c9511;posted_link;r/tech;https://www.quantamagazine.org/milestone-experiment-proves-quantum-communication-really-is-faster-20181219/;['m3hq1k'];['esprit-de-lescalier'];[1615556336.0];['Milestone Experiment Proves Quantum Communication Really Is Faster'];[nan];2018-12-19;Kevin Hartnett December;Milestone Experiment Proves Quantum Communication Really Is Faster | Quanta Magazine;"Quantum computers are still a dream
column2: but the era of quantum communication is here. A new experiment out of Paris has demonstrated
column3: for the first time
column4: that quantum communication is superior to classical ways of transmitting information.

column1: “We are the first to show a quantum advantage for transmitted information that two parties have to share to perform a useful task
column2: ” said Eleni Diamanti
column3: an electrical engineer at Sorbonne University and a co-author of the result along with Iordanis Kerenidis
column4: a computer scientist at Paris Diderot University
column5: and Niraj Kumar.

column1: Quantum machines — which exploit quantum properties of matter to encode information — are widely expected to revolutionize computing. But progress has been slow. While engineers labor to build rudimentary quantum computers
column2: theoretical computer scientists have confronted a more fundamental obstacle: They’ve been unable to prove that classical computers will never be able to perform the tasks quantum computers are designed for. This past summer
column3: for example
column4: a teenager from Texas proved that a problem long thought to be quickly solvable only on a quantum computer can be done rapidly on a classical computer as well.

column1: However
column2: in the realm of communication (rather than computation)
column3: the benefits of a quantum approach are certifiable. More than a decade ago computer scientists proved that
column4: at least theoretically
column5: quantum communication beats classical ways of sending messages for certain tasks.

column1: “Mostly people have looked at computational tasks. One big advantage is that with communication tasks
column2: the advantages are provable
column3: ” Kerenidis said.

column2: Kerenidis and two other computer scientists imagined a scenario in which one person needed to send information to another so that the second person could answer a particular question. The researchers proved that a quantum setup could accomplish the task by transmitting exponentially less information than a classical system. But the quantum setup they imagined was purely theoretical — and far beyond the technology of the time.

column1: “We could prove this quantum advantage
column2: but it was difficult to actually implement the quantum protocol
column3: ” Kerenidis said.

column1: Introduction
The new work carries out a modified version of the scenario that Kerenidis and colleagues envisaged. The question addressed in the paper involves two users
column2: Alice and Bob. Alice has a set of numbered balls. Each ball is randomly colored red or blue. Bob wants to know whether a particular pair of balls
column3: chosen at random
column4: has the same color or different colors. Alice wants to send Bob the smallest amount of information she can while still ensuring that Bob can answer his question.

column1: This problem is called the “sampling matching problem.” It has implications for cryptography and digital currency
column2: where users often want to exchange information without necessarily divulging everything they know. It’s also well-suited to demonstrating a quantum communication advantage.

column1: “You can’t just say
column2: ‘I want to send you a movie or something that’s one gigabyte and encode it into a quantum state’” and expect to find a quantum advantage
column3: said Thomas Vidick
column4: a computer scientist at the California Institute of Technology. “You have to look at tasks that are more subtle.”

column1: To solve the matching problem classically
column2: Alice has to send Bob an amount of information proportional to the square root of the number of balls. But the unorthodox nature of quantum information makes a more efficient solution possible.

column1: In the laboratory setup used in the new work
column2: Alice and Bob communicate via laser pulses. Each pulse represents a single ball. The pulses go through a beam splitter
column3: which sends half of each pulse toward Alice and half toward Bob. As a pulse passes by Alice
column4: she can shift something called the phase of the laser pulse to encode information about each ball — whether it’s red or blue.

column1: Meanwhile Bob encodes information about the pairs of balls he cares about into his half of the laser pulses. The pulses then converge in another beam splitter
column2: where they interfere with each other. The way in which the two sets of pulses interfere with each other reflects differences in the way the phase of each pulse has been shifted. Bob can read the interference pattern on nearby photon detectors.

column1: Up until the moment that Bob “reads” Alice’s laser message
column2: Alice’s quantum message is capable of answering any question about any pair. But in the act of reading the quantum message
column3: he destroys it
column4: yielding information about just one pair of balls.

column1: This characteristic of quantum information — that it carries the potential to be read many ways but can ultimately be read only one way — dramatically reduces the amount of information that needs to be transmitted to solve the sampling matching problem. If Alice needs to send Bob 100 classical bits to ensure he can answer his question
column2: she can accomplish the same objective in about 10 qubits
column3: or quantum bits.

column1: “It’s the sort of proof-of-principle stuff you have to do if you’re going to build up a real quantum network
column2: ” said Graeme Smith
column3: a physicist at JILA in Boulder
column4: Colorado
column5: who works on quantum technology.

column1: The new experiment is an unalloyed triumph over classical methods. The researchers went into the experiment knowing exactly how much information needed to be transmitted classically to solve the problem. They then indisputably demonstrated that it could be solved in a far leaner fashion by quantum means. “It’s nice in this paper to see people really making a good effort to make sure the thing they’re doing is hard classically
column2: and then doing the hard thing” using quantum methods
column3: Smith said.

column1: The result also suggests an alternative route for achieving a long-standing goal in computer science: proving that quantum computers reign over classical ones. Such quantum “supremacy” has been hard to establish in the purely computational realm
column2: but many important problems hinge on more than just computation.

column1: “Combining what we can do with computing and communication power
column2: putting these two things together
column3: would make it easier to prove a quantum advantage
column4: ” Kerenidis said.";6126;['gqp0gfh'

column1: 119;1123;e2e0707252b67e9560e2052ee4a97ede1c5dc2657479033b4c371e2b6ace9afc;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.technologyreview.com/news/429429/the-cia-and-jeff-bezos-bet-on-quantum-computing/;['10y17u'];['finisterre'];[1349371232.0];['The CIA bets that a Canadian startup has working quantum computers'];[nan];2012-10-04;Tom Simonite;The CIA and Jeff Bezos Bet on Quantum Computing;"With funding from the Amazon founder and the CIA’s investment arm
column2: the Canadian company D-Wave is gaining momentum for its revolutionary approach to computing.

column1: Inside a blocky building in a Vancouver suburb
column2: across the street from a dowdy McDonald’s
column3: is a place chilled colder than anywhere in the known universe. Inside that is a computer processor that Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and the CIA’s investment arm
column4: In-Q-Tel
column5: believe can tap the quirks of quantum mechanics to unleash more computing power than any conventional computer chip. Bezos and In-Q-Tel are in a group of investors who are betting $30 million on this prospect.

column1: Entangled: This is part of the structure that cools and shields the D-Wave processor so it can (apparently) conduct its quantum calculations.
If the bet works out
column2: some of the world’s thorniest computing problems
column3: such as the hunt for new drugs or efforts to build artificial intelligence
column4: would become dramatically less challenging. This development would also clear the tainted reputation of D-Wave Systems
column5: the startup whose eight-year-long effort to create a quantum computer has earned little more than skepticism bordering on ridicule from prominent physicists.

column1: D-Wave’s supercooled processor is designed to handle what software engineers call “optimization” problems
column2: the core of conundrums such as figuring out the most efficient delivery route
column3: or how the atoms in a protein will move around when it meets a drug compound. “Virtually everything has to do with optimization
column4: and it’s the bedrock of machine learning
column5: which underlies virtually all the wealth creation on the Internet
column6: ” says Geordie Rose
column7: D-Wave’s founder and chief technology officer. In machine learning
column9: software examines information about the world and formulates an appropriate way to act in the future. It underpins technologies such as speech recognition and product recommendations and is a priority for research by companies

column1: “Our intelligence community customers have many complex problems that tax classical computing architecture
column2: ” Robert Ames
column3: vice president for information and communication technologies at In-Q-Tel
column4: said in a statement released today. In-Q-Tel’s primary “customer” is the CIA
column5: and the National Security Agency is another. Both are known to be investing heavily in automated intelligence gathering and analysis.

column1: Rose
column2: a confident Canadian with a guitar and samurai sword propped in the corner of his windowless office
column3: has been making grand claims to journalists since 2007
column4: when he unveiled D-Wave’s first proof-of-concept processor at a high-profile event at the Computer History Museum in Mountain View
column5: California. Attendees saw a D-Wave processor (apparently) solve sudoku puzzles and find a close match to a particular drug molecule in a collection of other compounds. But in the weeks
column6: months
column8: skepticism and accusations of fraud rained down on the company from academic experts on quantum computing. Rose’s initial predictions about how quickly the company would increase the size and capabilities of its chips fell by the wayside

column1: Signing up Bezos and In-Q-Tel—the company’s most prominent backers yet—is the latest in a series of events that suggest D-Wave thinks it is ready to finally answer its critics. In May 2011
column2: the company published a paper in the prestigious journal Nature that critical academics said was the first to prove D-Wave’s chips have some of the quantum properties needed to back up Rose??s claims. Artificial intelligence researchers at Google regularly log into a D-Wave computer over the Internet to try it out
column3: and 2011 also saw the company sign its first customer. Defense contractor Lockheed Martin paid $10 million for a computer for research into automatically detecting software bugs in complex projects such as the delayed F-35 fighter (see “Tapping Quantum Effects for Software that Learns”). Questions remain about just how its technology works
column4: but D-Wave says more evidence is forthcoming. It is readying an improved processor that Rose calls the company’s first true product rather than a piece of research equipment. D-Wave is expected to announce other major customers in coming months.

column1: Cold Spot
Step inside D-Wave’s ground-floor office suite and you’re greeted by bland meeting rooms
column2: offices
column3: and cubicles. But open the correct door off the main corridor and you emerge into a bright white lab space dominated by four black monoliths—D-Wave’s computers. Roughly cube-shaped
column4: and around 10 feet tall
column5: they emit a rhythmic
column6: high-pitched sound as supercooled gases circulate inside. Each of the machines has a door on the side and is mostly empty
column7: with what looks like a ray gun descending from the ceiling
column8: a widely spaced stack of five metal discs of decreasing size held together with cables
column10: and pipes plated with gold and copper. It is actually a cold gun: the structure is a chilly -452 °F (4 °Kelvin) at the wide end and a few thousandths of a degree above absolute zero at its tip
column11: where D-Wave’s inch-square chip can be found. Not even the deepest reaches of space are this cold
column12: or so shielded from magnetic fields as this chip
column13: which is etched at a plant in Silicon Valley from a niobium alloy that becomes superconducting at ultralow temperatures.

column1: The processor in every computer you’ve used is made from silicon and patterned with transistors that create logic gates—switches that are either on (represented by a 1 in the computer’s programming) or off (a 0).  D-Wave’s processors are also made up of elements that switch between 1 and 0
column2: but they are loops of niobium alloy—there are 512 of them in the newest processor. These loops are known as qubits and can trap electrical current
column3: which circles inside the loops either clockwise (signified by a 0) or counterclockwise (1). Smaller superconducting loops called couplers link the qubits so they can interact and even influence one another to flip between 1 and 0.

column1: This delicate setup is designed so that the layout of qubits conforms to an algorithm that solves a particular kind of optimization problem at the core of many tasks difficult to solve on a conventional processor. It’s like a specialized machine in a factory able to do one thing really well
column2: on a particular kind of raw material. Performing a calculation on D-Wave’s chip requires providing that raw material
column3: in the form of the numbers to be fed into its hard-coded algorithm. It’s done by setting the qubits into a pattern of 1s and 0s
column4: and fine-tuning how the couplers allow the qubits to interact. After a wait of less than a second
column5: the qubits settle into new values that represent a lower state of energy for the processor
column6: and reveal a potential solution to the original problem.

column1: What happens during that crucial wait is a kind of quantum mechanical argument. The qubits enter a strange quantum state where they are simultaneously both 1 and 0
column2: like Schrodinger’s cat being both dead and alive
column3: and lock into a strange synchronicity known as entanglement
column4: a phenomenon once described by Einstein as “spooky.” That allows the system of qubits to explore every possible final configuration in an instant
column5: before settling into on the one that is simplest or very close to it.

column1: At least
column2: that’s what D-Wave’s scientists say. Many questions remain about what actually happens inside the company’s chips
column3: not least in the heads of the company’s own physicists
column4: engineers
column5: and computer scientists. “We’re building this system empirically
column6: not just following the theory
column8: the D-Wave vice president who leads its processor development. He and the company’s other engineers don’t know for sure what’s happening in the chip
column9: but as long as each design generates answers to the problems posed
column10: the finer details of the quantum physics taking place inside can wait for retrospective validation.

column1: It’s an attitude that seems to have played well with investors
column2: but it still rankles academics. “At an engineering level they’ve put together a setup that’s impressive in various ways
column3: ” says Scott Aaronson
column4: an MIT professor who studies the limits of quantum computation. “But in terms of the evidence that they’re solving problems using quantum mechanics faster than you could classically
column5: I don’t think it’s there yet.” A fierce critic of D-Wave in the years following its 2007 demo
column6: Aaronson softened his stance last year after the company’s Nature paper showing quantum effects. “In the past there was an enormous gap between the marketing claims and where the science was and that’s come down
column9: who visited the company’s labs in February. “The burden of proof is on them and they haven’t met the burden yet.”

column1: Aaronson’s biggest gripe is that the design of D-Wave’s system could plausibly solve problems without quantum effects
column2: in which case it would simply be a very weird conventional computer. He and other critics say the company must still prove two things: that its qubits really can enter superpositions and become entangled
column3: and that the chip delivers a significant “quantum speed-up” compared to a classical computer working on the same problem. So far the company has presented proof of neither in a peer-reviewed forum.

column1: Rose says that D-Wave is working on proving evidence of entanglement
column2: and that recent head-to-head tests against classical computers showed it pulling ahead on the kind of computing problem that it is designed to solve.

column1: Aaronson also says the way D-Wave’s processor is hard-coded for one particular type of problem will inhibit the range of problems it might solve. In addition
column2: the relatively small number of qubits on the processor today means it can handle only tiny strings of data. Using mathematical tricks to translate a problem into the right form to deal with those limitations
column3: and reversing the process once D-Wave’s chip has given its answer
column4: could cause significant slowdowns
column5: says Aaronson. Rose counters that a quantum processor will be fast enough to overcome any such penalties
column6: and he says he has engineers working on ways to automatically translate normal programming code into what a D-Wave chip needs.

column1: Whether or not D-Wave can satisfy Aaronson and other skeptics doesn’t necessarily matter to investors and technology companies. That’s because in so many areas of business
column2: computing power is crucial to maintaining a competitive advantage
column3: says Steve Jurvetson
column4: a partner at venture capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson
column5: who has invested in D-Wave twice and calls it “the most singular swing-for-the-fences technology” he ever funded. “The application space for this
column6: ” he says
column7: “is anywhere we’ve had to fall back on an heuristic—a rule of thumb—to solve a problem: day traders
column9: anyone in e-commerce and the Googles and Microsofts of the world.” Companies such as Lockheed
column11: and big pharma companies are most familiar with the limits of conventional computers and will be first in line
column13: but designing a new car or a new online store could also benefit.

column1: Companies and government agencies have another
column2: perhaps more urgent motivation to take a chance on a startup that has a beguiling idea but a few troubling loose ends. There is good reason to believe that the exponential growth in computing power seen over the last few decades is ending
column3: says Bob Lucas
column4: who directs research on supercomputing and quantum computing at the University of Southern California
column5: where Lockheed’s D-Wave computer is installed. Many of the regular advances in computing power have come from connections on chips shrinking year after year
column6: but with leading chip maker Intel currently working on making them just 14 nanometers across
column7: there’s not much smaller things can get. “We’re living in the last 10 years of exponential growth of [classical] computing power
column8: and alternatives to that will become more of interest
column9: ” Lucas says. He adds that through his experiments on Lockheed’s D-Wave system he has been converted from “highly skeptical to cautiously optimistic” about the technology. ";12238;['c6hoo7b'

column1: 120;593;a75258423df21b8be8f243dfb704d4b496b97400cd07df38e3ebd241bc3f9cee;posted_link;r/worldnews;https://news.sky.com/story/quantum-entanglement-einsteins-spooky-phenomenon-caught-on-camera-for-first-time-11762100;['cch4o7'];['Skibumcraig'];[1562967989.0];"[""Quantum entanglement: Einstein's 'spooky' phenomenon caught on camera for first time | Science & Tech News | Sky News""]";[nan];2019-07-12;;Quantum entanglement: Einstein's 'spooky' phenomenon caught on camera for first time;"Quantum entanglement: Einstein's 'spooky' phenomenon caught on camera for first time
Scientists have photographed a strong form of quantum entanglement
column2: where two particles interact and share physical states.

column1: The image is of a strong form of quantum entanglement
column2: where two particles interact with each other and share their physical states for an instant.

column1: It happens no matter how great the distance between the two particles.
The connection is known as Bell entanglement and underpins the field of quantum mechanics.
Paul-Antoine Moreau
column2: of the University of Glasgow's School of Physics and Astronomy
column3: said: ""The image we've managed to capture is an elegant demonstration of a fundamental property of nature
column4: seen for the very first time in the form of an image.

column1: It's an exciting result which could be used to advance the emerging field of quantum computing and lead to new types of imaging.""
Einstein thought quantum mechanics was ""spooky"" because of the instantaneousness of the apparent remote interaction between the two particles in the entanglement.
It seemed incompatible with parts of his theory of special relativity.
Scientist Sir John Ball later formalised this concept by describing a strong form of entanglement exhibiting this feature.
Bell entanglement is harnessed today in practical applications like quantum computing and cryptography.
But this is the first time it has been captured in a single picture.

The team from the University of Glasgow said they devised a system which fires a stream of entangled photons from a quantum source of light at ""non-conventional"" objects - displayed on liquid-crystal materials which change the phase of the photons as they pass through - to get the image.";1714;['etni0su'

column1: 121;148;807806b387b66c5c9f06ff103a24f9967aa906436274b660890b3f4a38f0d187;posted_link;r/CryptoCurrency;https://cointelegraph.com/news/no-a-quantum-computer-won-t-instantly-reward-you-with-69-000-bitcoins-yet;['ipn127'];['bm_bkly'];[1599679204.0];['Quantum computing could break blockchains in the future. The next big challenge for Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies?'];[nan];2020-09-08;Turner Wright;No
column2: a quantum computer won't instantly reward you with 69
column3: 000 Bitcoins ... yet;"A Bitcoin wallet with nearly $700 million is up for grabs — but anyone intending to be a “crypto thief” and nab it will have to crack the password first.

column1: Crypto Twitter user Alon Gal has put out a call to his 29
column2: 900 followers for solutions on how to gain access to 69370.22 Bitcoin (BTC)
column3: worth roughly $695.4 million as of this writing. According to the Sept. 8 post from Gal
column4: the wallet has been passed between hackers for the past two years without success at determining the password.

column1: Blockchain records show transactions associated with the wallet address began in April 2013. Many online forums like All Private Keys offer members of the crypto community a chance to crack Bitcoin Core wallet.dat files with lost passwords for a share of the remaining balance.
“I have the wallet
column2: ” Gal said. “Google
column3: hook me up with a quantum computer please.”

column1: This raises an interesting question — using a quantum computer
column2: what would be the chance someone could gain access to a random wallet with a lost password
column3: even with a $695 million motivation?

column1: Advancements in quantum computing have been areas of contention for cryptocurrency proponents for some time
column2: as many believe the machines could undermine the security of the Bitcoin blockchain.

column1: Experts
column2: however
column3: are divided on the idea. While the very primitive present-day quantum computers cannot break blockchains and their underlying cryptography
column4: larger ones on the horizon might have that capability.

column1: As recently as June
column2: scientists in China were able to exchange an encryption key at a distance of 1
column3: 120 kilometers using quantum entanglement
column4: exceeding the previous best attempt by 1
column5: 000 kilometers. Further advancements in the technology could potentially mean users would be able to authorize transactions outside of the Internet.

column1: In terms of lost passwords
column2: the technology would have the ability to go through more permutations than the best machines today to find the unencrypted passwords or even to reverse a hash.

column1: Last year
column2: ex-Bitcoin Core developer Peter Todd called Google’s “quantum superiority” feat — a computer which solved an equation which would otherwise take 10
column3: 000 years in just 3 minutes 20 seconds — as “a primitive type of quantum computing that is nowhere near breaking cryptography.”

column1: However
column2: others including Deloitte aren’t so sure. The accounting firm’s website states that current technology in quantum computing makes 25% of all Bitcoin in circulation vulnerable to attack. If enough coins were stolen
column3: the market could potentially crash
column4: undermining confidence in cryptocurrency.

column1: “Even if everyone takes the same protection measures
column2: quantum computers might eventually become so fast that they will undermine the Bitcoin transaction process
column3: ” the firm stated. “In this case the security of the Bitcoin blockchain will be fundamentally broken.”";2824;['g4l0geh'

column1: 122;210;4fefab447b4cfcd83276a8afa63bb5af9ba80e0bf4471a1133ff6dfe05e8b5a5;posted_link;r/science;http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2012-07/uotf-bbu072712.php;['xdug8'];['GraybackPH'];[1343641301.0];['Breakthrough by U of T-led research team leads to record efficiency for next-generation solar cells. Researchers have made a breakthrough in the development of colloidal quantum dot (CQD) films
column2: leading to the most efficient CQD solar cell ever'];[nan];2012-07-29;;Breakthrough by U of T-led research team leads to record efficiency for next-generation solar cells;"TORONTO
column3: ON – Researchers from the University of Toronto (U of T) and King Abdullah University of Science & Technology (KAUST) have made a breakthrough in the development of colloidal quantum dot (CQD) films
column4: leading to the most efficient CQD solar cell ever. Their work is featured in a letter published in Nature Nanotechnology.

column1: The researchers
column2: led by U of T Engineering Professor Ted Sargent
column3: created a solar cell out of inexpensive materials that was certified at a world-record 7.0% efficiency.

column1: Previously
column2: quantum dot solar cells have been limited by the large internal surface areas of the nanoparticles in the film
column3: which made extracting electricity difficult
column4: said Dr. Susanna Thon
column5: a lead co-author of the paper. ""Our breakthrough was to use a combination of organic and inorganic chemistry to completely cover all of the exposed surfaces.""

column1: Quantum dots are semiconductors only a few nanometres in size and can be used to harvest electricity from the entire solar spectrum – including both visible and invisible wavelengths. Unlike current slow and expensive semiconductor growth techniques
column2: CQD films can be created quickly and at low cost
column3: similar to paint or ink. This research paves the way for solar cells that can be fabricated on flexible substrates in the same way newspapers are rapidly printed in mass quantities.

column1: The U of T cell represents a 37% increase in efficiency over the previous certified record. In order to improve efficiency
column2: the researchers needed a way to both reduce the number of ""traps"" for electrons associated with poor surface quality while simultaneously ensuring their films were very dense to absorb as much light as possible. The solution was a so-called ""hybrid passivation"" scheme.

column1: By introducing small chlorine atoms immediately after synthesizing the dots
column2: we're able to patch the previously unreachable nooks and crannies that lead to electron traps
column3: explained doctoral student and lead co-author Alex Ip. ""We follow that by using short organic linkers to bind quantum dots in the film closer together.""

column1: Work led by Professor Aram Amassian of KAUST showed that the organic ligand exchange was necessary to achieve the densest film.

The KAUST group used state-of-the-art synchrotron methods with sub-nanometer resolution to discern the structure of the films and prove that the hybrid passivation method led to the densest films with the closest-packed nanoparticles
column2: stated Professor Amassian.

column1: The advance opens up many avenues for further research and improvement of device efficiencies
column2: which could contribute to a bright future with reliable
column3: low cost solar energy.

column1: According to Professor Sargent
column2: ""Our world urgently needs innovative
column3: cost-effective ways to convert the sun's abundant energy into usable electricity. This work shows that the abundant materials interfaces inside colloidal quantum dots can be mastered in a robust manner
column4: proving that low cost and steadily-improving efficiencies can be combined.""";2973;['c5lhyn8'

column1: 123;572;dd3b5b2b2d36499545c7cdfe0c111cf7cdf1a3bee52e81071ec2a5a4615c4f69;posted_link;r/science;http://news.cornell.edu/stories/2018/08/physics-theory-used-predict-crowd-behavior;['9btcop'];['mvea'];[1535720039.0];['Physics theory used to predict crowd behavior - Researchers developed a highly accurate mathematical approach to predict the behavior of crowds of living creatures
column2: using Nobel Prize-winning methods originally developed to study large collections of quantum mechanically interacting electrons.'];[nan];2018-08-30;Linda B Glaser;Physics theory used to predict crowd behavior | Cornell Chronicle;"Electrons whizzing around each other and humans crammed together at a political rally don’t seem to have much in common
column3: but researchers at Cornell are connecting the dots.

column1: They’ve developed a highly accurate mathematical approach to predict the behavior of crowds of living creatures
column2: using Nobel Prize-winning methods originally developed to study large collections of quantum mechanically interacting electrons. The implications for the study of human behavior are profound
column3: according to the researchers.

column1: For example
column2: by using publicly available video data of crowds in public spaces
column3: their approach could predict how people would distribute themselves under extreme crowding. By measuring density ?uctuations using a smartphone app
column4: the approach could describe the current behavioral state or mood of a crowd
column5: providing an early warning system for crowds shifting toward dangerous behavior.

column1: Tomas Arias
column2: professor of physics
column3: is corresponding author of “Density-Functional Fluctuation Theory of Crowds
column4: ” which published Aug. 30 in Nature Communications. Co-authors include Itai Cohen
column5: professor of physics; lead authors Yunus A. Kinkhabwala
column6: a doctoral student in the field of engineering
column8: a doctoral student in the field of physics; and Jeffrey Silver

column1: Interactions among individuals in a crowd can be complex and difficult to quantify mathematically; the large number of actors in a crowd results in a complex mathematical problem. The researchers sought to predict the behavior of crowds by using simple measurements of density to infer underlying interactions and to use those interactions to predict new behaviors.
To achieve this
column2: they applied mathematical concepts and approaches from density-functional theory (DFT)
column3: a branch of many-body physics developed for quantum mechanical systems
column4: to the behavior of crowds.

column1: “This is one of the all-too-rare cases – particularly where living systems are involved – where the theory preceded the experiments
column2: and the experiments
column3: in precise mathematical detail
column4: completely confirmed the theory
column5: ” said Arias.

column1: “The step of moving this from theory to experiment was not trivial
column2: ” said Cohen. “Yunus and Felipe put in a huge amount of effort to figure out how to apply the theory to real systems.”

column1: To test their theory
column2: the researchers created a model system using walking fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster). They first demonstrated a mathematical way to extract functions that quantify how much the flies like different locations in their environment – the “vexation” function – and how much they mind crowding together – the “frustration” function based on the details of how the population densities change as the flies more around.

column1: They then showed that by mixing and matching this information with observations of a single fly in an entirely new environment
column2: they could accurately predict
column3: before any observations
column4: how a large crowd of flies would distribute themselves in that new environment. They also tracked changes in the overall behavior of the crowd – i.e.
column5: its “mood” – by tracking evolution of the social preference “frustration” function.

column1: While fruit flies were “a convenient
column2: and ethical
column3: first test system
column4: ” Arias said
column5: the behavior of a crowd at a political rally would provide a human example of DFT theory. Individuals will try to find the best location to stand – typically closest to the stage – while avoiding overcrowded areas. When new and better locations become available
column6: individuals are likely to move toward them.

column1: To develop a mathematically predictive theory
column2: the researchers associated a number – the vexation function – with the intrinsic desirability of each location; the lowest value would be at the ideal location
column3: closest to the stage. The frustration function accounts for the undesirability of crowding effects
column4: and a behavioral rule accounts for the tendency of individuals to look for better locations.

column1: “The remarkable mathematical discovery
column2: ” Arias said
column3: “is that precise values for vexation and frustration can be obtained instantly and automatically
column4: simply by observing changes in crowding as the crowd mills around
column5: without the need for any kind of survey to ask people in the crowd how they feel about different locations or crowding together.”

column1: By varying the social circumstances in their fly experiments – such as changing the ratio of male and female
column2: or inducing hunger and thirst – and monitoring the frustration values of the crowd
column3: the researchers showed they can detect changes in the “mood” of the crowd. The DFT approach
column4: therefore
column5: not only predicts crowd behaviors under new circumstances
column6: but also can be used to quickly and automatically detect changes in social behaviors.

column1: Another application
column2: using cell-phone and census data
column3: could analyze political or economic drivers and population pressures to describe and predict large-scale population flows
column4: such as mass migrations. “The resulting predictions of migration during acute events would enable better planning by all levels of government officials
column5: from local municipalities to international bodies
column6: with the potential to save millions of human lives

column1: 124;1190;d3b8e92ab8517013a613f9ef912cab4300cdaace4cfeab6ef1f192d8d0484fec;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.theverge.com/2013/10/10/4824026/a-first-look-inside-googles-secretive-quantum-lab;['1o5sfc'];['DonkeyFuel'];[1381428429.0];"[""Google reveals what it's doing inside its Quantum Artificial Intelligence Lab""]";[nan];2013-10-10;Russell Brandom;A first look inside Google's futuristic quantum lab;"In May
column2: Google launched the Quantum Artificial Intelligence Lab with hardware from the Canadian quantum computing company D-Wave and technical expertise from NASA. It was an ambitious open research project aimed at exploring both the capabilities of quantum computer architecture and the mysteries of space exploration — but in the months since
column3: they've stayed quiet about exactly what kind of work they've been doing there.

column1: Operated at near-absolute-zero temperatures
Tomorrow
column2: they're breaking the silence with a brief short film
column3: set to debut at the Imagine Science Films Festival at Google New York. The film takes a look at various researchers working on the project
column4: as well as the computer itself
column5: which has to be operated at near-absolute-zero temperatures. Researchers hope the quantum architecture will eventually be used to optimize solutions across complex and interconnected sets of variables currently outside the capabilities of conventional computing. That could allow for new solutions in computational medicine or help NASA to construct a more comprehensive picture of the known universe. ""We don't know what the best questions are to ask that computer
column6: says NASA's Eleanor Rieffel in the video. ""That's exactly what we're trying to understand.""

column1: Video provided by Google
We don't know what the best questions are to ask that computer.""
Beyond the film
column2: Google says it's made great leaps in recent experiments with the quantum chips
column3: determining which algorithms work better in a quantum setup and providing further evidence that the D-Wave processor uses quantum entanglement
column4: a behavior that links particles with no apparent physical connection between them. D-Wave has always claimed that its chips involved entanglement
column5: but it had been difficult to conclusively demonstrate before now.

column1: The first practical application has been on Google Glass
column2: as engineers put the quantum chips to work on Glass's blink detector
column3: helping it to better distinguish between intentional winks and involuntary blinks. For engineering reasons
column4: the quantum processor can never be installed in Glass
column5: but together with Google's conventional server centers
column6: it can point the way to a better blink-detecting algorithm. That would allow the Glass processor to detect blinks with better accuracy and using significantly less power. If successful
column7: it could be an important breakthrough for wink-triggered apps
column8: which have struggled with the task so far.";2448;['ccp5bi5'

column1: 125;1257;87528c5cb471c1351fe7d30b96c4337ba4648b5bb3c59373a8f87dccf323778f;posted_link;r/europe;https://www.vttresearch.com/en/news-and-ideas/finlands-first-5-qubit-quantum-computer-now-operational;['r5nfn6'];['karaps'];[1638279379.0];"[""Finland's first 5-qubit quantum computer is now operational""]";[nan];2021-11-30;Pekka Pursula;Finland's first 5-qubit quantum computer is now operational | VTT;"With this milestone
column2: VTT and IQM take a step closer to making quantum computers manufacturable
column3: scalable and more accessible for the world.

column1: ESPOO
column2: Finland (November 30th
column3: 2021) Today
column4: VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland announced that the country’s first operational 5-qubit quantum computer is up and running. Together with the quantum computing hardware startup IQM
column5: VTT has taken its first steps to enable the building of quantum computers that will be both scalable and easier to manufacture
column6: allowing more companies to begin their quantum computing journey.

column1: The incredible computing performance of quantum computers makes it possible to solve problems that are beyond the capabilities of modern high-performance computers. In the future
column2: quantum computers will be used
column3: for instance
column4: to accurately model viruses and drugs or used to design materials that are challenging to design with today’s technology.

column1: “The development of quantum computing will affect all industries. Our experience in building the quantum computer
column2: and our know-how in developing quantum algorithms will help us develop quantum foresight to
column3: for example
column4: identify future trends and support companies in understanding how and when their business will be affected
column5: ” says Pekka Pursula
column6: Research Manager at VTT. “The best way to do this will be for companies to work together with VTT
column7: and actually use our new hardware.”

column1: The big challenge in quantum computing is scalability. Quantum physicists and engineers around the world are trying to figure out how to scale quantum computing hardware to include hundreds and thousands of qubits
column2: scale up the production in an economically efficient way
column3: and scale algorithms and use of quantum computing in real-life applications.

column1: VTT has 30 years of expertise in quantum technology research and excellent facilities to work on hardware scaling. The scaling of the use requires VTT to work hand-in-hand with the companies to develop algorithms for specific applications.
“Today’s announcement marks an important milestone for IQM and for the European quantum initiatives. With the completion of this phase
column2: IQM will become one of the very few quantum companies that can deliver an on-premises quantum computer to a customer. I congratulate our partners
column3: VTT and also the entire IQM team who has managed to deliver this ambitious milestone during the pandemic. This is just the first phase of the delivery and because of our ability to upgrade the systems
column4: we are looking forward to working with VTT on delivering the 20-qubit and the 50-qubit systems
column5: ” says Dr. Jan Goetz
column6: CEO and co-founder of IQM

column1: The 5-qubit quantum computer is part of a larger initiative. VTT and IQM aim to build together a much more powerful 50-qubit quantum computer by 2024 and further develop Finland’s long-lasting technology and expertise in quantum computing. The country already has an active research community called InstituteQ – of which VTT
column2: Aalto University
column3: and Helsinki University are the founding members – which is focused on developing world-class quantum expertise. BusinessQ network supports companies in incorporating quantum technology into their business
column4: enabling growth for the Finnish society.";3211;['hmnsvci'

column1: 126;68;d1b35ba11988a4530389bf3a1e7ea96c95b3f68c4028981dbf30c99559c2888f;posted_link;r/science;http://arxivblog.com/?p=1230;['7ytwg'];['nomdeweb'];[1235102616.0];['Human eye may be able to detect quantum entanglement'];[nan];2009-03-12;Osame Kinouchi says;Human eye could detect spooky action at a distance;"It’s almost a year since Nicolas Gisin and colleagues at the University of Geneva announced that they had calculated that a human eye ought to be able to detect entangled photons. “Entanglement in principle could be seen
column2: ” they concluded.

column1: That’s extraordinary because it would mean that the humans involved in such an experiment would become entangled themselves
column2: if only for an instant.

column1: Gisin is a world leader in quantum entanglement and his claims are by no means easy to dismiss.
Now he’s going a step further saying that the human eye could be used in a Bell type experiment to sense spooky-action-at-a-distance. “Quantum experiments with human
eyes as detectors appear possible
column2: based on a realistic model of the eye as a photon detector
column3: ” they say.

column1: One problem is that human eyes cannot se single photons–a handful are needed to trigger a nerve impulse to the brain.
That might have scuppered the possibility of a Bell-type experiment were it not for some interesting work from Francesco De Martini and buddies at the Universityof Rome
column2: pointing out how the quantum properties of a single particle can be transferred to an ensemble of particles.

column1: That allows a single entangled photon
column2: which a human eye cannot see
column3: to be amplified into a number of entangled photons that can be seen. The eye can then be treated like any other detector.

column1: This all looks like fun. The first person to experience entanglement –mantanglement–would surely be destined for some interesting press covereage.
But the work raises an obvious question: why is Gisin pursuing this line? The human eyeball could be put to use in plenty of optics experiments
column2: so why the focus on mantanglement?

column1: Could it be that Gisin thinks there is more to entanglement than meets the eye?";1750;['c07sahk'
column2: 'c07s6be'
column5: 'c07s4yi'

column1: 127;124;fc4f1fb41a7a0f8d0c48e1c4a949ba388e172d8402da4e40b31caefe060b9484;posted_link;r/science;http://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/mathematical-breakthrough-sets-out-rules-for-more-effective-teleportation/;['16qvz8'];['davidreiss666'];[1358420839.0];['Mathematical breakthrough sets out rules for more effective teleportation:   New protocol advances solutions for more efficient teleportation - the transport of quantum information at the speed of light. '];[nan];2013-01-17;;Mathematical breakthrough sets out rules for more effective teleportation;"New protocol advances solutions for more efficient teleportation - the transport of quantum information at the speed of light.
Building a quantum computer is one of the great challenges of modern physics
column2: and it is hoped that the new teleportation protocol will lead to advances in this area.Sergii Strelchuk

column1: For the last ten years
column2: theoretical physicists have shown that the intense connections generated between particles as established in the quantum law of ‘entanglement’ may hold the key to eventual teleportation of information.

column1: Now
column2: for the first time
column3: researchers have worked out how entanglement could be ‘recycled’ to increase the efficiency of these connections. Published in the journal Physical Review Letters
column4: the result could conceivably take us a step closer to sci-fi style teleportation in the future
column5: although this research is purely theoretical in nature.

column1: The team have also devised a generalised form of teleportation
column2: which allows for a wide variety of potential applications in quantum physics.

column1: Once considered impossible
column2: in 1993 a team of scientists calculated that teleportation could work in principle using quantum laws. Quantum teleportation harnesses the ‘entanglement’ law to transmit particle-sized bites of information across potentially vast distances in an instant.

column1: Entanglement involves a pair of quantum particles such as electrons or protons that are intrinsically bound together
column2: retaining synchronisation between the two that holds whether the particles are next to each other or on opposing sides of a galaxy. Through this connection
column3: quantum bits of information - qubits - can be relayed using only traditional forms of classical communication.

column1: Previous teleportation protocols have fallen into one of two camps
column2: those that could only send scrambled information requiring correction by the receiver or
column3: more recently
column4: “port-based” teleportation that doesn't require a correction
column5: but needs an impractical amount of entanglement – as each object sent would destroy the entangled state.

column1: Now
column2: physicists from Cambridge
column3: University College London
column4: and the University of Gdansk have developed a protocol to provide an optimal solution in which the entangled state is ‘recycled’
column5: so that the gateway between particles holds for the teleportation of multiple objects.

column1: They have even devised a protocol in which multiple qubits can be teleported simultaneously
column2: although the entangled state degrades proportionally to the amount of qubits sent in both cases.

column1: “The first protocol consists of sequentially teleporting states
column2: and the second teleports them in a bulk
column3: ” said Sergii Strelchuk from Cambridge’s Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics
column4: who led the research with colleagues Jonathan Oppenheim of Cambridge and UCL and Michal Horodecki of the University of Gdansk.

column1: “We have also found a generalised teleportation technique which we hope will find applications in areas such as quantum computation.”
Einstein famously loathed the theory of quantum entanglement
column2: dismissing it as “spooky action at a distance”. But entanglement has since been proven to be a very real feature of our universe
column3: and one that has extraordinary potential to advance all manner of scientific endeavor.

column1: “There is a close connection between teleportation and quantum computers
column2: which are devices which exploit quantum mechanics to perform computations which would not be feasible on a classical computer
column3: ” said Strelchuk.

column1: “Building a quantum computer is one of the great challenges of modern physics
column2: and it is hoped that the new teleportation protocol will lead to advances in this area.”

column1: While the Cambridge physicists’ protocol is completely theoretical
column2: last year a team of Austrian scientists reported teleporting photons over 143km
column3: breaking previous records
column4: and quantum entanglement is increasingly seen as an important area of scientific investment. Teleportation of information carried by single atoms is feasible with current technologies
column5: but the teleportation of large objects - such as Captain Kirk - remains in the realm of science fiction.

column1: Adds Strelchuk: “Entanglement can be thought of as the fuel
column2: which powers teleportation. Our protocol is more fuel efficient
column3: able to use entanglement thriftily while eliminating the need for error correction.”";4300;['c7yk7qv'
column4: 'c7yl0vb'
column5: 'c7ylhpe'
column6: 'c7yjwlr'

column1: 128;340;962d78749d85c0b8cd401542e9e49e50ecd7fcbe8bfdb830bac8182840fb308e;posted_link;r/technology;http://www.tomshardware.com/news/ibm-17-qubit-quantum-computer
column2: 34434.html;['6bvczg'];['Dipluz'];[1495103762.0];['IBM Inches Closer To Quantum Supremacy With 16- And 17-Qubit Quantum Computers'];[nan];2017-05-17;Lucian Armasu;IBM Inches Closer To Quantum Supremacy With 16- And 17-Qubit Quantum Computers;"IBM announced that it has built two new quantum computers
column3: which number 16 and 17 qubits
column4: respectively. The 16-qubit computer will be available to developers and researchers at no cost through the IBM Cloud service. The 17-qubit quantum computer will be sold as a prototype commercial product to other companies.

column1: A qubit is the basic unit of information in a quantum computer
column2: as well as the quantum equivalent of a ""bit"" in the conventional computing world. However
column3: instead of having a value of either 0 or 1
column4: it can have 0
column6: or both values at the same time. This is called ""superposition
column7: and it's a fundamental property of quantum computing.

column1: Towards Quantum Supremacy
IBM and Google believe that “quantum supremacy
column2: ” or the moment when quantum computers will solve at least some problems faster than the fastest supercomputers on Earth
column3: will be achieved when we can build a quantum computer with around 50 qubits. Both companies plan to have such a computer ready in the next few years.

column1: So far most universal quantum computers have been stuck at five or fewer qubits
column2: with Google being one of the few to break apart with its nine-qubit quantum computer. Google’s computer was also able to demonstrate one of the first practical applications of universal quantum computers by accurately simulating a hydrogen H2 molecule.

column1: Although we don’t know yet if Google has further upgraded its quantum computer since it last talked about the nine-qubit one
column2: IBM seems to have one-upped Google this time with 16- and 17-qubit quantum computers.

column1: IBM’s New Quantum Computers
The 16-qubit quantum computer will allow more complex experimentation than its previous five-qubit system
column2: according to IBM. It will be freely accessible to developers
column3: programmers
column4: and researchers who want to run quantum algorithms
column5: work with individual qubits
column6: or explore tutorials and simulations. Beta access is available through the IBM Quantum Experience program
column7: and a new software development kit (SDK) is available on GitHub.

column1: The 17-qubit quantum computer leverages significant improvements in materials
column2: device
column3: and architecture to make it IBM’s most powerful universal quantum computer. The chip is still a prototype but it will be offered for sale to interested businesses looking to do a quantum leap (get it?) over their competitors.

column1: The significant engineering improvements announced today will allow IBM to scale future processors to include 50 or more qubits
column2: and demonstrate computational capabilities beyond today’s classical computing systems
column3: ” said Arvind Krishna
column4: senior vice president and director of IBM Research and Hybrid Cloud. “These powerful upgrades to our quantum systems
column5: delivered via the IBM Cloud
column6: allow us to imagine new applications and new frontiers for discovery that are virtually unattainable using classical computers alone

column1: Quantum Volume
Although IBM seems to already be ahead of everyone else when it comes to the number of quits in universal quantum computers--with the exception of D-Wave’s 2
column2: 000 qubit system
column3: which is not a universal quantum computer--it noted that the number of qubits isn’t the most important factor
column4: or
column5: rather
column6: not the only factor that matters.

column1: Due to the fragile nature of quantum information
column2: the quality of the qubits
column3: how they talk to each other
column4: and minimizing quantum errors are even more important when it comes to increasing the computational power of a quantum system.

column1: This is why IBM has adopted a new metric
column2: which it calls “quantum volume
column3: ” to measure the computational power of quantum computers. According to the company
column4: the quantum volume metric accounts for the number and quality of qubits
column5: circuit connectivity
column6: and error rates of operations. IBM also noted that its 17-qubit prototype offers a significant improvement in quantum volume over previous quantum computers.

column1: Over the next few years
column2: IBM plans to increase the quantum volume of its qubits even more aggressively by improving all aspects of its quantum processors
column3: including increasing their qubit number to 50 or more.";4048;['dhptmfv'

column5: 'dhpxlc1'
column6: 'dhpz1hr'

column1: 129;391;daeb6efec215a0d119c5fd2435909018fcad75759f6ac500c3c1a28beb9a9ab6;posted_link;r/science;https://www.iflscience.com/physics/time-might-not-flow-in-just-one-direction-in-the-quantum-world/;['r2kr6y'];['jcvzneuro'];[1637924533.0];['New research published in the journal Communications Physics suggests that the flow of time at a quantum level doesn’t have to go in just one direction. Quantum systems
column2: in certain conditions
column3: might move both forward and backward in time.'];[nan];2021-11-26;Dr Alfredo Carpineti;Time Might Not Flow In Just One Direction In The Quantum World;"New research suggests that the flow of time at a quantum level doesn’t have to go in just one direction. Quantum systems
column4: in certain conditions
column5: might move both forward and backward in time. And this is a very exciting discovery.

column1: We are not talking about time machines or the quantum realm of the Marvel Universe here. But just how we experience time at our level might not exactly be the true nature of time. Time is one of the great mysteries of the universe. We experience it and we know that it works in a certain way
column2: going in the same direction from the past into the future.

column1: This particular direction – the arrow of time as it is called – has been connected with the concept of entropy
column2: the measure of the disorder of a system. In an isolated system
column3: such as our universe
column4: the entropy will always increase and the direction of the increase matches the direction of time passing.

column1: As reported in the journal Communications Physics
column2: the researchers looked at phenomena where entropy changes are small. By the fundamental properties of quantum mechanics
column3: it is possible that the entropy could spontaneously decrease (like going backward in time). They also employed another important quantum mechanical property: superposition. In that state
column4: your physical system can exist in multiple configurations.

column1: “If a phenomenon produces a large amount of entropy
column2: observing its time-reversal is so improbable as to become essentially impossible. However
column3: when the entropy produced is small enough
column4: there is a non-negligible probability of seeing the time-reversal of a phenomenon occur naturally
column5: ” lead author Dr Giulia Rubino from the University of Bristol
column6: said in a statement.

column1: “We can take the sequence of things we do in our morning routine as an example. If we were shown our toothpaste moving from the toothbrush back into its tube
column2: we would be in no doubt it was a rewinded recording of our day. However
column3: if we squeezed the tube gently so only a small part of the toothpaste came out
column4: it would not be so unlikely to observe it re-entering the tube
column5: sucked in by the tube’s decompression.”

column1: The international team looked at a quantum superposition with a state that evolves both backward and forward in time. They found that more often than not
column2: this results in the system ending up forward in time. But for small entropy changes
column3: the system can continue to evolve both forward and backward in time.

column1: This work is pointing at the big unknown that is Time at its most fundamental level. And this work hints at we might understand it even less than we previously thought.
“Although time is often treated as a continuously increasing parameter
column2: our study shows the laws governing its flow in quantum mechanical contexts are much more complex. This may suggest that we need to rethink the way we represent this quantity in all those contexts where quantum laws play a crucial role
column3: ” Dr Rubino concluded.";2897;['hm563dq'
column4: 'hm570rl'
column5: 'hm6caun'
column6: 'hm5p0va'

column1: 130;905;97d732ce06d0598fb53d185fa49e854d46c9af018c8292c4c180f3e320f2dd1d;posted_link;r/science;https://www.sciencealert.com/scientists-have-achieved-direct-counterfactual-quantum-communication-for-the-first-time;['6bo7j8'];['lekevoid'];[1495022307.0];['Scientists Achieve Direct Counterfactual Quantum Communication'];[nan];2017-05-09;Fiona MacDonald;Scientists Achieve Direct Counterfactual Quantum Communication For The First Time;"Quantum communication is a strange beast
column2: but one of the weirdest proposed forms of it is called counterfactual communication - a type of quantum communication where no particles travel between two recipients.

column1: Theoretical physicists have long proposed that such a form of communication would be possible
column2: but now
column3: for the first time
column4: researchers have been able to experimentally achieve it - transferring a black and white bitmap image from one location to another without sending any physical particles.

column1: If that sounds a little too out-there for you
column2: don't worry
column3: this is quantum mechanics
column4: after all. It's meant to be complicated. But once you break it down
column5: counterfactual quantum communication actually isn't as bizarre as it sounds.

column1: First up
column2: let's talk about how this differs from regular quantum communication
column3: also known as quantum teleportation
column4: because isn't that also a form of particle-less information transfer?

column1: Well
column2: not quite. Regular quantum teleportation is based on the principle of entanglement - two particles that become inextricably linked so that whatever happens to one will automatically affect the other
column3: no matter how far apart they are.

column1: But that form of quantum teleportation still relies on particle transmission in some form or another. The two particles usually need to be together when they're entangled before being sent to the people on either end of the message (so
column2: they start in one place
column3: and need to be transmitted to another before communication can occur between them).

column1: Alternatively
column2: particles can be entangled at a distance
column3: but it usually requires another particle
column4: such as photons (particles of light)
column5: to travel between the two.

column1: Very simply
column2: the quantum Zeno effect occurs when an unstable quantum system is repeatedly measured.

column1: In the quantum world
column2: whenever you look at a system
column3: or measure it
column4: the system changes. And in this case
column5: unstable particles can never decay while they're being measured (just like the proverbial watched kettle that will never boil)
column6: so the quantum Zeno effect creates a system that's effectively frozen with a very high probability.

column1: If you want to delve a little deeper
column2: the video below gives a great explanation:

column1: Counterfactual quantum communication is based on this quantum Zeno effect
column2: and is defined as the transfer of a quantum state from one site to another without any quantum or classical particle being transmitted between them.

column1: This requires a quantum channel to run between two sites
column2: which means there's always a small probability that a quantum particle will cross the channel. If that happens
column3: the system is discarded and a new one is set up.

column1: To set up such a complex system
column2: researchers from the University of Science and Technology of China placed two single-photon detectors in the output ports of the last of an array of beam splitters.

column1: Because of the quantum Zeno effect
column2: the system is frozen in a certain state
column3: so it's possible to predict which of the detectors would 'click' whenever photons passed through. A series of nested interferometers measure the state of the system to make sure it doesn't change.

column1: It works based on the fact that
column2: in the quantum world
column3: all light particles can be fully described by wave functions
column4: rather than as particles. So by embedding messages in light the researchers were able to transmit this message without ever directly sending a particle.

column1: The team explains that the basic idea for this set up came from holography technology.
In the 1940s
column2: a new imaging technique - holography - was developed to record not only light intensity but also the phase of light
column3: the researchers write in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

column1: One may then pose the question: Can the phase of light itself be used for imaging? The answer is yes.""
The basic idea is this - someone wants to send an image to Alice using only light (which acts as a wave
column2: not a particle
column3: in the quantum realm).

column1: Alice transfers a single photon to the nested interferometer
column2: where it can be detected by three single-photon detectors: D0
column3: D1
column4: and Df.

column1: If D0 or D1 'click'
column2: Alice can conclude a logic result of one or zero. If Df clicks
column3: the result is considered inconclusive.

column1: After the communication of all bits
column2: the researchers were able to reassemble the image - a monochrome bitmap of a Chinese knot. Black pixels were defined as logic 0
column3: while white pixels were defined as logic 1 …

column1: In the experiment
column2: the phase of light itself became the carrier of information
column3: and the intensity of the light was irrelevant to the experiment.""

column1: Not only is this a big step forward for quantum communication
column2: the team explains it's technology that could also be used for imaging sensitive ancient artefacts that couldn't survive direct light shined on them.

column1: The results will now need to be verified by external researchers to make sure what the researchers saw was a true example of counterfactual quantum communication.
Either way
column2: it's a pretty cool demonstration of just how bizarre and unexplored the quantum world is.";5024;['dho8am5'
column3: 'dho7n03'
column4: 'dhocqf7'
column5: 'dhodc1d'
column6: 'dhpfvwr'

column1: 131;49;0a9c1f1a54aed7e0815c4e989a407ea7c2e936a54df73f3b42234c4417d00870;posted_link;r/Physics;http://arstechnica.com/science/news/2010/05/quantum-teleportation-achieved-over-ten-miles-of-free-space.ars?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss;['c6llq'];['Vailhem'];[1274423874.0];['Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles of free space'];[nan];2010-05-19;Casey Johnston;Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles of free space;"Quantum teleportation has achieved a new milestone or
column2: should we say
column3: a new ten-milestone: scientists have recently had success teleporting information between photons over a free space distance of nearly ten miles
column4: an unprecedented length. The researchers who have accomplished this feat note that this brings us closer to communicating information without needing a traditional signal
column5: and that the ten miles they have reached could span the distance between the surface of the earth and space.

column1: As we've explained before
column2: ""quantum teleportation"" is quite different from how many people imagine teleportation to work. Rather than picking one thing up and placing it somewhere else
column3: quantum teleportation involves entangling two things
column4: like photons or ions
column5: so their states are dependent on one another and each can be affected by the measurement of the other's state.

column1: When one of the items is sent a distance away
column2: entanglement ensures that changing the state of one causes the other to change as well
column3: allowing the teleportation of quantum information
column4: if not matter. However
column5: the distance particles can be from each other has been limited so far to a number of meters.

column1: Teleportation over distances of a few hundred meters has previously only been accomplished with the photons traveling in fiber channels to help preserve their state. In this particular experiment
column2: researchers maximally entangled two photons using both spatial and polarization modes and sent the one with higher energy through a ten-mile-long free space channel. They found that the distant photon was still able to respond to changes in state of the photon they held onto even at this unprecedented distance.

column1: However
column2: the long-distance teleportation of a photon is only a small step towards developing applications for the procedure. While photons are good at transmitting information
column3: they are not as good as ions at allowing manipulation
column4: an advancement we'd need for encryption. Researchers were also able to maintain the fidelity of the long-distance teleportation at 89 percent— decent enough for information
column5: but still dangerous for the whole-body human teleportation that we're all looking forward to.";2182;['c0qgtgd'
column6: 'c0qhx1t'

column1: 132;149;27a1ac339afffbeea41cd4abeff29fd11ca7f2dd3bf51a223ad9910235676940;posted_link;r/technology;https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/us-government-stop-dickering-and-prepare-for-post-quantum-encryption-now/;['wwru9z'];['Tough_Gadfly'];[1661367939.0];"['US Government: Stop Dickering and Prepare for Post-Quantum Encryption Now ""Do not wait until the quantum computers are in use by our adversaries to act
column2: the government\'s computer security agency warns.']";[nan];2022-08-24;Stephen Shankland;US Government: Stop Dickering and Prepare for Post-Quantum Encryption Now;"""Do not wait until the quantum computers are in use by our adversaries to act
column3: the government's computer security agency warns.

column1: If you're wondering when your company should start taking seriously the security problems that quantum computers pose
column2: the answer is now
column3: the US government says.

column1: Do not wait until the quantum computers are in use by our adversaries to act
column2: the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency said in a guide published Wednesday. ""Early preparations will ensure a smooth migration to the post-quantum cryptography standard once it is available.""

column1: Quantum computers
column2: which take advantage of the weird physics of the ultrasmall to perform calculations
column3: are a nascent technology today. Companies like IBM
column4: Intel
column5: Google and Microsoft have joined a host of startups in investing billions of dollars in their development
column6: though. And as they become more powerful
column7: quantum computers could crack conventional encryption

column1: That's why the US government's National Institute of Standards and Technology embarked on a search for post-quantum cryptography technology that would protect sensitive information even from quantum computers. With submissions and analysis from experts around the world
column2: NIST picked four post-quantum encryption algorithms and is working to standardize them by 2024.

column1: Quantum computers also could undermine cryptocurrencies
column2: which also use today's cryptography technology.";1453;['ilmymii'
