column1: 133;190;99d319d8d7aed0d78dd74b23a1bb077539f4ad4a6ec9bdbf5cbcdd72058992d9;posted_link;r/todayilearned;http://discovermagazine.com/2010/apr/01-back-from-the-future;['1dzxfi'];['MrMag1c'];[1368103802.0];['TIL according the quantum mechanical experiments
column2: the future determines the present'];[nan];2010-08-26;Zeeya Merali;Back From the Future;"A series of quantum experiments shows that measurements performed in the future can influence the present. Does that mean the universe has a destiny—and the laws of physics pull us inexorably toward our prewritten fate?

column1: Jeff Tollaksen may well believe he was destined to be here at this point in time. We’re on a boat in the Atlantic
column2: and it’s not a pleasant trip. The torrential rain obscures the otherwise majestic backdrop of the volcanic Azorean islands
column3: and the choppy waters are causing the boat to lurch. The rough sea has little effect on Tollaksen
column4: barely bringing color to his Nordic complexion. This is second nature to him; he grew up around boats. Everyone would agree that events in his past have prepared him for today’s excursion. But Tollaksen and his colleagues are investigating a far stranger possibility: It may be not only his past that has led him here today
column5: but his future as well.

column1: Tollaksen’s group is looking into the notion that time might flow backward
column2: allowing the future to influence the past. By extension
column3: the universe might have a destiny that reaches back and conspires with the past to bring the present into view. On a cosmic scale
column4: this idea could help explain how life arose in the universe against tremendous odds. On a personal scale
column5: it may make us question whether fate is pulling us forward and whether we have free will.

column1: The boat trip has been organized as part of a conference sponsored by the Foundational Questions Institute to highlight some of the most controversial areas in physics. Tollaksen’s idea certainly meets that criterion. And yet
column2: as crazy as it sounds
column3: this notion of reverse causality is gaining ground. A succession of quantum experiments confirm its predictions—showing
column4: bafflingly
column5: that measurements performed in the future can influence results that happened before those measurements were ever made.

column1: As the waves pound
column2: it’s tough to decide what is more unsettling: the boat’s incessant rocking or the mounting evidence that the arrow of time—the flow that defines the essential narrative of our lives—may be not just an illusion but a lie.

column1: Tollaksen
column2: currently at Chapman University in Orange County
column3: California
column4: developed an early taste for quantum mechanics
column5: the theory that governs the motion of particles in the subatomic world. He skipped his final year of high school
column6: instead attending physics lectures by the charismatic Nobel laureate Richard Feynman at Caltech in Pasadena and learning of the paradoxes that still fascinate and frustrate physicists today.

column1: Primary among those oddities was the famous uncertainty principle
column2: which states that you can never know all the properties of a particle at the same time. For instance
column3: it is impossible to measure both where the particle is and how fast it is moving; the more accurately you determine one aspect
column4: the less precisely you can measure the other. At the quantum scale
column5: particles also have curiously split personalities that allow them to exist in more than one place at the same time—until you take a look and check up on them. This fragile state
column6: in which the particle can possess multiple contradictory attributes
column7: is called a superposition. According to the standard view of quantum mechanics
column8: measuring a particle’s properties is a violent process that instantly snaps the particle out of superposition and collapses it into a single identity. Why and how this happens is one of the central mysteries of quantum mechanics.

column1: “The textbook view of measurements in quantum mechanics is inspired by biology
column2: ” Tollaksen tells me on the boat. “It’s similar to the idea that you can’t observe a system of animals without affecting them.” The rain is clearing
column3: and the captain receives radio notification that some dolphins have been spotted a few minutes away; soon we’re heading toward them. Our attempts to spy on these animals serve as the zoological equivalent of what Tollaksen terms “strong measurements”—the standard type in quantum mechanics —because they are anything but unobtrusive. The boat is loud; it churns up water as it speeds to the location. When the dolphins finally show themselves
column4: they swim close to the boat
column5: arcing through the air and playing to their audience. According to conventional quantum mechanics
column6: it is similarly impossible to observe a quantum system without interacting with the particles and destroying the fragile quantum behavior that existed before you looked.

column1: Most physicists accept these peculiar restrictions as part and parcel of the theory. Tollaksen was not so easily appeased. “I was smitten
column2: and I knew there was no chance I was ever going to do anything else with my life
column3: ” he recalls. On Feynman’s advice
column4: the teenager moved to Boston to study physics at MIT. But he missed the ocean. “For the first time in my life
column5: I lost the background sound of surf
column6: ” he says. “That was actually traumatic.”

column1: Mindful that a job in esoteric physics might not be the best way to put food on his family’s table
column2: Tollaksen worked on a computing start-up company while pursuing his Ph.D. But if the young man wasn’t sure of his calling
column3: fate quickly gave him a nudge when a physicist named Yakir Aharonov visited the neighboring Boston University. Aharonov
column4: now at Chapman with Tollaksen
column5: was renowned for having codiscovered a bizarre quantum mechanical effect in which particles can be affected by electric and magnetic fields
column6: even in regions where those fields should have no reach. But Tollaksen was most taken by another area of Aharonov’s research: a time-twisting interpretation of quantum mechanics.

column1: “Aharonov was one of the first to take seriously the idea that if you want to understand what is happening at any point in time
column2: it’s not just the past that is relevant. It’s also the future
column3: ” Tollaksen says. In particular
column4: Aharonov reanalyzed the indeterminism that forms the backbone of quantum mechanics. Before quantum mechanics arrived on the scene
column5: physicists believed that the laws of physics could be used to determine the future of the universe and every object within it. By this thinking
column6: if we knew the properties of every particle on the planet we could
column8: calculate any person’s fate; we could even calculate all the thoughts in his or her head.

column1: That belief crumbled when experiments began to reveal the indeterministic effects of quantum mechanics—for instance
column2: in the radioactive decay of atoms. The problem goes like this
column3: Tollaksen says: Take two radioactive atoms
column4: so identical that “even God couldn’t see the difference between them.” Then wait. The first atom might decay a minute later
column5: but the second might go another hour before decaying. This is not just a thought experiment; it can really be seen in the laboratory. There is nothing to explain the different behaviors of the two atoms
column6: no way to predict when they will decay by looking at their history
column7: and—seemingly—no definitive cause that produces these effects. This indeterminism
column8: along with the ambiguity inherent in the uncertainty principle
column10: who fumed that God doesn’t play dice with the universe.

column1: It bothered Aharonov as well. “I asked
column2: what does God gain by playing dice?” he says. Aharonov accepted that a particle’s past does not contain enough information to fully predict its fate
column3: but he wondered
column4: if the information is not in its past
column5: where could it be? After all
column6: something must regulate the particle’s behavior. His answer—which seems inspired and insane in equal measure—was that we cannot perceive the information that controls the particle’s present behavior because it does not yet exist.

column1: “Nature is trying to tell us that there is a difference between two seemingly identical particles with different fates
column2: but that difference can only be found in the future
column3: ” he says. If we’re willing to unshackle our minds from our preconceived view that time moves in only one direction
column4: he argues
column5: then it is entirely possible to set up a deterministic theory of quantum mechanics.

column1: In 1964 Aharonov and his colleagues Peter Bergmann and Joel Lebowitz
column2: all then at Yeshiva University in New York
column3: proposed a new framework called time-symmetric quantum mechanics. It could produce all the same treats as the standard form of quantum mechanics that everyone knew and loved
column4: with the added benefit of explaining how information from the future could fill in the indeterministic gaps in the present. But while many of Aharonov’s colleagues conceded that the idea was built on elegant mathematics
column5: its philosophical implications were hard to swallow. “Each time I came up with a new idea about time
column6: people thought that something must be wrong

column1: Perhaps because of the cognitive dissonance the idea engendered
column2: time-symmetric quantum mechanics did not catch on. “For a long time
column3: it was nothing more than a curiosity for a few philosophers to discuss
column4: ” says Sandu Popescu at the University of Bristol
column5: in England
column6: who works on the time-symmetric approach with Aharonov. Clearly Aharonov needed concrete experiments to demonstrate that actions carried out in the future could have repercussions in the here and now.

column1: Through the 1980s and 1990s
column2: Tollaksen teamed up with Aharonov to design such upside-down experiments
column3: in which outcome was determined by events occurring after the experiment was done. Generally the protocol included three steps: a “preselection” measurement carried out on a group of particles; an intermediate measurement; and a final
column4: “postselection” step in which researchers picked out a subset of those particles on which to perform a third
column5: related measurement. To find evidence of backward causality—information flowing from the future to the past—the experiment would have to demonstrate that the effects measured at the intermediate step were linked to actions carried out on the subset of particles at a later time.

column1: Tollaksen and Aharonov proposed analyzing changes in a quantum property called spin
column2: roughly analogous to the spin of a ball but with some important differences. In the quantum world
column3: a particle can spin only two ways
column4: up or down
column5: with each direction assigned a fixed value (for instance
column6: 1 or –1). First the physicists would measure spin in a set of particles at 2 p.m. and again at 2:30 p.m. Then on another day they would repeat the two tests
column7: but also measure a subset of the particles a third time
column8: at 3 p.m. If the predictions of backward causality were correct
column10: the spin measurement conducted at 2:30 p.m. (the intermediate time) would be dramatically amplified. In other words
column11: the spin measurements carried out at 2 p.m. and those carried out at 3 p.m. together would appear to cause an unexpected increase in the intensity of spins measured in between
column12: at 2:30 p.m. The predictions seemed absurd
column13: as ridiculous as claiming that you could measure the position of a dolphin off the Atlantic coast at 2 p.m. and again at 3 p.m.
column14: but that if you checked on its position at 2:30 p.m.
column15: you would find it in the middle of the Mediterranean.

column1: And the amplification would not be restricted to spin; other quantum properties would be dramatically increased to bizarrely high levels too. The idea was that ripples of the measurements carried out in the future could beat back to the present and combine with effects from the past
column2: like waves combining and peaking below a boat
column3: setting it rocking on the rough sea. The smaller the subsample chosen for the last measurement
column4: the more dramatic the effects at intermediate times should be
column5: according to Aharonov’s math. It would be hard to account for such huge amplifications in conventional physics.

column1: For years this prediction was more philosophical than physical because it did not seem possible to perform the suggested experiments. All the team’s proposed tests hinged on being able to make measurements of the quantum system at some intermediate time; but the physics books said that doing so would destroy the quantum properties of the system before the final
column2: postselection step could be carried out. Any attempt to measure the system would collapse its delicate quantum state
column3: just as chasing dolphins in a boat would affect their behavior. Use this kind of invasive
column4: or strong
column5: measurement to check on your system at an intermediate time
column6: and you might as well take a hammer to your apparatus.

column1: By the late 1980s
column2: Aharonov had seen a way out: He could study the system using so-called weak measurements. (Weak measurements involve the same equipment and techniques as traditional ones
column3: but the “knob” controlling the power of the observer’s apparatus is turned way down so as not to disturb the quantum properties in play.) In quantum physics
column4: the weaker the measurement
column5: the less precise it can be. Perform just one weak measurement on one particle and your results are next to useless. You may think that you have seen the required amplification
column6: but you could just as easily dismiss it as noise or an error in your apparatus.

column1: The way to get credible results
column2: Tollaksen realized
column3: was with persistence
column4: not intensity. By 2002 physicists attuned to the potential of weak measurements were repeating their experiments thousands of times
column5: hoping to build up a bank of data persuasively showing evidence of backward causality through the amplification effect.

column1: Just last year
column2: physicist John Howell and his team from the University of Rochester reported success. In the Rochester setup
column3: laser light was measured and then shunted through a beam splitter. Part of the beam passed right through the mechanism
column4: and part bounced off a mirror that moved ever so slightly
column5: due to a motor to which it was attached. The team used weak measurements to detect the deflection of the reflected laser light and thus to determine how much the motorized mirror had moved.

column1: That is the straightforward part. Searching for backward causality required looking at the impact of the final measurement and adding the time twist. In the Rochester experiment
column2: after the laser beams left the mirrors
column3: they passed through one of two gates
column4: where they could be measured again—or not. If the experimenters chose not to carry out that final measurement
column5: then the deflected angles measured in the intermediate phase were boringly tiny. But if they performed the final
column6: postselection step
column7: the results were dramatically different. When the physicists chose to record the laser light emerging from one of the gates
column8: then the light traversing that route
column10: ended up with deflection angles amplified by a factor of more than 100 in the intermediate measurement step. Somehow the later decision appeared to affect the outcome of the weak
column12: even though they were made at an earlier time.

column1: This amazing result confirmed a similar finding reported a year earlier by physicists Onur Hosten and Paul Kwiat at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. They had achieved an even larger laser amplification
column2: by a factor of 10
column4: when using weak measurements to detect a shift in a beam of polarized light moving between air and glass.

column1: For Aharonov
column2: who has been pushing the idea of backward causality for four decades
column3: the experimental vindication might seem like a time to pop champagne corks
column4: but that is not his style. “I wasn’t surprised; it was what I expected
column5: ” he says.

column1: Paul Davies
column2: a cosmologist at Arizona State University in Tempe
column3: admires the fact that Aharonov’s team has always striven to verify its claims experimentally. “This isn’t airy-fairy philosophy—these are real experiments
column4: ” he says. Davies has now joined forces with the group to investigate the framework’s implications for the origin of the cosmos (See “Does the Universe Have a Destiny?” below).

column1: Vlatko Vedral
column2: a quantum physicist at the University of Oxford
column3: agrees that the experiments confirm the existence and power of weak measurements. But while the mathematics of the team’s framework offers a valid explanation for the experimental results
column4: Vedral believes these results alone will not be enough to persuade most physicists to buy into the full time-twisting logic behind it.

column1: For Tollaksen
column2: though
column3: the results are awe-inspiring and a bit scary. “It is upsetting philosophically
column4: ” he concedes. “All these experiments change the way that I relate to time
column5: the way I experience myself.” The results have led him to wrestle with the idea that the future is set. If the universe has a destiny that is already written
column6: do we really have a free choice in our actions? Or are all our choices predetermined to fit the universe’s script
column7: giving us only the illusion of free will?

column1: Tollaksen ponders the philosophical dilemma. Was he always destined to become a physicist? If so
column2: are his scientific achievements less impressive because he never had any choice other than to succeed in this career? If I time-traveled back from the 21st century to the shores of Lake Michigan where Tollaksen’s 13-year-old self was reading the works of Feynman and told him that in the future I met him in the Azores and his fate was set
column3: could his teenage self—just to spite me—choose to run off and join the circus or become a sailor instead?

column1: The free will issue is something that Tollaksen has been tackling mathematically with Popescu. The framework does not actually suggest that people could time-travel to the past
column2: but it does allow a concrete test of whether it is possible to rewrite history. The Rochester experiments seem to demonstrate that actions carried out in the future—in the final
column3: postselection step—ripple back in time to influence and amplify the results measured in the earlier
column4: intermediate step. Does this mean that when the intermediate step is carried out
column5: the future is set and the experimenter has no choice but to perform the later
column6: postselection measurement? It seems not. Even in instances where the final step is abandoned
column8: the intermediate weak measurement remains amplified
column9: though now with no future cause to explain its magnitude at all.

column1: I put it to Tollaksen straight: This finding seems to make a mockery of everything we have discussed so far.
Tollaksen is smiling; this is clearly an argument he has been through many times. The result of that single experiment may be the same
column2: he explains
column3: but remember
column4: the power of weak measurements lies in their repetition. No single measurement can ever be taken alone to convey any meaning about the state of reality. Their inherent error is too large. “Your pointer will still read an amplified result
column5: but now you cannot interpret it as having been caused by anything other than noise or a blip in the apparatus
column6: ” he says.

column1: In other words
column2: you can see the effects of the future on the past only after carrying out millions of repeat experiments and tallying up the results to produce a meaningful pattern. Focus on any single one of them and try to cheat it
column3: and you are left with a very strange-looking result—an amplification with no cause—but its meaning vanishes. You simply have to put it down to a random error in your apparatus. You win back your free will in the sense that if you actually attempt to defy the future
column4: you will find that it can never force you to carry out postselection experiments against your wishes. The math
column5: Tollaksen says
column6: backs him on this interpretation: The error range in single intermediate weak measurements that are not followed up by the required post­selection will always be just enough to dismiss the bizarre result as a mistake.

column1: Tollaksen sums up this confounding argument with one of his favorite quotes
column2: from the ancient Jewish sage Rabbi Akiva: “All is foreseen; but freedom of choice is given.” Or as Tollaksen puts it
column3: “I can have my cake and eat it too.” He laughs.

column1: Here
column2: finally
column3: is the answer to Aharonov’s opening question: What does God gain by playing dice with the universe? Why must the quantum world always retain a degree of fuzziness when we try to look at it through the time slice of the present? That loophole is needed so that the future can exert an overall pull on the present
column4: without ever being caught in the act of doing it in any particular instance.

column1: “The future can only affect the present if there is room to write its influence off as a mistake
column2: ” Aharonov says.

column1: Whether this realization is a masterstroke of genius that explains the mechanism for backward causality or an admission that the future’s influence on the past can never fully be proven is open to debate. Andrew Jordan
column2: who designed the Rochester laser amplification experiment with Howell
column3: notes that there is even fundamental controversy over whether his results support Aharonov’s version of backward causality. No one disputes his team’s straightforward experimental results
column4: but “there is much philosophical thought about what weak values really mean
column5: what they physically correspond to—if they even really physically correspond to anything at all
column6: ” Jordan says. “My view is that we don’t have to interpret them as a consequence of the future’s influencing the present
column7: but rather they show us that there is a lot about quantum mechanics that we still have to understand.” Nonetheless
column8: he is open to being convinced otherwise: “A year from now
column9: I may well change my mind.”

column1: Popescu argues that the Rochester findings are hugely important because they open the door to a completely new range of laboratory explorations based on weak measurements. In starting from the conventional interpretation of quantum mechanics
column2: physicists had not realized such measurements were possible. “With his work on weak measurements
column3: Aharonov began to pose questions about what is possible in quantum mechanics that nobody had ever even thought could be articulated
column4: ” Popescu says.

column1: Aharonov remains circumspect. He has spent most of his adult life waiting for recognition of the merit of his theory. If it is destined that mainstream physics should finally take serious notice of his time-twisting ideas
column2: then so it will be.

column1: And Tollaksen? He too is at one with his destiny. A few months ago he moved to Laguna Beach
column2: California. “I’m in a house where I can hear the surf again—what a relief
column3: ” he says. He feels that he is finally back to where he was always meant to be.

column1: DOES THE UNIVERSE HAVE A DESTINY?
Is feedback from the future guiding the development of life
column2: the universe
column3: and
column4: well
column5: everything? Paul Davies at Arizona State University in Tempe and his colleagues are investigating whether the universe has a destiny—and if so
column6: whether there is a way to detect its eerie influence.

column1: Cosmologists have long been puzzled about why the conditions of our universe—for example
column2: its rate of expansion—provide the ideal breeding ground for galaxies
column3: stars
column4: and planets. If you rolled the dice to create a universe
column5: odds are that you would not get one as handily conducive to life as ours is. Even if you could take life for granted
column6: it’s not clear that 14 billion years is enough time for it to evolve by chance. But if the final state of the universe is set and is reaching back in time to influence the early universe
column7: it could amplify the chances of life’s emergence.

column1: With Alonso Botero at the University of the Andes in Colombia
column2: Davies has used mathematical modeling to show that bookending the universe with particular initial and final states affects the types of particles created in between. “We’ve done this for a simplified
column3: one-dimensional universe
column4: and now we plan to move up to three dimensions
column5: ” Davies says. He and Botero are also searching for signatures that the final state of the universe could retroactively leave on the relic radiation of the Big Bang
column6: which could be picked up by the Planck satellite launched last year.

column1: Ideally
column2: Davies and Botero hope to find a single cosmic destiny that can explain three major cosmological enigmas. The first mystery is why the expansion of the universe is currently speeding up; the second is why some cosmic rays appear to have energies higher than the bounds of normal physics allow; and the third is how galaxies acquired their magnetic fields. “The goal is to find out whether Mother Nature has been doing her own postselections
column3: causing these unexpected effects to appear
column4: ” Davies says.

column1: Bill Unruh of the University of British Columbia in Vancouver
column2: a leading physicist
column3: is intrigued by Davies’s idea. “This could have real implications for whatever the universe was like in its early history
column4: ” he says.";24413;['c9vlxbe'

column1: 134;10;a41d76eadff84589702670d2f5dd459a669c15e3e6f2a2a770f4d3e20e352ade;posted_link;r/science;http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2011/09/12/3314227.htm;['kdlov'];['davidreiss666'];[1315869460.0];['Scientists squeeze light past quantum limit'];[nan];2011-09-12;ABC;Scientists squeeze light past quantum limit;"The race to discover gravity waves may be getting closer to the finish line with scientists successfully squeezing light using quantum mechanics.
The detection of gravity waves is one of the Holy Grails of astronomy and astrophysics. It will allow researchers to study the inner workings of exploding stars and colliding black holes.
Einstein's general theory of relativity predicts these massive astronomical events generate tiny fluctuations
column2: causing the fabric of space-time to expand and contract - like ripples on the surface of a pond.

column1: These yet to be discovered waves require the most sensitive detectors ever built
column2: but up until now they've not been sensitive enough.

column1: Now an international team of scientists
column2: which includes Professor David Blair
column3: Director of the Australian International Gravity Wave Research Centre at the University of Western Australia
column4: report on a new technique in the journal Nature Physics
column5: which almost doubles the sensitivity of these detectors.

column1: Blair says the GEO600 gravity wave observatory in Germany is the first practical application of this new technology
column2: and is part of a global network called the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO).

column1: The observatory will measure tiny variations in the distance travelled by two halves of a laser beam that's been split along perpendicular arms of a kilometre-sized instrument called an interferometer.
But any the change in the beams caused by gravity waves is so tiny
column2: it's drowned out by a quantum effect called vacuum fluctuations.

column1: Empty space isn't really empty
These fluctuations
column2: caused by the uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics involves virtual particles popping in and out of existence for short periods.

column1: Scientists know it's real because they leave detectable traces. Virtual photons
column2: for example
column3: produce tiny shifts in energy levels in atoms and minute changes in the magnetic moment of electrons.

column1: Blair says
column2: ""We overcome this by using so-called squeezed light
column3: which changes quantum uncertainty in the frequencies monitored by the detectors"".

column1: The key technology was pioneered by gravitational wave researchers at the Australian National University led by Professor David McClelland.""
Using special crystals
column2: this squeezing process creates quantum entangled photons between the ferometer's mirrors
column3: turning green light into infrared light
column4: and turning one photon into two""
column5: says Blair.

column1: Quantum entanglement happens when two interacting subatomic particles are separated
column2: yet changes made to one will impact the other
column3: even though they're not physically connected.

column1: The strange thing is
column2: when you look at it
column3: there's nothing there
column4: yet this 'nothing' which is the vacuum fluctuation can be squeezed and we know it's real
column5: because it changes the sensitivity of the detector
column6: says Blair.

column1: It's mind blowing
column2: changing the way we think about light and the universe"".

column1: It will allow us to test theories such as time standing still on the surface of black holes and space getting warped to the most extreme degree possible"".";3039;['c2jg3b9'
